                "reviews": "\nCRITIQUE \r\n\r\n1. If you want to know what this movie is about, then simply watch Star \r\nWars Episode IV (A New Hope), because the story is nearly verbatim with \r\nelements thrown in from episodes V and VI for good measure.\r\n\r\n2. The leads who take the rein from the old Star Wars Universe are: \r\nHispanic, black, and a woman. There is nothing wrong with this in and \r\nof itself, but when it is done simply to be politically correct, then \r\nthe story suffers. I think one critic describes this best when she \r\nsaid, \"For the first time in Star Wars history, a franchise will be \r\nbuilt around the adventures of the sort of people that Hollywood \r\nroutinely overlooks: women and people of color. So even if The Force \r\nAwakens sucks, it's made one big diverse achievement for Hollywood.\" \r\nThis means the only place you will see an honest review of this movie \r\nis in the user reviews here at IMDb\r\n\r\n3. Luke is now Obi Wan, his long lost daughter is the new hope, and his \r\nnephew is the new Darth Vader\r\n\r\n4. They broke nearly every rule established by the original Star Wars. \r\nJedi talent no longer takes years of training, nor does one need to be \r\nstrong with the force to hold his own in a light saber battle against a \r\ntrained Sith lord, etc.\r\n\r\nWHAT THEY COULD HAVE DONE\r\n\r\nThere are 100 places they could have taken this story. They could have \r\nmade Jar Jar a secret Sith lord who was playing dumb all these years, \r\nthey could have worked in elements of Star Wars Rebels and made Ezra a \r\nSith lord, or they could have had it where Luke turned to the dark \r\nside. I even heard early rumors that they were going to have Finn find \r\nLuke's severed hand with a light saber in it.\r\n\r\nTo me, it would have made the most sense to do a story where the \r\nRepublic is now the political force of the Galaxy and the First Order \r\nare the rebels. Luke could have been training a new Jedi order and they \r\ncould have shown a growing Sith threat, with a real villain and not the \r\nweanie in panties that we got in this movie, throughout the battles \r\nwith the First Order. They could have made Hans more distinguished \r\n(after all he was a King and it's been 30 years, so he should have \r\ngrown up by now). Instead, we got the same Han Solo from 1975 but who \r\nlooked 40 years older and disheveled. I'm sure Harrison Ford had no \r\nintention of doing another Star Wars movie and insisted that this would \r\nbe the last one. So he would have been killed off no matter what. \r\nHowever, it could have been far less predictable and more creative and \r\ntouching. If they wanted to keep the story line they went with, then \r\nthey still could have started this way and shown how Kylo Rey was \r\nturning to the dark side.\r\n\r\nAny of these would have been far better than the trash I saw tonight. \r\nIt's amazing how I could think of these story lines (as I'm sure can \r\n1000s of other Star Wars fans) but none of the so called talented \r\nwriters, producers, and directors in Hollywood can do this? This simply \r\namounts to lazy writing and oversight.\r\n\r\nCONCLUSION\r\n\r\nBecause everything was so predictable and the story was a rehash of \r\nwhat we already saw, the movie was BORING! It's amazing how Hollywood \r\ncan continue to put out movies like this, cheat their viewers, and then \r\nwonder in astonishment why everyone stays home to stream or pirate \r\nmovies. Maybe it's because more and more movies these days simply \r\nsupport overpaid political activists whose only creative effort is to \r\nmake a political statement at the expense of entertainment.\r\n\r\nI'm done with Star Wars. I don't need to see episodes VIII or IX, \r\nbecause I already know what is going to happen. Episode VIII and IX \r\nwill be remakes of the Empire Strikes Back and Return of the Jedi with \r\nRen as Luke, Luke as Obi Wan, and Kylo Rey as Darth Vader. I'm sure \r\nVIII will have the surprise statement by Kylo Rey when he battles Ren \r\nsaying, \"Ren, I am your cousin,\" and IX will end with Ren bringing Rey \r\nto the good side with little furry creatures celebrating in tree tops \r\nand the ghosts of Luke and Han looking approvingly over the scene. \r\nYeah, been there done that, there is no sense in my wasting money or \r\ntime to do it again.\r\n\r\nStar Wars is Dead! Thanks Disney and Abrams and you politically correct \r\nwhackos. Thanks a lot!\r\n\r\nA NOTE ON POSITIVE REVIEWS\r\n\r\nAfter reading many of the positive reviews, I can only come to the \r\nconclusion that 1/3 of them are written by hard core Star Wars fans who \r\nwill rave about anything with the \"Star Wars\" logo attached to it and \r\nwill refuse to their dying day that they were wrong about this movie, \r\n1/3 by people who never saw Star Wars and accept this cheap rip off \r\nbecause it is the only version of the story they have seen, and 1/3 by \r\nstudio hacks.\r\n\r\nThe positive reviewers have also resorted to calling the negative \r\nreviewers \"Haters.\" It's amazing how convenient it is today for people \r\nto throw that word around to discredit anyone who has a differing \r\nopinion. That should tell you everything you need to know about the \r\ncharacter and honesty of the positives reviewers.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Argemaluco",
                "reviewDate": "1 February 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "The  5th  Wave",
                "reviewTotalVote": "7",
                "reviewUseful": "3",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nI knew beforehand that The 5th Wave was based on a juvenile novel, and\ntherefore, I supposed that it was going to put more emphasis on the\nromance and the \"feelings\" than the science fiction aspects.\nNevertheless, I decided to watch it because I have always had a\nparticular affinity for the extraterrestrial invasion tales.\nConsidering all that, I can't blame anyone; having had to suffer this\npiece of junk is exclusively my fault. The mentioned invasion\napproximately occupies the first 15 minutes of the film, when the\nobligatory huge spaceships occupy the heaven of Earth and unleash four\ndestructive \"waves\", starting by a magnetic pulse which leaves humanity\nwithout electricity; then, there are earthquakes and swells which\ndestruct coastal areas; and finally, the bird flu which to infect the\nrest of the population. So, the few survivors get organized into\nimprovised militias waiting for the feared \"fifth wave\"... but all that\nwill have to wait while we follow the girl Callie in the search of her\nbrother Sam, in which she will experience (tedious) adventures and find\n(insipid) romance with a survivor hiding a dangerous secret. Meanwhile,\nwe watch Sam and Ben, a school partner of Callie's, initiating their\ntraining as soldiers in order to fight against \"the others\" (like the\naliens call them), destructing their innocence while acquiring the\nruthless aptitude to kill other people. In summary, we basically have\nThe Road for teenagers on the one hand, and on the other hand, Full\nMetal Jacket also for teenagers. The result: incredibly boring and\nabsolutely inert. That was exactly what I expected from the romantic\nsub-plot; but I also found the rest (formed by apocalyptic drama,\naction scenes and the general tone of the movie) soporific. We never\nfeel any suspense of the desperation of human species in danger of\nextinction. The scale of the unimaginable tragedy witnessed by the\nsurvivors is immediately forgotten, in order to give way to the trite\njuvenile drama. I think I have seen films in the SyFy channel with a\nbigger emotional impact and more endearing characters. After all, The\n5th Wave ends up ignoring the extraterrestrial invasion because its\nmercenary purpose was employing the end of the world as a simple\nbackground to the usual romantic triangle between a girl, her\nmysterious savior and the school partner she has always been fond of.\nThe 5th Wave is an absolute waste of time, and I really struggle to\nfind a single positive element to mention about it (I didn't even like\nthe performance from Chl\u00f6e Grace Moretz, who I consider as one of the\nbest contemporary actresses). I think that any episode of the series\nColony has better ideas and more interesting drama about the\nextraterrestrial invasion. As usual, the TV saves the day.\n"

                "reviewTitle": "Predictable.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "3",
                "reviewUseful": "0",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nI think SF films like this are popular because they have the effect of\nmaking the audience feel that 'life is normal and the world is fine'\nwhen the film is over. The only problem with that subtext is that in\nreality life is getting downright screwed up for plenty of people these\ndays even if there is no alien invasion coming at any time soon. The\npremise for making movies like this is that this type of SF is \"good\nhonest escapism\" but I think that disastrous scenarios for Earth are\nnot just the stuff of SF. There is no significant number of electric\ncars on the road today (even after the idea that relying on oil for\nenergy is bad for Earth's atmosphere has long been established) and\nwe-as a society-are still virtually completely dependent on big oil as\nour main source of fuel for our vehicles and the thing that balances\nour economy also. And woe betide anyone who says using so much oil is\ndumb especially since we can use electricity to power vehicles cleaner\n& cheaper. Films like this are \"reassuring\" to people because it's all\n'just a story.' Maybe big oil is run by aliens. The acting in the film\nwas predictably fair to good and the special effects were predictably\nminimal. There were exactly three other people in a cinema that could\neasily accommodate about 300 people when I saw this film on a weekend\nmatin\u00e9e showing in the early afternoon. Apparently people also don't go\nto the movies on the weekend anymore either.\n"

                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\n\"Nature abhors a vacuum.\" As it is with science, so it is with movie\nstudios. Where there is a gap, it will be filled. Four years after the\nlast \"Twilight\" film, the year after the \"Hunger Games\" series ended\nand the year before the \"Divergent\" and \"Maze Runner\" franchises finish\nshowing teens how to survive the end of the world, 2016 gives us \"The\n5th Wave\" (PG-13, 1:52). Based on Rick Yancey's 2013 novel of the same\nname, \"The 5th Wave\" has taken its place as the 5th major YA movie\nseries of the new millennium, and utilizes elements of the previous\nfour. This film has the love triangle of \"Twilight\" and \"The Hunger\nGames\", the \"I gotta be me\" sensibility of \"Twilight\" and \"The\nDivergent Series\", the \"don't look behind the curtain\" plot line of the\nlast three of those film series and the \"girl power\" element of the\nfirst three. Lastly, as USA Today's review of the book states, \"The 5th\nWave\" does \"for aliens what 'Twilight' did for vampires.\" Of course,\nborrowing from previous stories doesn't mean that this one isn't\noriginal, or good."

                "reviewTotalVote": "4",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nSo far this film completes a very fun and very solidly made franchise\nthat will go nicely with my Kung Fu Panda collection. DreamWorks really\nimpressed me with this one. Proving that Shrek the Third was just a\nhiccup (no pun intended). And I love it when I struggle to say which\nfilm is the best out of the franchise, that means they made a great\nfranchise. One thing that DreamWorks knows how to do is keep you\nguessing. People always assume the film is going to do badly but\nactually ends up hitting a home run, this is no exception. If\nDreamWorks keeps this up, they can overrun Pixar as they are going\nthrough a weak time right now with the exception of Inside Out.\nDreamWorks continues to impress with year after year of good to great\nfilms. Heck I think Home is better then Cars 2. Now what stands out\nabout the film itself is it isn't afraid to take chances. And more\ntimes then not actually ends up paying off. The voice talent is well,\ntalented. Each character whether its returning ones or new ones each of\nthem does a marvelous job. Bryan Cranston, Kate Hudson, and especially\nJ.K. Simmons who literally blends into the character. I couldn't\nimagine him talking behind the microphone because he didn't use his\nactual voice rather made the character his. The negatives I have is\nthat it doesn't spend time with the characters we've come to enjoy.\nTigress even though she was in it more then the other Furious Fives,\nbut I still would like to see her in action more then they did. They\ncompletely shun the other characters like Viper, Mantis, Crane, and\nMonkey. They sort of pushed them aside and made room for the newer\ncharacters. Which is fine, but after coming to know and love these\ncharacters especially Tigress, I would liked to have seen more from\nthem. Also, the story seems overdone especially the villain. Even\nthough I like J.K. Simmons as the character, the character himself is\njust Ti Lung all over again (sorry if I misspelled his name). And is\nthe third time a villain has underestimated Po with the same question,\n\"Is he the one destined to stop me?\" Or something along those lines.\nBut despite those mistakes the film makes up in shire courage.\nDreamWorks could have easily been lazy and made this another Shrek the\nThird, but thank heavens it wasn't that. I had a lot of fun watching\nthis as a full grown adult, so kids should have a blast with this film.\nLike in DreamWorks fashion this is a film worthy of the entire family\nand you deserve it so you can get the bad taste of Norm of the North\nout of your mouths. This is how animated film are meant to be.\nDreamWorks proves they are still one of the best in the business, maybe\nthe best right now. Check it out, you will regret it if you don't. Now\nto grade: Animation: A+ Characters: A Voice Acting: A Story: B+ Risk\nValue: A+ Music: A- (Best score by Hans Zimmer in a long time.)\nOverall: A\n"

                "reviews": "\nFor years, Michael Bay has been hailed as one of the worst directors of\ntoday. With the release of 13 Hours, people now seem hopeful that he\ncan make good movies! 13 Hours focuses on a security team in Libya who\ndon't even have an idea on why they're there. It is basically them\ntrying to fight and figure out how they're going to escape from their\ncompound, which is being attacked, and return home to America. John\nKrasinski plays the main character, and he proves that he can become\nmore than just the pretty boy from The Office, as he gives a very\nstellar performance. The rest of the cast does well too. Also, some\nof the camera work can be unbelievably shaky at the beginning, although\nfor some reason, it's not like that throughout the entire movie.\nAction-wise, this movie has some very intense sequences that will make\nyou wonder if they are going to make it or not.                 "reviewTotalVote": "4",
                "reviewUseful": "3",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nWhen I learned history in school I had trouble to relate. It seemed\nthat they wanted me to learn mostly dates and places. And dates and\nplaces were not able to fascinate me. Luckily I was also an avid reader\nof fiction and reading historical novels made the events of the past so\nmuch more real . So to this day I have a tendency to look at historical\nevents through the interpretation of artists, be it writers, painters,\nmusicians or directors of movies. The older you get the more you\nrealize that even events which happen during your life time and\nsometimes just around the corner from you are being interpreted in so\nmany different ways, that at the end nobody really knows what happened.\nThe attack in Benghazi certainly falls into this category. So\npolitically charged and obfuscated, what was really going on? So I went\nto see the movie. First of all the movie was filmed in Malta not in\nLibya, I have been to Malta not to Libya and while there are\nsimilarities, they are not the same. The movie posed more questions\nthan answers for me. Why was there so little security for the compound\nof the ambassador? Why did the official refused to send help? Why were\nthese highly paid security contractors not used to help? Why did\nTripoli refuse to send help? Why did the American base in Italy or\nSpain did not send help? All these places were not far away? I read\nsomewhere that these American bases took 15 hours before they were able\nto dispatch somebody??? Why do the Libyan hate the Americans so much?\nObviously big failure all around,from the state department to the\npentagon and from some bureaucrats. So we are left with a handful of\nmacho super warriors, who finally get permission, to fight hundreds of\nterrorists and that is the movie. We see this story in American war\nmovies over and over again The super heroes who dodge all bullets while\neverybody else dies , they keep their sense of humor in even the most\nvolatile situation and come out okay at the other end. Well, not\neverybody came out okay at the end and the film did a good job showing\nthe humanity of those whose job is to kill and to be tough. So leaving\nthe movie I was as knowledgeable as I was before. I do not know what\nhappened I do not know what is being disguised from us and what orders\nhave been issued to those who were there to shut up. I am glad to know\nthat the surviving members of the warriors resigned and are pursuing a\nless dangerous life. Would I recommend that movie?                 "reviewAuthor": "ccorral419",
                "reviewDate": "20 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Wow!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "5",
                "reviewUseful": "3",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nDirector Michael Bay (\"Transformers\") rips reality from today's\nheadlines presenting an in your face, behind-the-scenes look at the\n2012 Benghazi attack in Libya that took the lives of US Ambassador\nChris Stevens (Matt Letsher \"Scandal\") and Sean Smith, along with the\nlives of other US soldiers and many Libyan rebels. \"Wow\" is the word\nthe comes to mind while both experiencing and then reflecting on the\nfilm. John Krasinski (\"The Office\") joins his fellow soldiers (James\nBadge Dale, Pablo Schreiber, David Denman \"Parenthood,\" Dominic Fumusa\n\"Nurse Jackie,\" and Max Martine) and others as they are charged with\nprotecting their compounds and rescuing Stevens. Each actor, along with\nthe always great-to-hate character actor David Costabile (\"Suits\"), are\nexcellent in their respective gritty roles, with Krasinski successfully\nstepping outside of his \"The Office\" role. Bay knows rock'm sock'm film\nmaking, and it all comes in handy here. Unfortunately, he is one of\nthose directors who feels an up close, constantly moving camera is the\nbest way to get his point across. Because of this style of filmmaking,\nmuch of the action is in blur. However, when he backs the camera away,\nallowing the audience to take in the surroundings, the result builds\ntension beyond belief. The \"Hillary\" effect isn't addressed here, so no\nneed to beat a dead horse. Realistic writing by Chuck Hogan, and\nscreenplay by Mitchell Zuckoff, keep the audience glued to the screen,\naction and storyline. From the film, and what we know from the news,\nsomething went seriously wrong in the communication in Libya, forcing\nour soldiers to step up and do what they do best - survive! Don't miss\nthis one!\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Dave McClain (dave-mcclain@hotmail.com)",
                "reviewDate": "30 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "This film will give you and your family two of the finest hours you'll spend in a theater this year.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "7",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nCoasties get no respect. At least, not as much as soldiers, sailors,\nairmen and marines get. Even the word may sound derogatory to an\noutsider, but coastie is actually the most widely accepted term for\nCoast Guardsmen. Less complimentary terms include the \"Navy National\nGuard\", \"the Navy's little sister\" and \"puddle pirates\". See? No\nrespect. Even though the roots of the U.S. Coast Guard go back to 1790\nand its current missions make it as valuable in peacetime as in\nwartime, and its focus is jobs that none of the other armed services\nundertake regularly (if at all), few people know much about coasties. I\nblame the movies. There aren't very many Coast Guard movies out there.\n2006's \"The Guardian\" is the only one I could think of before 2016's\n\"The Finest Hours\" (PG-13, 1:57), which really is an \"incredible true\nstory\"! In this film, Chris Pine takes a break from the bridge of the\nStarship Enterprise to captain a much smaller ship, but one in no less\ndanger than his ship in the \"Star Trek\" movies. Pine plays Boatswain's\nMate First Class Bernard Webber, stationed in Chatham, Massachusetts in\nthe early 1950s. As a coastie, he's very capable, but meek. As a man,\nhe's handsome, but shy. Nevertheless, Bernie rises to any occasion when\npresented with a challenge. He wins the heart of a pretty and assertive\nlocal girl named Miriam (Holliday Grainger) and soon they're engaged.\nOn the day that Bernie plans to officially notify his commanding\nofficer (Eric Bana) that he's getting married, he gets sent out into a\nnor'easter to rescue about three dozen merchant mariners whose ship was\none of two disabled in this especially severe winter storm."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Greg (gregmoroberts@yahoo.com)",
                "reviewDate": "20 September 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Best Film of the Year",
                "reviewTotalVote": "82",
                "reviewUseful": "44",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nOf the nearly 400 films being showcased at this year's Toronto \r\nInternational Film Festival (TIFF), Denis Villeneuve's Sicario was the \r\none film at the top of my 'Must See' list. Having premiered at this \r\nyear's Cannes Film Festival where it went on to be nominated for the \r\nprestigious Palme D'Or, Sicario stars Emily Blunt, Joh Brolin and \r\nBenicio Del Toro as members of a government task force who attempt to \r\napprehend a villainous drug lord. \r\n\r\nDirector Denis Villeneuve is on some kind of roll. His previous films \u0096 \r\nPolytechnique, Incendies and Prisoners \u0096 were all thought provoking \r\ncharacter pieces offset by realistic and graphic depictions of \r\nviolence. Sicario opens with just such a scene as Blunt's Kate Macer \r\nleads a rain on a Mexican drug house near Phoenix, Arizona and \r\ndiscovers dozens of executed victims packed into the walls. Audiences \r\nwill have barely settled in their seats and scrunched on but a handful \r\nof popcorn kernels when the shocking revelation is revealed on screen. \r\n\r\nFrom here, Macer is forced to work with Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) and \r\nAlejandro (Del Toro) who works as a sort of fixer on both sides of the \r\nborder. Their work leads them to drug trafficker Fausto (Julio Cesar \r\nCedillo) and the group then works to transport the criminal back across \r\nthe border. Their journey will be met with many obstacles with \r\nshoot-outs at border crossings and a tense hunt and shoot inside a drug \r\ntrafficking tunnel connecting the two countries. \r\n\r\nThe focus of Sicario (which is Mexican slang for 'hitman') is clearly \r\non Blunt's lead character and Blunt is up to the task in being the \r\nsmartest person in the room while also being the one most left in the \r\ndark as to the team's objectives. She will be continually conflicted by \r\nher male peers particularly their penchant for instigating or \r\nresponding forcefully to appeared violence. The action settled between \r\nMacer's first-hand education thrust the film forward to a very \r\nsatisfying and acceptable conclusion. \r\n\r\nThe supporting cast is equally engrossing particularly Del Toro who \r\nwill be on screen for most all of the film's most memorable shots. Del \r\nToro's character is clouded in mystery and unclear motives and Del Toro \r\ngives his best performance since Traffic.\r\n\r\nSicario was penned by Taylor Sheridan who played Deputy Chief Hale on \r\nFX's Sons of Anarchy. His take on the war on drugs and the violence and \r\nhuman costs that surround the battle are dead on target. The realism \r\nresults in Sicario being hardly the crowd-pleaser. It is a bleak and \r\ngrim film that might just be Villeneuve's best work to date. \r\n\r\nThe photography by Roger Deakins is stunning. Expect Deakins to garnish \r\nanother Academy Award nomination for his efforts here to go with his \r\nwork on The Shawshank Redemption and Skyfall. \r\n\r\nAlso worthy of note is the music by J\u00f3hann J\u00f3hannsson that grabs you by \r\nthe balls while the action unfolds. \r\n\r\nSicario might be too bleak for Academy voters, but make no mistake of \r\nSicario's impact and brilliance. It was on my 'Must See' list for a \r\nreason and did not disappoint. Easily the best film of the year so far.\r\n\r\n\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "Jackson Booth-Millard",
                "reviewDate": "22 October 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Sicario",
                "reviewTotalVote": "15",
                "reviewUseful": "9",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nI saw the poster for this film on the side of bus, the three leading\ncast members certainly appealed to me, and the title that I did not\nunderstand the meaning of, I saw it was getting great reviews, so I\nwent to see it, directed by Denis Villeneuve (Prisoners). Basically\nidealistic FBI Special Weapons and Tactics Teams agent Kate Macer\n(Emily Blunt) and her partner Reggie Wayne (Daniel Kaluuya) survive an\nexplosion in Chandler, Arizona, following the discovery of dozens of\ncorpses within the walls of a house. Kate's boss Dave Jennings\n(Titanic's Victor Garber) recommends her to undercover CIA Special\nActivities Division officer Matt Graver (Josh Brolin) who enlists her\nto aid in finding those responsible for the bomb that killed two\nofficers. Kate is partnered with enigmatic consultant Alejandro\n(Benicio Del Toro), who has a questionable past, she thought they were\ntravelling to El Paso, Texas, in fact they arrive in Ju\u00e1rez, Mexico,\nand the mission is to crack down on the escalating drugs war, and\nspecifically to capture or kill cartel boss Manuel D\u00edaz (Bernardo P.\nSaracino). At one point the transportation vehicles the officers are\ntravelling in are caught in traffic, this is in fact some some of prior\ngathering of cartel members, Kate is appalled by the attack on these\ncriminals, with no regard for the safety of civilians in their\nvehicles. Matt and his team are interested in finding D\u00edaz's boss, drug\nlord Fausto Alarc\u00f3n (Julio Cedillo), they target money launderers, Kate\nis ignored for believing she could be close to making an arrest on\nD\u00edaz, and the situation gets worse when she recognises local cop Ted\n(Jon Bernthal) is wearing the same rubber wristband as a money\nlaunderer, he is one of many cops, that he names in interrogation,\nworking for D\u00edaz. On a night that Matt and his team plan to follow\nD\u00edaz, using distraction, Mexican police officer Silvio (Maximiliano\nHern\u00e1ndez) is kidnapped by Alejandro, suspecting something Kate goes\nagainst orders and follows Alejandro, escaping his attempt to kill her\nshe demands answers from Matt, he says that their goal is to restore\npower to the Colombian Medell\u00edn Cartel, this is apparently the best\nhope for the U.S. Alejandro and Silvio manage to catch up with D\u00edaz,\nSilvio is killed by Alejandro and he kills D\u00edaz at Alarc\u00f3n's estate, it\nwas Alarc\u00f3n that brutally killed his wife and daughter, Alejandro kills\nthe drug lord's wife and two sons so he can experience the same loss he\ndid, before he finally kills him. Alejandro returns and Kate is ashamed\nand dishonoured by his actions, she refuses to sign a waiver stating\nthat everything they did was \"by the book\", but she does so when her\nown gun is put to her head, Kate initially then points the gun at\nAlejandro, but she stops herself, lowers her gun and allows him to walk\naway. Also starring Daniel Kaluuya as Reggie Wayne, Jeffrey Donovan as\nSteve Forsing, Raoul Trujillo as Rafael and Lora Martinez-Cunningham as\nJacinta. To be completely, despite great performances by always\nreliable Blunt, the interesting Del Toro and decent Brolin, I found\nthis film a bit complicated most of the time, I don't know if it was\ntoo political, or I was just generally confused. I understood the main\ncharacter being caught in situations she did not expect, and the title\n\"sicario\" means \"hitman\" in Spanish, but I could only just follow the\naction, I was however gripped by the gun-filled and explosive moments,\noverall I can't fully agree with five stars out of five that critics\ngive it, but I did like it, it's a worthwhile crime thriller. Good, in\nmy opinion!\n"

                "reviewTitle": "A masterclass in acting (Del Toro) and directing (Villeneuve)",
                "reviewTotalVote": "2",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\n2015 was a very good year in films, and \"Sicario\" can be considered one\nof its highlights, but not one of the very best. First off, for me this\nmovie was a great way to get to know for the first time two big names\nand talents in the industry: lead actor Benicio Del Toro and director\nDenis Villeneuve. The former did an outstanding job -maybe Oscar\nworthy, totally nomination worthy- at portraying a cold and expert man\n(I won't get into detail not to spoil anything), the latter made great\nuse of the south-US/Mexico landscapes, but also of the focus on small\ndetails, to give a proper identity to the film, which eventually looks\nslick and classy while also portraying horrifying images (i.e. the\namazing first scene). I also liked Josh Brolin's take as an eccentric,\nno-nonsense DoD consultant, though his character tended to turn darker\nand darker for no apparent reason. Probably (hopefully) he's gonna have\na big role in the sequel. J\u00f3hann J\u00f3hannsson keeps up the good work with\na simple, yet fitting soundtrack: he reminds me more and more of the\nmastermind, Hans Zimmer, in that sense. But let's get to the nay part.\nBefore watching \"Sicario\" I'd heard that Emily Blunt's performance was\nthe one to look after. It isn't. She really tries, and she does so hard\nshe gets irritating. She's always swearing, crying, being disappointed,\nand all that in a desperate way, as if she needed to show us she's the\nlead actress in a boys' flick. Her partner does the same, or even\nworse. Finally, some words on the complicated plot. At the end of the\nstory, everything fits well, and you won't be disappointed, but in the\nmaking it feels at times disorienting and excessively cryptic."

                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nSicario is about as ordinary a thriller as you can make without going\ntoo wrong. The acting is generally good and the photography is\nbeautiful. Where the film goes wrong is in two places. (1) The\ndirection fails to take advantage of two situations in which enormous\ntension could have been built and built - the scene on the line waiting\nto cross the border and the scene in the tunnel. Instead of being\nmasterpieces, these scenes are merely OK. The setups are excellent, but\nthe execution is merely ordinary. (2) The character played by Blunt is\nnot true to herself, in the end, yet there is no real compelling reason\nto explain the transition. Films where the protagonist changes as a\nresult of some fundamental reckoning are great, but in this case, it\ndoesn't hold up for me. This is why the film ends as it does, because\nthere is nothing to sustain the ending around the main character."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "brchthethird",
                "reviewDate": "24 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "An excellent examination of the morally foggy \"War on Drugs\"",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nHow far we should go in prosecuting the drug war is the main concern of\nSICARIO, the latest directorial effort by Denis Villeneuve. The\nviolence brought about by America's war on drugs is a sensitive one\nbecause of the complex motives and casualties on both sides. This film\ndoesn't really offer any answers, but it does provide enough to\nmentally chew on as the morally gray areas inherent in such an effort\nare explored. The audience's surrogate is Kate (Emily Blunt), an FBI\nagent who volunteers for an inter-agency task force that takes her into\nthe heart of Mexico with the goal of finding a top boss in the cartel.\nAlong for the mission is a mysterious person, Alejandro (Benicio del\nToro), whose allegiance and motives are unclear (at first). If there's\none weakness in the film, it's Emily Blunt's character, unfortunately.\nWhile she and her FBI partner provide the bulk of the dramatic\nconflict, she never really develops satisfactorily, instead relegated\nto a mostly passive observer. Benicio del Toro's character is by far\nthe most interesting and compelling, and he get most of the best\nmoments and dialogue. From a technical standpoint, SICARIO compares\nwell with Villeneuve's other work and features outstanding\ncinematography, courtesy of Roger Deakins (who also worked on\nPRISONERS). Slow and deliberate camera-work nicely complements the\nslow-burn pacing, which culminates in one of the tensest (and morally\nambiguous) scenes in recent memory. If there's one thing that this film\ndoes extremely well, it shows that the drug war has far-reaching\neffects from the top of the food chain down to a cop who is just trying\nto provide for his family (even if it is on the wrong side of the law).\nI should also mention the excellent score by Johann Johannsson,\nalthough a key element of it is reminiscent of Hans Zimmer's style. If\nI had seen this last year, it most certainly would have made my top\nten. As it stands, it further establishes Denis Villeneuve as a talent\nto be reckoned with and is suitably entertaining to boot.\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "ironhorse_iv",
                "reviewDate": "9 November 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "I can somewhat bonded with this movie. It was mostly a good watch.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "17",
                "reviewUseful": "10",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nLet's be honest, here. The dead is indeed alive. It's nice to see the\nwords, Spectre come back from the dead, after a 40 year absence from\nthe franchise. It has been way too long. The reason for this, is that\nwhen 1961's novel 'Thunderball', was being made; original James Bond\nauthor, Ian Fleming opt for some help from his friends, such as\nscreenwriter, Kevin McClory & some others to make a film version of it.\nOnly to screw them from writing credit, when the film script version\nwas completed in 1964. This lead, to a long legal battle, between\nMcClory & Fleming, until McClory won out, in 1976; retained the filming\nrights of the novel. With that deal, came the lost, at least ten\nprevious own literary properties & titles. One of them, happen to be\nthe Spectre Organization in which, James Bond fight against in the\nnovel, Thunderball. Once, considered as a future James Bond title in\nthe 1960s & 1980s, Spectre wasn't made into a movie, until November\n2013, when Eon Production and McClory's estate formally settled the\nissue. This allow, MGM, Eon Production's mother company to acquire the\nfull copyright film rights to the concept of Spectre and all of the\ncharacters associated with. Still, the production for this film was\ntroublesome. First off, the movie went, highly over-budget, and\nover-schedule. Many of these problems, came from the fact, that Sony\ndemanded rewrites after a 2014 email hack. They really want to cover\nup, and recon the leak spoilers, even beyond when filming started. This\ncause, the movie to have a very incredibly underwhelming and at times,\nnonsensical third act. I have to say, its shows. The main plot of James\nBond (Daniel Craig) trying to unravel, a new terrorist organization,\ndoesn't match, well, with the sub-plot of M (Ralph Fiennes) trying to\nstop, his government from creating, a unified New World Order\nsurveillance network. It was very uneven. I also get that the movie\ntakes place 18 months, after the events of 2012's Skyfall, but it\nreally seem, like all the flaws that James Bond had, in the last movie,\nis non-existence in this film. It's really odd, how he can barely hit\nhis target in the last movie, and now, he's has the power of improbably\naiming skills. It's so jarring. What happen to all of his weaknesses?\nFor an action movie, this is probably, the weakest in the Daniel\nCraig's James Bond series of films. There are way too much, badly done,\nCGI effects. It's always stale, when we see the same, repetitive\naction. Most of all, lots of bad guys just standing around, talking and\nmaking idiotic decision making. Still, they did, get some hits on Bond.\nSad, the whole torturing scene isn't one of them. I didn't like the\nwhole, non-selling. It was a bit confusing on what the hell, was going\non! However, I do like the demolition scene that the villains plan.\nStill, the filming process must have been extremely miserable for both\nthe returning director, Sam Mendes & main actor, Daniel Craig. There\nhas been times, when, Craig had joked that he would rather slit his\nwrists than play 007 again, and Mendes threating to leave, the\nproduction. However, I guess, cooler heads prevails, because they were\nable to pull, the movie, off. It was far from being a total disaster!\nIn my opinion, the movie that has James Bond's first encounter with the\nglobal criminal organization, Spectre, since 1971's Diamonds Are\nForever was mostly alright to me. I have only a few problems with it.\nFirst off, the movie length. It's a really strained watch. Since, the\nmovie does have some slow & often clich\u00e9s parts, you really feel, the\nlong runtime. Still, the movie does have a lot more, humor than the\nprevious Daniel Craig's films. I like, how the writers were a lot more\nopen to a lot of old school Bond mannerism. It's nice to see that side\nof Bond, again. Also, I do love the cool references to the older films.\nGreat homages. I also like, how Moneypenny (Naomie Harris) & Q (Ben\nWhishaw) are given, more to do, than minor background characters. Some\nof the best scenes, are with those characters. However, this movie is\nmissing the emotional drive. The chemistry between Bond and his main\nlove-interest, Dr. Madeleine Swann (L\u00e9a Seydoux) is questionable at\nbest, due to the age different. I really found, their love-affair,\nkinda forced. While Seydoux was alright as eye-candy. Her acting, not\nso much. Her French accent is a little distracting. I kinda wish, the\nminor, bond girl, that Monica Bellucci plays, had a bigger role in the\nplot. After all, Daniel Craig indeed love, working with her, the most.\nShe might be 50, but she's still gorgeous. Christoph Waltz as the\nvillain, Franz Oberhauser AKA Ernst Stavro Blofeld did a great job at\nbeing the charming host/criminal psychopath. I also didn't mind, Dave\nBatista's minor role as the henchmen. However, I kinda, wish, he had\nmore lines. There was a lot of grief over Sam Smith's new Bond song:\n\"Writing on the Wall, but it sounded grand and a fitting Bond song over\nthe credits. It's not amazing, but sure it's better than a lot of other\nrecent efforts like Madonna. I just didn't like the weird octopus porn\nopening, but I did dig, the D\u00eda de los Muertos opening with Thomas\nNewman's score. Cinematographer Hoyte Van Hoytema did ensures that\nMexico City are never less than ravishing. Don't care, if they got\ntaxation benefits, because of that, but I didn't, how the movie travels\nfrom one exotic location to another. It was too much! Too hard to keep,\ntrack of it. Overall: While, it fails to pack the emotional punch.\nSpectre is 007 out of 10. It's still worth seeing.\n"
            },

                "reviewAuthor": "JohnWelles",
                "reviewDate": "16 November 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Spectacular, Occasionally Flawed",
                "reviewTotalVote": "35",
                "reviewUseful": "19",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\n\"Spectre\" (2015), the twenty-fourth James Bond film, and directed by\nthe Oscar-winner Sam Mendes, is a remarkably lithe affair. Mendes opens\nthe film with an incredible, five-minute opening shot following Bond as\nhe makes his way through the Day of the Dead celebrations in Mexico\nCity. It's a stunning visual coup, unprecedented for the series or in\nany other similar action film of recent years, and announces that\nMendes, after making \"Skyfall\" (2012), is still interested in\ninnovating within what has become a venerable British institution."

Agent\n007 has gone rogue and is in Mexico City in the midst of the 'day of\nthe dead' festivities as he keenly follows M's last order. In the\nvibrant city center, he pursues the masked assassin in a lengthy single\nshot that leads him to a hotel rooftop from where he executes his\nmission. A building blows up as a result and soon the action leads to a\nthrilling helicopter sequence that disperses the crowd of thousands\nwhile the agent engages in a physical combat inside the barrel rolling\nchopper. 'Spectre' is what some fans of this franchise have been\nwaiting for since 'Casino Royale', which still remains Daniel Craig's\nbest take on the secret agent. While Spectre might be campy and\nincredulous in parts akin to Bond of prior generations, it still\nretains some of the darkness and grimness of Sam Mendes' 'Skyfall' and\nwith a lot more entertainment. This is a formulaic Bond film that\nmaintains an efficient dose of gadgets, car chases, stunts, females,\ntailored suits and gorgeous locales. Bond is back in action."

While there is little believable\nchemistry between Craig and new Bond gal Seydoux there is the\nlittle-used but always welcome sultry Bellucci to spice things up.\nDirector Sam Mendes returns to the franchise pulling out all the stops\nincluding a one-take non-cut opening salvo pre-credit trek thru Mexico\nCity's Day of the Dead ceremony with Bond tracking an assassin that\ninvolves a crumbling hotel and one helluva vertigo inducing chopper\nsequence.                 "reviewTitle": "Avenging Always",
                "reviewTotalVote": "58",
                "reviewUseful": "33",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nThe second outing of Whedon's Avengers is bound to be compared to the\nfirst, but I cannot help but simply see this movie as a bridge between\nthe first and the third that is yet to come. Don't get me wrong, I\nloved this movie, but as is inevitable with ongoing series the middle\npart is a lot of continuation and no resolve. The opening dives\nstraight into the action without any prelude as to how the team have\nreassembled after the events of Iron Man 3, Cap 2 and Thor 2. The\naudience are left to assume that at some point between Iron Man 3 and\nthis movie Tony Stark decided to rebuild the Avengers after Shield went\ndown, thus donning his armour once more. With a few episodes of Angents\nof Shield still to air perhaps we will get a more thorough explanation\nbut for now one can only conclude that Stark was the driving force of\nthe idea and Cap the elected leader. The Maximoff twins are well\nexecuted away from the forbidden mutant element, the Avengers following\nCoulson's terminology of enhanced persons and dancing around the\npotential connection to the Inhumans that we may see in the future.\nWithout giving too much away I'll briefly touch on the romantic\nentanglements portrayed, the main twist meaning that many a\nBarton/Romanov shipper are to be disappointed. I however found the\ndevelopment of Barton's character to be endearing and by the end of the\nmovie was cheering on Hawkeye more than any other Avenger, now\ndesperate for a solo outing for the character (TV series anyone?). As\nfor Romanov, her romantic interest seems a bit forced and probably has\nmore to do with the chemistry between the actors than the characters.\nThere is a spark there no doubt but from a character standpoint it\nmakes little sense and seems to just serve to pull at our heartstrings\nlater on when the inevitable happens. It's a pleasure to see Paul\nBettany on screen at long last, his JARVIS becoming a fully formed\nVision and by films end becoming a New Avenger in his own right. The\nmyriad of cameos are enjoyable and thankfully purposeful as the end of\nthe movie sees the New Avengers forming out of this 'B-Team', hinting\nat the potential for Phase 4 of Marvel's plan as the current cast's\ncontracts start to run out. In conclusion, this movie is a wonderful\ncontinued romp through the Marvel Cinematic Universe and leaves you\ndesperate for the next instalment and doesn't drop the ball, which as\nthe ninth movie in the series is an achievement in itself. Let the good\ntimes keep rolling!\n"

                "reviews": "\nDon't expect me to write something as easy and liquid as this movie is.\nIt is popcorn cinema at its best. The story? A bunch of co(s)mic based\nsuper heroes and super villains choose to fight about...something. a\nbucket of possibilities come into my mind, the world, justice, a city,\na nation, whatever. Take what you like. The holy grail of shallow\ncinema. We are\nobliged into value based thinking. Everything is of a certain value.\nMixed with strong moral based and ethic principles, so we don't freak\nout. Our way of living is a modern tale, our ego is of value. And\ntales, as they were used through all times in history, do emphasize on\na certain aspect. They offer a different view on real life\ncircumstances, we cant easily describe else. And this is what The\nAvengers does. They are the perfect image of our principles, of our\nlives, how we are supposed to be in order to succeed in our lives, in\nbusiness, in enterprises, in companies, in public places, at the\ngrocery, at home, in our families, even on the toilet. Serve and\nprotect. Love your next like your beloved brother. And you know this\nisn't easy, to keep the toilet clean with a brush after using it. Unseen because of the conservative\nand stodgy chair we took place in. And this movie is a tribute to this\ninjustice.                 "reviewTotalVote": "52",
                "reviewUseful": "28",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nIf, and, where The Avengers failed to captivate audiences, The Avengers\nAge of Ultron succeed, and in may ways excelled. There are numerous\nways that this movie could be reviewed. Compared to the first one, or\nas an individual movie itself. Generally second movies have always\nfallen prey to the sequel syndrome, where the hopes and expectations of\nthe film are let down; this is not that sequel. The movie itself is so\ngripping of excitement that one does not need to provide any spoilers\nto divulge just how breathtaking it will leave you, or more so excited.\nEach and every scene offers something new. Where the first movie was\nmore about how the Avengers come to be, this movie shows the mentality\nand development of each character and why they are who they are\nrespectively. The one thing that genuinely makes this film stand apart\nis the technology. Again, without spoiling, there are so many parts\nthat make this a world that can be, but has yet to happen. Alien\ntechnology aside, which is a hard thing when talking about the\nAvengers, the human tech has been beefed up in a very realistic and\nfuturistic way. Each and every fight scene gets better and better\nthroughout the movie, and the characters themselves make the movie. So\nmany laughs, so many twist, many where the action was less than a\nsecond beforehand, and you are still asking how and why, but there is\nno time to think. That is not an issue though, it all gets explained.\nThe cause for a 9 rating instead of a perfect 10 is that there are some\ngaps. Questions of how he or she got there so fast, almost making it\nlook like they teleported, but that was not the case. Overall, Avengers\nAge of Ultron is thus far the best action movie of 2015, and with\nrespects to Marvel, the best franchise movie yet. What the future holds\nfor Marvel has yet to be revealed, but there are clues. When the next\nmovie is released, the battle to save the earth, to save mankind, will\nneed more heroes than the ones that have already captivated the\ntheatrical world.\n"

In the Fantastic Four flick, the 'destroyer\nof planets' looked remarkably similar to a huge dust vortex from the TV\nseries episode 'The Doomsday Machine' that was laying waste to entire\nworlds in it's path. In this film, the directive given Ultron by Tony\nStark involves a global peacekeeping initiative, but it's programming\nstrongly resembles a plan to do away with all imperfection. That's\nexactly what happened in the TV Star Trek episode \"The Changeling\", in\nwhich a hokey looking computer named NOMAD became determined to destroy\nanything that didn't meet squarely with it's self appointed definition\nof perfection. If Captain Kirk were involved in this story, he might\nhave steered the Avengers to a plan that involved using logic to\ndemonstrate that blowing stuff up was not a perfect solution."
            },

                "reviewAuthor": "zardoz-13",
                "reviewDate": "2 November 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Hex-Rated Rubbish!!!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "24",
                "reviewUseful": "14",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\n\"The Last Witch Hunter\" casts spells that are far from inspired and\nmediocre at best. \"Dungeons & Dragons\" aficionado Vin Diesel toplines\nthis ponderous, PG-13 rated pabulum as an 800-year old protagonist who\nstruggles with the help of the Catholic Church to preserve a precarious\npeace between witches and mankind. Not only does Diesel appear\nincredibly miscast as an immortal \"Highlander\" type medieval warrior\ncareening around contemporary New York City in a sports car, but also\nthis witchy washy yarn doesn't surpass superior witchcraft fantasies\nsuch as \"Snow White and The Huntsman\" (2012) and \"Hansel & Gretel:\nWitch Hunters\" (2013). The chief problem with this lavishly-produced,\nCGI-laden extravaganza is that it takes itself far too seriously. Apart\nfrom its dire shortage of humor, this dreary potboiler suffers from a\ndearth of quotable dialogue, banal adversaries, and second-rate\nsupporting characters. Gifted thespians like Oscar-winner Michael Caine\nand Elijah Wood shrivel in lackluster roles as our hero's sidekicks who\nare designated as 'Dolans.' \"Sahara\" director Breck Eisner and three\nscenarists, Cory Goodman of \"Priest\" along with Matt Sazama and Burk\nSharpless of \"Dracula Untold,\" have conjured up a synthetic storyline\nthat generates neither charisma nor spectacle. Actually, they appear to\nhave imitated the sensational Wesley Snipes' vampire saga \"Blade\" right\ndown to its rebirth of an ancient blood demon. Similarly, \"The Last\nWitch Hunter\" should have bristled with non-stop momentum, violently\noutlandish combat sequences, and a coherently contrived mythology.\nInstead, it degenerates into a dreary mumbo-jumbo melodrama. The most\nambitious CGI scene pits our hero against a clumsy beast known as 'the\nSentinel,' and he destroys behemoth with a sword as if he were a\nbullfighter straddling it. This unruly creature resembles a huge tiger\nthat appears as it if were assembled from wicker and features a jet\nengine afterburner for its gullet. Our hero's chief adversary is a\nhideous Witch Queen swarming with creepy crawlies who looks like she\nhas spent too many centuries in a mud bath. Moreover, she boasts none\nof the imaginative flamboyance of Charlize Theron's enchantress in\n\"Snow White and the Huntsman.\" "
            },

                "reviewAuthor": "zardoz-13",
                "reviewDate": "30 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Along For The Ride But Not As Good As The First \"Ride Along\"",
                "reviewTotalVote": "6",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nStand-up comic Kevin Hart still cracks me up. The 5-foot. 2-inch,\nbantamweight, motor-mouth, African-American comedian still reminds me\nof Chris Tucker standing in a hole two-feet deep. Hart's hyperactive\nverbosity, enormous impertinence, and infectious vitality make him\nriotous in movies. He could stand around, do nothing, and he would\nstill be hilarious. He stole the show in the first \"Ride Along\" crime\nthriller comedy with Ice Cube, and he is still a scene-stealer in \"Ride\nAlong\" director Tim Story's \"Ride Along 2\" with Ice still staring him\ndown with his glacial glare. Unfortunately, the second \"Ride Along\"\ndoesn't surpass the original. Hart has more than enough minutes to\nclown around in his usual routines, but \"R.I.P.D\" co-scribes Phil Hay\nand Matt Manfredi, who rewrote the original \"Ride Along,\" don't provide\nas many surprises. Remember the two dirty cops that surprised Cube at\nthe end of \"Ride Along?\" Nothing like that happens in this superficial\nsequel. Like the original, \"Ride Along 2\" dutifully recycles every\nclich\u00e9 from those 1980s era police procedurals, but producer Will\nPacker has anted up more Shekels and shifted the predictable,\nfollow-the-dots action to Miami, Florida. If you've seen cop movies\nlike \"Rush Hour,\" \"Fuzz,\" \"48 HRS,\" \"Training Day,\" and \"Paul Blart,\nMall Cop,\" you know what to expect at every turn. \"Ride Along 2\" sticks\nto the formula with slavish zeal, but the camaraderie between Kevin\nHart and Ice Cube as polar opposites overshadows the film's sophomoric\nshenanigans. Indeed, \"Ride Along 2\" resembles one of director Tim\nStory's favorite crime comedies \"Midnight Run\" where a bounty hunter\nsought to shield a mob accountant long enough to get him into witness\nprotection. Story changes the accountant into a computer hacker for\n\"Ride Along 2,\" and zany \"Hangover\" actor Ken Jeong plays the hacker\nwith unusual restraint.\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "7",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nThere's something about Ride Along 2 that makes it a very forgettable\ncomedy movie that I'm probably not going to remember. The story is a\nbuddy cop movie with Kevin Hart as the wild cop who wants to prove\nhimself and Ice Cube as the straight man. There's trouble brewing in\nMiami and it is their time to figure what's going on. I think have\nstart out with the humor, because I feel that there is something\nlacking in that department. It's a real shame because I feel that there\nare some good concepts behind them, but I'm not sure if it's the\nwriting, the directing, or the acting that comes off as unfunny and\nrather boring. I feel that Kevin Hart can be a really funny guy. I know\nthat he's trying but there is something about the movie that's not\nmaking me laugh outside of a few exception. I think the biggest thing\nthat I can think of is that the story just felt so standard and, in a\nweird way, it bleeds itself into the jokes and gags in the movie.\nThere's not anything about it stand itself out from other comedy movies\nthat I've seen in my life. Granted, there are some gags that did work\nbut there just seems more where the gags doesn't hit, and in some\ncases, goes into complete bizarre mode. I will give the movie this,\ncompared to other comedies that I've seen, there's hardly anything\nabout the humor that makes me want to leave the theater (there are some\nweird exceptional gags though), but the fact that it's just so\nforgettable is just sad to me. There's nothing really good about it,\nbut there's not anything really bad about it either. It's just a dull\ncomedy so I would say is that if your one of those people that could\neasily be laughed, then I feel you could get more out of this movie\nthan I can. But for me, this is a movie that I think I'll forget in the\nnear future.\n"

                "reviews": "\nFor the original Ride Along (2014), it was by no means a buddy cop\nmovie that broke any rules or boundaries. It was mostly a standard\naffair of the usual buddy cop genre clich\u00e9s that occasionally threw\nsomething new into the mix. One of the biggest differences for this\nfeature among other cop comedies was the pair of main leads. Putting\ntough guy Ice Cube and comic short stack Kevin Hart together wasn't a\nbad idea at all. Even with the number of problems the picture had, Cube\nand Hart were able to make the watch a tolerable experience. Of course\nbecause this was probably one of the big reasons as to why that movie\ndid well, Universal Studios green lit this sequel. And like other\nsequels that come after their originals, their lack of attention begins\nto show. There's nothing wrong with hiring the majority of the same\ncrew to film a sequel but they have to know how to develop the story\nand not just run on auto-pilot; rehashing everything from the first\nentry. The promised chav to gentleman\ntransformation never occurs - apparently being comfortable with who you\nare is what makes a gentleman - with the hero starting as a lout and\nending up as a lout in a bespoke suit. What really sinks the film\nthough is its lack of a moral compass. I could complain about the\ncrudity of having a Swedish princess offer anal sex to the hero but the\nreal culprit is the way the film mixes comic book sensibilities with\nhyper-realistic violence. People are tortured and cut in half without a\nqualm. If you want to see Colin\nFirth brutally and repeatedly stabbing a woman in the stomach then this\nis the film for you.\n"

                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nTowards the end of the movie, Henry Cavill's Napoleon Solo asks, \"How's\nTHAT for entertainment?\" (when teaching the movie's villain a lesson\nabout monologuing), and my answer regarding this movie would have to\necho Waverly's \"very good\", as this film manages to out-Bond the last\ntwo actual Bond films. While it might be the unpopular opinion, I in\nfact enjoyed Guy Ritchie's two Sherlock Holmes films and so decided to\ngive this a chance, knowing nothing about the original TV series this\nmovie was based on and going in with no preconceived notions. One thing\nthat sets it apart from other recent spy thrillers is it staying set in\nthe 60s time period and not being \"modernised\". From the opening \"spy\njazz\" music, it sets the tone for what will be a fun ride. Ritchie's\nunique directing style fits perfectly with this slick/stylish film and\nhe proves once again to have the right touch when it comes to blending\nhumor with serious moments (one example being in the most morbidly\namusing torture sequence I've seen since Bond's in Casino Royale).\nWhilst there are \"talky\" moments and occasions where the camera lingers\non a shot for a solid moment, which those with impatience may grow\nrestless during, there's also action (but not such that it's overkill)\nmixed with humour, some emotional beats and even the odd sexy moment.\nIt all combines extremely well."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "bob-the-movie-man",
                "reviewDate": "20 August 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Open Channel D for Disappointing",
                "reviewTotalVote": "87",
                "reviewUseful": "47",
                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nStylish, glamorous and cool is how I remember the \"The Man from \r\nU.N.C.L.E.\" when growing up in the 60's, with the incomparable Robert \r\nVaughn playing the titular \"Man\" (Napoleon Solo, famously named by Ian \r\nFleming no less) and with David McCallum having a rapidly increasing \r\npresence as his Russian colleague Illya Kuryakin. I must have spent \r\nmuch of my school playtimes crouched in a corner with a Parker pen \r\nwhispering \"Open Channel D\" into the top! Highly entertaining and \r\nmisogynistic, sidelining women as little more than elegant cloth-horses \r\nfor later (hinted-at) sexual fun, the new film adaptation differs in \r\nonly one respect\u0085 unfortunately, not the one you most would like it to. \r\n\r\nHenry Cavill (\"Superman\") plays Solo, forced into a spiky working \r\nrelationship with his cold-war rival Kuryakin (Arnie Hammer from \"The \r\nSocial Network\") when a famous nuclear scientist goes missing risking \r\nnuclear bombs falling into the hands of a rogue power (which midway \r\nthrough the film seems \u0096 rather oddly \u0096 to be equated to the Nazis). \r\nThe team recruit the help of the scientist's daughter Gaby (Alicia \r\nVikander) to track down her missing father. \r\n\r\nGuy Ritchie films are always a bit of a lottery: the \"Sherlock Holmes\" \r\nfilms had panache; the less said about \"Swept Away\" the better. \"The \r\nMan from U.N.C.L.E.\" lies somewhere in the middle, which I predicted \r\nfrom the trailer: whereas I have raved about the trailers for \"Inside \r\nOut\" and the new \"Star Wars\", I had the exact opposite reaction to the \r\ntrailer for \"Uncle\"\u0085. it was just so 'meh'. So this was a film I \r\nentered with low expectations, and those expectations were pretty well \r\nmet.\r\n\r\nThis is not to say that the film doesn't have its moments: some amusing \r\nbanter between the two male leads; an atmospheric cold-war Berlin set; \r\nsome high octane scenes that bear stylish comparison to Sergio Leone \r\nWesterns; and the delectable Alicia Vikander (\"Ex Machina\"). \r\n\r\nBut against these plusses it all seemed, at its heart, rather soulless. \r\nFor significant periods of the film I wasn't fully engaged and the film \r\ngrew tiresome, not helped by multiple finales that fizzled out with a \r\ndamp squib intro to the next in the franchise.\r\n\r\nIn terms of feminism, the film doesn't move the ball along very far. \r\nTrue that Vikander's character is an East German car mechanic who knows \r\nhow to wrestle a man to the ground, but once into 'the plot' she is \r\ngiven precious little to do other than dress prettily (something she \r\ndoes, with the help of costume designer Joanna Johnston, very nicely). \r\nOne of the primary villains \u0096 Victoria (Elizabeth Debicki from \"The \r\nGreat Gatsby\") \u0096 is also female, but again the role seems largely \r\ntoothless and revolves around her draped in 60's fashions and pouting a \r\nlot.\r\n\r\nOf the male stars, Cavill and Hammer (which sounds like a make of \r\ntoothpaste) lack any great charisma; Hugh Grant does a good Hugh Grant \r\nimpersonation; with the most fun being had by Sylvester Groth \r\n(\"Inglourious Basterds\") who is creepily entertaining as the ex-Naxi \r\ntorture doctor.\r\n\r\nWhilst eschewing the norm in most reboots of reworking the classic \r\ntheme, Daniel Pemberton's soundtrack is unusual and fits the retro- \r\nnature of the film well, although it can be a little too brash at \r\ntimes. Also retro in nature is the use of 60's style split screens but \r\nthis is much less successful, totally neutering the suspense in some of \r\nthe action sequences. This is most notable in the final Bond-style raid \r\non 'baddie HQ' which, combined with the deafening music track, clearly \r\ncost a lot of budget to stage but is just yawn-worthy dull in its \r\npresentation.\r\n\r\nWith a current 7.6 on IMDb I may be in the minority, but i.m.h.o. it's \r\nworth a Sunday-afternoon watch on DVD but not something to rush to the \r\ncinema to see.\r\n\n"
            },

                "reviewUseful": "7",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nThe Man from U.N.C.L.E. has been a big box office bomb, which it didn't\ndeserve to be. Guy Ritchie's flashy and pleasingly retro spy thriller\nis a fun ride but it lacks any kind of genuine punch. It's a very\ngeneric spy plot which is given lift by being set during the Cold War\nand involving the CIA's best agent (Henry Cavill) and the KGB's best\nagent (Armie Hammer) working together. Overall TMFU is a moderate\nsuccess. Guy Ritchie's direction is visually excellent and unlike the 2\nSherlock Holmes films (Which were good but not exactly Sherlock Holmes)\nhis style fits the movie perfectly. The acting is good all around, with\nArmie Hammer improving on his fairly generic performance in The Lone\nRanger although Henry Cavill occasionally comes across as a bit smug.\nDespite being set in a different time period the film manages not to\nfeel anachronistic and serves up plenty of sleek entertainment.\nUltimately this is basically just lots of style with little substance\nalthough the Cold War setting makes it more interesting."

I would like to\naddress those things with a review from the female side of things. A\nfemale side that loves the romance of love and the journey it takes.\nThis is as much a love story as it is a western. I think people are so\nused to the explosive, wham, bam, hit em' up action movies that when\nthose things are missing, they don't feel satisfied. We learn a lot\nabout Jane in the first few moments of the movie. She is tough, she is\nstrong and most importantly, she is loyal. She loves those that are in\nher care and she's willing to stand her ground in order to protect\nthem. This was her movie, which would explain McGregor's\nunderdevelopment. We know enough about him to know we don't like him\nand that we are rooting for Jane. I thought the flashbacks helped in\nbuilding the relationship that went on. The two were engaged before Edgerton had to go off to war,\nbut she took off west after not having heard from him in three years.\nShe ended up in New Mexico married to a former outlaw (Noah Emmerich)\nwho saved her from a white slaver (Ewan McGregor? Portman has to defend him,\nand she rounds up Edgerton, who settled in the area after he found out\nwhat happened to his former fianc\u00e9e, to help her protect them. The\nstory's simple, but Portman and Edgerton carry the film nicely. They\nhave a believable sense of history between them. It's not an\naction-packed film, but it delivers well when it gets to the climax.\nThere are some weaknesses in the details of the film, especially in the\nflashbacks, which often seem skeletal in their scripting (Joel Edgerton\nco-wrote the screenplay with two others). But to put this as simply as I can -though that doesn't\nmean this will be short-, this film was filled with 1,000 of the most\ncommon clich\u00e9s extracted from these great films and stories and crammed\nthem into one mashed-up, jumpy, unreserved, ridiculous, abnormal,\nspiteful, detestable, idiotic, moronic, absurd, ludicrous, senseless,\nmeaningless, pointless, terribly-written, unbelievably- unrealistic,\nsuper-super-super-hero-wannabe movie that very desperately AND\nobviously AND obnoxiously attempts to special-effect everything -and I\nmean everything- to simply gain some big bucks because, hey, it's\nMarvel, what could go wrong? It's sad to see how successful their\nattempts were; I fell for it... for me, it's all due to The Avengers\nbecause that was freaking amazing, even though it had a lot of\ncommonplace stuff. And boy, do I regret wasting my two hours on this\nextremely disappointing collage. Basically, it's a film made of\ncollages because everything just had to be colorful in outer space. No\nseriously. Of course everything is colorful there. It's not like the\ngalaxy is filled with 96% dark matter that is called DARK for a reason.\nSo yeah. Totally makes sense. And your skin also starts rotting in\nouter-space, too. Serious case of leprosy then? I liked Elektra more\nthan this. I'd rather have watched that five times. Kind of feel like\nthat says something. The only reasons I smiled or laughed was because\nthe directors and script writers were decent at making corny jokes,\npuns, and lines funny enough that giggling is impossible prevent unless\nyou are emotionless. They should have gone with comedy, rather than\naction-adventure, though, since I sincerely thought the rest of the\nmoments were just junk. Call me a spoil-sport if you must, but I was\nliterally whispering what would happen in the next minute to my friend\nbeside me. Usually I'm not very good at predicting what happens in\nfilms -unless they are seriously full of clich\u00e9s...which this film is-,\nbut I said them anyway. I was right 8 times. Out of 9. I counted.\nAnyway... though the beautiful graphics did rival that of Avatar, the\nplot of \"saving the people from the evil mastermind only this time it\ninvolves the whole galaxy instead of just one planet so it's not just\nEarth that's being targeted this time so ha we are different\" never got\nTHIS tiring. I was so close to sinking in my chair and dreaming up a\nnightmare because of how stupidly predictable this film was. Maybe that\nwas intentional and Marvel fans just wanted to see some new, more\nunique heroes this time, and also to see the visuals, and maybe to see\nChris Pratt and Zoe Saldana's pretty butts...but whatever. I had half\nthat mind prepared for a clich\u00e9-turned- awesome movie when I walked in\nthe theater. I came out with my whole mind filling up and overloading\nwith shame and displeasure."

I don't get motion sick. Mostly I\nfind the constant shaking just down right annoying. You get shots of\nground or wall or the back of someone's head, instead of an action\nscene that is comprehensible where the audience can see what is taking\nplace.                 "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nWhen I first watched The Maze Runner (2014), I thought it was an\nunderground sci-fi thriller like The Cube (1997). Turns out it was a\nnew age alternative blockbuster with teenagers fighting for survival in\na dystopian future regime (like the Hunger Games and the Divergent\nseries). Maze Runner: The Scorch Trials is the second entry of what it\nseems will be another teen dystopian trilogy. The first movie was a\nsci-fi/mystery/thriller combination, while this second one focuses\nmainly on action. I like good action films and this one had a lot of\nthat but like in most cases the original first film and idea are\nbetter. Nevertheless this second entry combines the element of urgency\nwith constant running action scenes and is a nice choice to accompany\nyour pop corn with. Direction and sound are nicely executed and the\nyoung actors' performances are solid. Dylan O' Brien will some day\nbecome a star (of course not as big as Jennifer Lawrence). So if you\nlike your sci-fi mixed with simplistic but intense action this one is\nrecommended."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "ethanthoren",
                "reviewDate": "16 August 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Ant-Man is Fantastic",
                "reviewTotalVote": "24",
                "reviewUseful": "12",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nAnt-Man is unlike any other Marvel movie. It is nowhere near as big as\nThe Avengers, or The Avengers: Age of Ultron, or Captain America: The\nWinter Soldier, or Iron Man, or Guardians of the Galaxy, or any of the\nother Marvel films. It it small, funny, and emotional. The effects are\njust as good as the other films in the MCU, but the script, characters,\nand story make this unique. The characters are funny, but deep. The\nscript is witty yet emotional. The story is on such a small scale:\nSure, he saves the world. But what if Scott Lang (the Ant-Man) failed?\nThen Hope Van Dyne would take over. And if she failed? Hank Pym could\nnot do it. He is too old now. In his prime, sure, but not now. If none\nof those three, the three main characters in the movie, could do it,\nthen the Avengers would do it. End of story. This is not a scenario\nnearly as big as the fate of Earth or the entire galaxy. It is a story\nof a man and his daughter. Hank and Hope, and Scott and Cassie. Men and\ntheir daughters. Sure, there is a villain, some hilarious side\ncharacters, laugh-out-loud moments and witty dialogue, but it is about\nfamily more than anything. That is what makes Ant-Man so great. It is\nnot just about a superhero, or a team of superheroes, but about the\nrelationship between a parent and their child. That alone makes the\nmovie worth seeing, not including the epic action scenes, hilarious\nmoments, great writing, fantastic acting, and more. If you miss\nAnt-Man, you are missing one of the best films in the MCU, and one of\nthe best films of the year.\n"

I've never\nseen the original movie, so I have no bias towards it. Based on the\nmovie's own merit's, the Point Break remake is laughably awful. In\nPoint Break, a rookie FBI agent tracks down a group of extreme athletes\nwho go around the world carrying out crimes in unusual and\nlife-threatening ways; they plan to do a series of near- impossible\nstunts called the Ozaki 8 in hopes of reaching spiritual enlightenment.\nAt least, that was the plot for about ten minutes before the movie\ndevolves into a series of party scenes and surprisingly dull extreme\nsports clips that could have been easily viewed on YouTube, all set to\nirritating club music. It takes a special director to make BASE jumping\nand cliff diving this boring. Ericson Core builds as little suspense as\npossible in his action set pieces and instead films admittedly\nwell-shot highlights reels for the action scenes. Any sort of suspense\nconjured up is because of the great cinematography because the\ncharacters are so flat and annoying that you almost wish they would get\nkilled off. Everyone in this movie acts stoned out of their mind. All\nthey do is spit faux- philosophical nonsense which gets tiring after\nthe first twenty minutes. It gets laughable towards the end of the\nmovie with lines like \"Ideas are strong. But not as strong as a whaling\nship,\" and no amount of context will make that line any less\nridiculous. The unbearable dialog, muddled plot and dull characters\nmakes this Point Break remake utterly pointless. If you're not a fan of\nremakes, this will make you reach your breaking point.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Troy_Campbell",
                "reviewDate": "4 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Impressive action sequences let down by almost everything else.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "3",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nA Gen Z update to Kathryn Bigelow's 1991 cult classic, this remake is\nessentially an episode of Fast and Furious in which the vehicular\nexploits have been replaced with an assortment of extreme sports\nsequences. Constructed with an alarming amount of real footage and\nphysical stunt work, the numerous action set pieces are rather\nimpressive; a high octane wing-suit gliding scene and the\ntension-building rock climbing finale topping the list. Yet the impact\nof these daredevil stunts is wasted on a film that fails on almost\nevery other level. Stemming from Kurt Wimmer's truly awful screenplay,\nevery second not spent traversing a mountainside, soaring through the\nair or surfing a mammoth wave is cringe worthy and/or yawn inducing.\nWimmer's dialogue attempts to be philosophical and Zen-like, but with\nclich\u00e9d stinkers like \"the only law is gravity\" and \"everyone dies,\nit's just a matter of how\", it's nothing short of unintentionally\nhilarious. Replacing the eternally cool Patrick Swayze was always going\nto be tough, however Edgar Ramirez does a solid job as charismatic\neco-warrior Bohdi. The same can't be said for\nlow-budget-Chris-Hemsworth hunk Luke Bracey though, who is so wooden as\nJohnny Utah he makes Keanu Reeves look like Daniel Day Lewis. This\nmodern update boasts a handful of genuinely fantastic action sequences,\nyet they're not enough to warrant a recommendation in what is otherwise\na limp and incoherent thriller.\n"
            },

                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nThe film presents a number of impressive extreme sport actions set\npieces with glorious parachutes or rock-climbing gear that will\ncertainly excite the audiences but sadly the plot with poor pacing has\nturned this remake slightly pointless. It manages to break the action\npoint based on the Ozaki Eight's fictional sets of highly dangerous\nattempts of worshiping the nature but fail in achieving several other\npoints, most obviously when it lacks of engagement in between the\ncharacters while the existence of political subtext and the crime\nconcept seems to be meaningless. Performance from the casts are overall\nfine but the decision to focus on the extreme adventures have totally\nneglected the potential of some supporting characters and the emotional\ndevelopment that cause the romance and friendship seems to be\nsuperficial. Visual effects are environmental breathtaking and\nstunning, the scores by Junkie XL are strong and inspiring yet all of\nthese are insufficient to provide additional thrills to make the film\nsuperior than the original cult in 1991.\n"

But the basis\nis only that the characters have the same names. Point Break is an\naction film best suited for testosterone-charged teen boys. The plot\ngoes nowhere. The acting is weak (at best). The film's attempt to\nattach a philosophy to the extreme sports is juvenile at best. Point\nBreak is too loud. There were too many tattoos. The FBI does not really\nrun independent international operations. On the positive side (yes\nthere is one--barely), the 3D photography is spectacular. The extreme\nsports scenes are impressive. The real star of the\nfilm is the 3D photography. It is a shame that a better plot could not\nhave been found.
