            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Argemaluco",
                "reviewDate": "15 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Point  Break  (2015)",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "0",
                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nPoint Break (1991) is one of my favorite films, but I will try to be as\nobjective as possible in the review of its remake. To start with, I\ncouldn't swallow the hollow \"new age\" philosophy of the villains (it\nmight be more appropriate to call them \"anti-heroes\"), full of vague\nwordiness which sounds deep despite not meaning anything (\"You only see\nthe limits... I only see the truth\"). And their actions don't make much\nsense. Sometimes, they want to \"return something to Earth\"\n(translation: stealing the rich and giving the poor), while in other\noccasions, they seem simple eco-terrorists or simple thieves seeking a\nbooty to finance their adventures. Example: the only bank robbery in\nthe film occurs at a bank on the top of a mountain. Why? Because they\ncan escape on motorbikes and funiculars, with the snowy tops as a\nsetting of the action. It's easy to notice that Point Break (2015)\nisn't interested in telling a congruent and interesting story, unlike\nthe 1991 film (useless information: the original Point Break was the\nfirst movie I bought on LaserDisc). This remake only wanted to include\nas many samples of extreme sports as possible, without caring about the\nsacrifice of logic in the story. Having said that... the mentioned\nsports exhibitions are visually attractive (director Ericson Core\ndefinitely took advantage of his long experience as a cinematographer)\nand very well done. Needless to say, there's abundant digital\nmanipulation, but the feats feel \"real\" and extremely dangerous. The\nspecial effects work is perfect, allowing the creation of good action\nsequences. Useless information number two: Point Break (2015) has the\nlongest end credits I have seen in a long time. It's almost 15 minutes\nof \"sports consultants\", local services in the numerous countries where\nthe film was shot and at least a dozen of special effects studios,\nincluding lola VFX, Image Engine and VPP; but the effort was worthy. I\nwish I could flatter the screenplay as much; and the least I say about\nthe forced romantic sub-plot, the better. Meanwhile, the accomplices of\nthe band are so poorly defined that, when one of them dies, we don't\neven know which one it was. Was it the one with beard and tattoos, or\nthe one with beard and tattoos, or the one with beard, tattoos and\nlenses? And that narrative sterility is what marks Point Break (2015)\nfrom the beginning to the end. As I said before, the \"extreme\" scenes\nare well done, but everything else is as interesting as the previously\nmentioned end credits. If we only take the action scenes, Point Break\n(2015) might work as a long extreme sports commercial; pity that, in\nits whole shape, we also have an uninteresting screenplay and bad\nperformances.\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Clark Kent",
                "reviewDate": "4 January 2011",
                "reviewTitle": "A Challenge to Those People Who Thought This Movie 'Made Sense'",
                "reviewTotalVote": "92",
                "reviewUseful": "62",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nSurrealism can appear to be ineffably bizarre, or inquisitively\ntitillating, depending purely on the viewer's intellect. Though the\nrealm of surrealism is highly nebulous and complex, but even a slight\nattempt at improvisation can sometimes go awry and open a Pandora's\nBox, making the task highly improbable and nigh impossible. This facet\nof reality may pose a handicap to the most gifted of the directors, but\nnot to the genius of Christopher Nolan, who not only dabbles with the\nconcept of surrealism, but also ingeniously blends it with the elements\nof Science Fiction in his latest wonder named Inception. Nolan created\na niche for himself a decade back by unleashing a monster of a movie\ncalled Memento. He further substantiated his status by conjuring movies\nlike Insomnia, The Prestige, Batman Begins, and The Dark Knight. His\nunremitting desire for innovation and uncanny craving to foray into the\nunexplored realms of imagination deservedly earned him an auteur tag,\nwhich gave him the carte blanche that a story-teller like Nolan\ndesperately needs. It's highly apparent that Nolan takes every possible\nadvantage of this liberty while filming Inception. Inception is not\nonly dreamlike, but is a dream in itself and is superior to any other\nthing conceived on the silver screen. With its entwined layers, the\nmovie for the most part serves as an unfathomable riddle and makes\nmultiple viewing extremely essential. It incredibly does extremely well\non both the humanistic as well as the technical fronts. In fact, the\nbalance between human emotions and the elements of Science Fiction is\nso adequate that it's impossible to separate them. "
            },

This is where we first met\nthem all: Luke, Han Solo, Princess Leia, Obi-Wan Kenobi (old 'Ben'),\nChewbacca, the 2 robots C3PO & R2D2 and, of course, Darth Vader. They\nwere instant pop culture icons; you got the sense you'd seen them\nbefore somewhere, but were sure this wasn't possible. But they'd been\nthere before in our minds. We'd read about them constantly in science\nfiction novels and short stories - tales of outer space civilizations,\nof spaceships zooming through asteroid belts, of exotic-looking aliens\nhanging around space ports. We'd dream about them at night and try to\nimagine ourselves in their midst; up until then, we could only imagine\nsuch things - there were no projected images to realize such dreams.\n\"Forbidden Planet\" from 1956 came close, and then there were the \"Star\nTrek\" and \"Lost in Space\" TV series, both hampered by dime store\nbudgets and cheesy sets. We ate 'em up since there was nothing else.\nThen Lucas made it real."

The great visual and imaginative mind of George Lucas made\nit possible for other filmmakers to get from realistic movies to a\ngeneration of movies containing imagination and fantasy. "

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "MovieGuy",
                "reviewDate": "25 May 2005",
                "reviewTitle": "The opening installment of the greatest trilogy in cinematic history...",
                "reviewTotalVote": "7",
                "reviewUseful": "7",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nTruly a landmark film. When it came out, there had never been anything\nlike it before, and it truly caused quite a stir. I would contend that\nit is not as good as its sequel, Empire Strikes Back; but it is still a\ngreat movie. There is humor, action, and some heartfelt moments. It is\nalso our introduction to some great characters that people will never\nforget - Chewbacca, Han Solo, Princess Leia, Luke Skywalker, Obi Wan\nKenobi...and of course everyone's favorite villain, Darth Vader. Alec\nGuinness really is outstanding in this movie. His role as Luke's first\nmentor is understated and believable...his somewhat tired attitude in\nretrospect seems very understandable after watching the prequels -\nafter all he's been through, it is very believable when he tells Luke,\n\"I'm getting to old for this sort of thing.\" The visual effects are not\nonly groundbreaking, but they still hold up very well even in this\nCGI-effects laden era. I would contend that ILM's use of modeling and\nlighting in the old films actually lends a more believable look to the\naction scenes than the prequels' use of video-game style battles and\nsensory overload. There is great chemistry between the actor's - and\nwhile Luke is a bit annoying, the back and forth of Han and Chewbacca,\nand C-3PO and R2-D2, as well as Leia's chemistry with Han and Luke,\nmake this movie extremely entertaining on an emotional level - it also\nmakes you care about the characters. Let us compare the lightsaber duel\nof this movie with that from Phantom Menace. Although the acrobatics\nand sheer fury of the duel just are not there in A New Hope, we\nactually feel something when Obi-Wan allows Vader to strike him down.\nConversely, when Qui-Gon Jinn is slain, there is not the same (if any)\nfeeling after it is done. Well, I'm rambling now. But this movie has it\nall. Space battles, lightsaber duels (a la Samurai flicks), chase\nsequences, thinly veiled references to the Western genre in the Canteen\non Tatooine. A Truly great adventure that, as it ended, was really just\nbeginning.\n"
            },
            {
                "reviewAuthor": "tom-darwin",
                "reviewDate": "22 April 2006",
                "reviewTitle": "Excellent Excess",
                "reviewTotalVote": "15",
                "reviewUseful": "11",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nThe very first note of John Williams's horn-blaring score as the film's\ntitle in thousand-foot-high block letters flashes on screen is the very\nmoment when American film-making turned inexorably to big-budget,\ngrand-themed audiovisual extravaganza strung together with simple\nstories, snappy catchphrases & cutesy jokes. But if George Lucas\ndecided to follow Henry Ford rather than John Ford, he built a Shelby\nCobra & left Pinto-making to his many, many imitators. Ironically, he\nhimself remade one of the finest works of film master Akira Kurosawa,\nthe Western-themed \"Hidden Fortress,\" with one scene (the fight in the\nbar) lifted from \"Yojimbo.\" As a result, \"Star Wars\" has a bit of the\njittery discomfort of characters trying to fit into a story that wasn't\nquite made for them, like people with past life experiences that\nintrude into the present. Kurosawa's hero is split not into two but\nTHREE heroes in \"Star Wars\" (four if you include the princess, who has\na more prominent role in \"Star Wars\"). Hamill's Luke is often\novershadowed by Kenobi (Guinness, whose skill had aged better than any\nfine wine) and Solo (Ford, in the role that deservedly made him a\nstar), though he often holds his own as the clueless but determined\nfarmboy-turned-hero. In less than five minutes, \"Star Wars\" sets the\nstandard of outer-space audiovisual special effects that the industry\nwas bound to follow from then on, forever sweeping away the earnest,\ntoylike realism that Gerry Anderson was then giving us in \"Space: 1999\"\nin favor of exhausting but beautiful orgies of fast, violent, sweeping\nmovement culminating in explosions of bright color & blaring sound. No\nwonder there's never any sex. \"Star Wars\" is science fiction only\nbecause it's set in outer space, by which standard \"Dirty Harry\" is a\ndetective story & \"Last Tango in Paris\" a romance. Little attempt is\nmade to explain the technological wonders depicted (we never find out\nwhy light sabers never have to be recharged or get even a cursory\nexplanation of the Death Star). What little science there is can't be\ncounted on, as when Solo extols the drag-racing abilities of the\nMillennium Falcon in parsecs, which are units of distance, not elapsed\ntime. But Lucas never means to educate, only to entertain. Solo is a\nsmuggler, not a science officer, while the others are not doctors or\nengineers but warriors, royalty or villains. Lucas's hammerhanded\nexcess works because it never lets up & never goes for the cheap &\neasy. Though the heroes are unconvincing, \"Star Wars\" creates an array\nof badguys in the Galactic Empire that remain unsurpassed in cinema,\nheaded by Darth Vader, who makes the Wicked Witch of the West look like\nMrs. Piggle-Wiggle. In another irony, the most memorable scene in \"Star\nWars\" is the motionless roundtable conference chaired by Tarkin\n(Cushing, in the greatest role of his long career) which yielded\nphrases long & gleefully repeated by a delighted America (\"This station\nis now the ultimate power in the universe!\" \"This bickering is\npointless!\" \"I find your lack of faith disturbing\"). Perhaps, with the\nspace program petering out & the hard realities of nuclear energy\ncoming home to us, our fascination with scientific exploration was\nwearing thin. In the 1960s it enabled the cast of \"Star Trek\" to bring\nthe writings of sci-fi geniuses to life with cardboard & aluminum foil.\nNever again. What better honor, or infamy if you like, could there be\nto \"Star Wars\" than that the \"Star Trek\" movies of the 1980s followed\nthe simple themes, cuteness & spectacular effects of \"Star Wars,\"\nturning their backs on their own heritage of awed exploration? Perhaps\nthat first detractors and then supporters of Ronald Reagan's Strategic\nDefense Initiative nicknamed it \"Star Wars\" so convincingly that the\noriginal name was quickly forgotten. The film might be a bit dated with\nits holistic, New Age mysticism (feel the force FLOWING through you!)\nwhich likely owes more to Jack Kerouac than Musashi Miyamoto & which\nbecame more difficult to depict with a straight face the farther the\nsequels & prequels went. Nevertheless, it was a worthy successor to the\nCode of the West, especially in contrasting Darth Vader with Luke &\nKenobi. \"Star Wars\" can't really be judged by the standards of other\nfilms, partly because it reset the standards & partly because it\nbecame, most unusually, the fourth in a series of six! But there's no\ndoubt that it's a heroic sensory extravaganza that will leave the\nviewer at once exhausted & exhilarated--and will do it over & over\nagain, without offending, condescending or making one think too hard.\nIf you just want to escape to a galaxy far, far away, jettison all\nskepticism, lower your shields & prepare to make the jump to\nhyperspace.\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "I B",
                "reviewDate": "5 October 2010",
                "reviewTitle": "George Lucas' mythological popcorn film is a two-hour roller-coaster ride that has passed into movie legend.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "5",
                "reviewUseful": "5",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nGeorge Lucas spent four years developing and working on the galactic\nfantasy Star Wars. This was after he directed the dystopian\nscience-fiction film THX 1138 (1971) and the rites-of-passage American\nGraffiti (1973). Star Wars was inspired by the Flash Gordon cartoon\nstrip. It cost $8 million to make in Britain with three little-known\nAmericans in the leading roles, supported by British actors. The story\nis a simple adventure yarn, and Lucas draws on samurai films, Westerns\nand every kind of myth, ancient and modern. The dogfights are based on\na close study of World War II films. Star Wars was an immediate\nsuccess. It became one of the great phenomena of cinematic history. It\nspawned two sequels, three prequels and endless imitators, creating a\ndemand for spectacular blockbusters that has not yet ended. Industrial\nLight and Magic, the special effects unit that served the film, became\na multi-billion dollar organization. Lucas himself also became and has\nremained one of Hollywood's most powerful figures. The film certainly\nstruck a nerve in an America recovering from the humiliations of the\nVietnam war. Ronald Reagan, elected president three years after Star\nWars was made, spoke of the Soviet Union as 'the Evil Empire' and gave\nhis proposed space-defense system the title Star Wars. The original\nStar Wars trilogy contributed to the worldwide renewal of the filmgoing\nhabit, but in creating an appetite for child-like blockbusters that\ndepend on special effects rather than on character and subtle\nnarrative, the film unfortunately played a key role in what was to be\ncalled 'the dumbing down' of America and popular culture.\n"
            },

                "reviews": "\nI don't think there's any denying that Star Wars changed cinema history\nand deservedly so. At the time of its release, science-fiction was\nconsidered a dead genre with the only major films from Hollywood's\nrecent cannon being the work from Stanley Kubrick and cheesy, yet still\nfun flicks like Logan's Run. Yet, no other futuristic movie wowed more\nthan George Lucas's space opera. From that infamous opening scroll,\nfeaturing that amazing heart-pumping score, to the end credits, people\nwere gripped and hoping their heroes that had grown to know those two\nprevious hours could come out alive. While, George Lucas did give his\nJedi knights more adventures, I don't think any of those sequels and\ncertainly not the prequels have managed to come close to the original\nStar Wars that practically defined the baby boom generation. Watching\nthe film again recently, I am still impressed by the awesome power of\nthe movie and the fact that even after thirty years after its release,\nit gets me more excited than the latest Hollywood blockbuster.             {
                "reviewAuthor": "Michael Kelley",
                "reviewDate": "16 December 2013",
                "reviewTitle": "The Beginning of a Wonderful Trilogy of Films",
                "reviewTotalVote": "6",
                "reviewUseful": "5",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nWell, the only way to begin this review is to mention when I saw \"Star\nWars\" for the very first time. I was merely a baby, from what I recall\nmy parents telling me before their divorce. I wasn't even born when\nthis first feature film hit theatres. I'm nineteen now, but I must\nadmit that \"Star Wars\" was one of the many things that decorated my\nchildhood. I always adored it, and always looked-up to Luke Skywalker.\nIt was the type of view I can only assume all boys had; we all wanted\nto be a Luke Skywalker. We wanted to be the cool hero with a\nlightsaber. In this review, I will do my very best not to give you a\nbiased review. However, forgive me, for I have always been a \"Star\nWars\" fanatic. This was my first re-viewing in quite a while, so at\nleast I'm reviewing the film with a clear set of eyes."
            },
            {
                "reviewAuthor": "David Conrad",
                "reviewDate": "28 November 2013",
                "reviewTitle": "Star Wars felt big even before it was",
                "reviewTotalVote": "6",
                "reviewUseful": "5",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nIn the early 1990s when I was about 8 or 10, I had a VHS copy of \"Star\nWars: A New Hope\" that I watched repeatedly. It was a recording from a\ntelevision broadcast and was missing the first few minutes, so the\nopening shots were of C-3PO and R2-D2 walking over the dunes of\nTatooine. That planet is not, of course, named in the movie; strange as\nit is to think, there must have been a brief span of time when I knew\nthe movie pretty well but didn't know the colossal amount of trivial\ninformation that I permanently internalized during my teen years. For a\nwhile I had no idea there were sequels. But the details and backstories\nthat books and games and movies and TV shows have filled in over the\ndecades were in a way already present, at least implicitly, at the\noutset. It is well-known that George Lucas was inspired by old sci-\nfi/adventure serials, and that he tried to give this \"episode\" of Star\nWars the feel of belonging to a far grander saga whose beginning and\nend were far off. It was an audacious, brilliant move, and it worked on\nmy younger self exactly as intended. I was able to conjure images of\nLuke's heroic father, supposedly killed in the off-handedly mentioned\nClone Wars, and I was able to get a sense of what those conflicts were\nlike from the way that Alec Guinness looked and sounded when he talked\nabout the past. I could feel the long history of Obi-Wan and Vader's\nrelationship in the way they appraised each other during their\nshowdown. I could imagine, vaguely, the previous ups and downs of the\nrebel alliance and the off-screen machinations of Imperial Senate. That\nthese things were planted in my imagination made the movie feel big and\nepic, though it is probably the \"smallest\" installment in the Star Wars\nfranchise in terms of the size and number of sets, the number of\ncharacters with speaking roles, and other metrics. The series has not\nalways benefited from trying to depict on-screen the people and events\nthat were at first only evocative allusions. I sometimes wish I could\nforget everything I've learned from the ever-expanding Star Wars\nuniverse (and that, believe me, is a lot) in order to feel again the\nway I felt when all I had to go on was \"A New Hope,\" and it was more\nthan enough.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "Matt McLeary",
                "reviewDate": "12 April 2013",
                "reviewTitle": "If The Matrix, Moon, Independence Day, & Terminator made a love baby, this is what would be born.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "223",
                "reviewUseful": "130",
                "reviewUserRating": "3",
                "reviews": "\nGranted Oblivion takes inspiration from countless sci-fi classics, \r\ngranted that it lets a larger than life star consume it, granted it \r\nlets visual flair and elegance triumph mind bending probabilities, but \r\nthere is no denying the fact that it is one hell of an entertainer, and \r\nprobably THE sci-fi vehicle that Tom Cruise wanted all his life, \r\nSpielberg aside.\r\n\r\nA long preamble sets the dystopian background- it is the year 2077, and \r\nthe earth has been devastated in a war with aliens who destroyed the \r\nmoon, thus destabilizing the earth, causing earthquakes and tsunamis. \r\nNuclear annihilation followed, and as the earth became inhabitable, the \r\nsurviving humans moved to Titan, a moon of Saturn, while alien \r\nscavengers still roam the irradiated habitat. They still mine the \r\nearth's resources through giant reactors which are in turn protected by \r\ndrones, which are maintained by a pair of technicians residing in a \r\nstylish, minimalistic floating facility in the clouds, with wiped out \r\nmemories- Jack Harper (Tom Cruise) and Victoria Olsen (Andrea \r\nRiseborough), who are counting their days to their return to Saturn. Is \r\nthis the truth? Who are Jack and Victoria? Why does Jack still have \r\nhaunting memories of his past? Are there humans left on earth? Who won \r\nthe war?\r\n\r\n\"Is it possible to miss a place you've never been? To mourn a time you \r\nnever lived?\"\r\n\r\nOblivion doffs it cap to gems such as 2001: A Space Odyssey, I am \r\nlegend, Independence Day, @Moon, Star Wars, Total Recall, The Matrix \r\nand of course, WALL\u0095E to create a striking, visually resplendent \r\nfeature. Fresh from his Oscar for Life of Pi (film), Claudio Miranda \r\ncreates an another unforgettable integration of cinematography and \r\nvisual effects- an arresting landscape of desolate beauty pockmarked \r\nwith craters and fallen signposts of humanity as we know it, and lush, \r\nunspoiled green valleys. The action is sporadic and effective, not \r\noverpowering, and there is a love triangle that is sensitively dealt \r\nwith. Cruise here is playing one of his more affable characters, a \r\ndreamer trying to find out the meaning of his existence, taking direct \r\ninspiration from Sam Rockwell's stellar turn in the Moon. As \r\nrevelations unravel, he gets into superstar mode with minimal \r\nfussiness- cool vehicles, check. Weapons, check. Beautiful babes, \r\ncheck. Mission to save the world, check. Risenborough is superb as the \r\nicy cool, rule following partner, Olga Kurylenko gives grace to an \r\nessentially damsel in distress role, while Morgan Freeman is his usual \r\nsolid self in a cameo. \r\n\r\nDirector Joseph Kosinski gives a graphic novel flair to the \r\nproceedings, and like his previous effort Tron Legacy, gives a solid \r\nbonus in the form of a surging musical score by French band M83.To sum \r\nup, Oblivion may not be terribly original, but it is stylish, well \r\nwritten and got performances to boot- especially Cruise who is in red \r\nhot form. It may not be a puzzle to solve, but in the immortal words of \r\nRoxette- it's got the look to warrant a trip to the theaters! Go on and \r\nenjoy a summer spectacle.\n"

He can be seen from miles\naway. b) Why the concept of helmets is lost so completely? The main\ncharacter does not wear a helmet even when he rides a dirt bike (a\nwhite dirt bike). c) A huge, long WHITE-colored rifle will get in one's\nway most of the time. Did anyone notice any spare mags? d) What is the\nstory with the rifle-mounted flash light? Don't they have any NVGs or\nlight-amplifying sights? No camouflage + bright flashlights? Do they\nwant to be detected by anyone from miles away? e) The main character is\nconstantly exposed, because he ridiculously works alone. There is no\none to spot for the guy who does repairs and therefore cannot watch his\n6 o'clock. He acts as though he is alone on the entire planet, although\nhe is so obviously not alone. f) No body armor?! Why? The main\ncharacter is evidently challenged by various opposing forces, but he\nhas no ballistic protection (see the part b about the absence of\nhelmets). g) If, or rather, when that flimsy flying machine brakes, the\nmain character will be stuck in the middle of radioactive no where. I\nwould not take this job. e) Since the flying machine is not a\nhelicopter, then why does it have a large tail with a fan? A tail rotor\nis only used on single-rotor helicopters. The flyer in the movie is a\nheavily thrust-vectoring machine with two engines. So, the tail with a\nfan becomes utterly useless, obviously. Also, whatever kind of concepts\nthey employ are WAY OVERUSED!                 "reviewTotalVote": "240",
                "reviewUseful": "163",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nLet's start this by stating how much of a die hard fan I am of\n'Jurassic Park', I love that film, always have, always will. 'The Lost\nWorld' is a worthy followup, but at the same time lost the panache the\nfirst one had, as for the third entry, I'll overlook it because it just\ngot too silly for my liking... anyway, on to 'Jurassic World'. First of\nall, the positives outweigh the negatives by far, so to start I shall\nbegin with the flaws. 'Jurassic World' near enough scraps the use of\nanimatronics that made the original films so realistic in comparison\nand instead overuses CGI, but that aside the visual effects are\nstunning. And the story, well, it's a little too far-fetched to say the\nleast, but not to the point where it's completely ridiculous, just\nenough for you to have a laugh but still enjoy it nonetheless.\nTrevorrow's direction, Pratt's acting and Giacchino's score are all\nsuperb, and these combined make the film a worthy watch. The film\nperfectly blends drama, emotion and action, and when I say action, I\nmean full-on awe- inspiring action. The closing battle is just rife\nwith intensity, to the extent that I was literally sitting on the edge\nof my seat in the cinema, it was perfectly choreographed (if maybe a\ntad predictable) but my heart was racing, I hadn't felt that excited\nwith a film's conclusion for a long time. All-in-all, it's a well-\nexecuted and beautifully-crafted sequel, but will never outdo the\noriginal, the best 'Jurassic Park', but a second spot grab? I think so.\n"

                "reviewUseful": "367",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nFine but predictable return to form for the Jurassic Park series finds\nJohn Hammond's dream for a \"Jurassic Park\" becoming a reality. However,\nin a way to have more people come back to the island, scientist's\ncreate a hybrid dinosaur as a new attraction. But, like every Jurassic\nPark film in the series, things don't go off as planed and all hell\nbreaks loose in it's aftermath. Unlike the last 3 movies however, this\nfilm is made up of mostly new characters to hold off the Dinosaurs with\nthe exception of a small side character from the Original Jurassic Park\nfilm played by BD Wong, who to be quite honest is only there to somehow\nfulfill continuity from The first film to the new one. It would have\nmade more sense to bring in some of the original leads to bridge the\nwhole series together but that seems to be asking too much. The new\ncharacters starting with lead Chris Pratt are fine but underwritten and\nclich\u00e9. Pratt's character and performance is really the only bright\nspot of the new cast of characters but he lacks the cool sarcastic wit\nand intelligence of Jeff Goldblum's Ian Malcolm and The everyman appeal\nof Sam Neill's Dr Alan Grant. Pratt however brings his own warm, comic\nsensibility that does make him endearing in his own right but unlike\nGoldblum and Neill who brought dramatic tension to the films, Pratt\ngets overshadowed by the dinosaurs once the bloody carnage begins.\nBryce Dallas Howard is decent but unremarkable in the uptight corporate\nwoman with no life role and Vincent D'Onofrio is OK as the resident\nhead of security of the park. Of course, there are two kids who plays\nthe nephews of Howard's character who are put in the middle of the\naction one it begins, leading to a predictable climax that while is\nfull of thrills, could have been seen a mile a away."

                "reviewTitle": "If you're looking to sit on the edge of your seat for two hours, welcome!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "127",
                "reviewUseful": "89",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nFirst of all I think people need to understand that film is a lot like\nmusic, you can't listen to a new Justin Bieber song and complain\nbecause it's not a Mozart masterpiece. And you definitely can't watch\nJurassic World expecting a mind-boggling, emotional Inception type\nfilm. I would put Jurassic World in the same category as most Michael\nBay films, the story line won't make you think, the characters won't go\nthrough any psychological changes but you will be thoroughly\nentertained by the special effects. I think it's fairly obvious\nthroughout the original trilogy and this film that we are the visitors\nto the attractions, Steven Spielberg gave the parallel Earth a new\nunimaginable attraction, one which surprised the audience so much, it's\nrated as one of the best films ever. Period. Fast forward twenty two\nyears past the films of Interstellar, Lord of the Rings and Harry\nPotter, we as a human race have seen a lot of original, unique things,\na plain old dinosaur film will not bring us the same thrills as it did\nin 1993. Therefore we are once again, the visitors to the attraction.\nWe will never feel the same buzz as first seeing that T-Rex crashing\nthe gates over, or the same chill down the neck when first hearing that\nRaptor shriek. However, we can still be entertained. Which is what\nhappens throughout the film. The characters are fairly bland, there are\nonly a couple likable ones, but they all seem to grow on you near the\nend, the bloodbath that is left by the new Dino is quite emotional and\ngives you a side to pick fairly easily, the surprises throughout the\nfilm keep it exciting and the special effects, well we are in 2015 and\nthey did have a lot of money to spend so lets just say they are\nincredible as expected. If you're looking to be on the edge of your\nseat for two hours and trust the film to not bore you, then you have\nnothing to worry about, the line graph representing excitement just\nclimbs up and up, if you're expecting another Shawshank Redemption,\nwell please don't slate the film when it doesn't satisfy your needs. I\nthink that films should have two ratings, one for overall, and another\nfor it's main sub-category, for example as an overall film I'd give it\na 7.5-8, it's sub-category of excitement I'd give a solid 10, a\ncomparison to the first Transformers which I'd give an 8 for excitement\nand a 5 overall. Therefore I really do recommend this film for anyone\nwho like me, enjoys special effects, good excitement and two hours to\njust sit on the edge of my seat and thoroughly enjoy my time. I can\nonly say I can't wait for the second one and I'm sure you will too\nafter you watch it.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "alexander-rumpf",
                "reviewDate": "12 June 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "A nod to the original and even more",
                "reviewTotalVote": "90",
                "reviewUseful": "57",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nAs a young boy, dinosaurs were the greatest thing on earth (well, the\ngreatest thing that once WAS on earth) for me. I knew most of their\nnames (like Gray in JW) and had my plastic dinosaurs fighting\nthemselves, evil, and sometimes also good. You can imagine my\nexcitement when I first saw Jurassic Park and I was truly blown away by\nthe idea. I still somehow wish that I could actually experience the\nevents in the movie, although I understand the critic that the author\nof the novel, Michael Crichton, wanted to express. Much of that critic\nis lost in the third sequel to the original movie, 22 years after its\noriginal release, at least it's hidden very deep in the plot. The\nscientists have created a new super- species, filled the missing pieces\nof DNA up with genes of amphibians that all have certain\nsurvival-powers, and it all goes terribly wrong, much because the\ndinosaurs are being underestimated as they always were. So is it a\nreboot of the first movie? At least a bit. They are referring to the\nfirst movie all the time, examples: A control guy wearing an Jurassic\nPark shirt proudly says he got an original shirt (shown in part 1\nseveral times) for $150 from eBay, they run through degenerated\noriginal buildings and one time the kids even drive an original van\nthat they repaired competently. New park-owner Masrani says that John\nHammond told him on his death bed to \"spare no expense\", which was one\nof the funniest scenes in the movie, yet Masrani doesn't want to\ncommercialize the park too much. That's where the movie starts being\nperfectly self-ironic: one control guy (the one with the classic shirt)\njokingly suggests, in order to please the investors, to name newly bred\nspecies after companies, \"so how about Pepsi-Saurus\"? The movie indeed\nis full of product placements, I counted at least 9 brands and logos\nthat are shown or mentioned during the film. So what is the purpose of\nthe movie? Mainly, I guess, it's meant as a nostalgic, yet up-to-date\nexperience/excuse for all those fans who were bitterly disappointed by\nthe Parts II&III. It's exciting, contains a little love story, it's got\nwit, social criticism and excellently animated dinosaurs. It shows that\n22 years after Jurassic Park, movie heroes are still being chauvinist\nand women are still stronger and braver as they are pictured in most\n(other) movies. And, finally, it fulfills every fans biggest desire:\nman and dinosaur, at last fighting side by side. That's probably why\nI'd give it an even better rating than the original Jurassic Park\nmovie, although of course classic scenes like the shaking water glass\nwill probably never be outperformed. R\u00e9sum\u00e9: Director Colin Trevorrow\nmanages to create an enthralling and visually stunning homage to the\noriginal which at some points brilliantly steps out of the shadow of\nits role model and finally puts the conciliatory end to the dinosaur\nuniverse that we, the fans, truly deserved.\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "caitlinmathews",
                "reviewDate": "12 June 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "The Park Should Have Stayed Closed...",
                "reviewTotalVote": "350",
                "reviewUseful": "180",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nJurassic World was truly one of the worst films I have seen in my 25\nyears of life, and millions of minutes of film has crossed my eyes. The\nacting was wooden, the characters at best forgettable and at worst\nannoying, and the plot line had the unique blend of idiocy and\nimplausibility now usually reserved for the Land Before Time franchise.\n(WARNING: HERE BE SPOILERS) We begin with the story of Zack and Gray,\nwho go to the now famous theme park Jurassic World to visit their aunt.\nIt's never actually explained how their American middle-class parents\nactually afford two first class plane tickets to Costa Rica just so\ntheir kids can see their aunt. It's just assumed it's on the absentee\naunt's bill. Gray is your typical kid, bouncing like a madman from one\nridiculous event to the next. JW is a gigantic theme park consuming\nmost of Isla Nublar, where JP was created. This multi-billion dollar\nfacility boasts interactive holograms of each dinosaur species in the\npark, a research laboratory that made this aspiring zoologist weak at\nthe knees, and a thriving population of both herbivores and carnivores.\nThere is a petting zoo where kids can ride baby trikes and apatasauri,\na SeaWorld-like arena where a Mosasaur is spoon-fed great white sharks,\nand giant hamster balls where visitors can wheel themselves through a\ngigantic field of herbivores. Zack gleefully informs us that JW has\nover a dozen herbivore species and roughly 10 carnivore species.\nUnfortunately, we never get to see most of these species during the\npair's jog through the park. We witness at most 5 herbivores\n(Triceratops, Apatasaurus, Gallimimus, Parasaurolophus, and\nAnklyosaurus are the ones I can recall) and 5 carnivore species\nincluding the Indominus Rex (Pteranodons, Dimorphodons, I.D.,\nTyrannosaurus, and Velociraptor). It is never explained HOW InGen, the\ninfamous soulless corporation that refuses to learn from its mistakes,\ngot running again after the incident in San Francisco. It's stated that\nthe original JP event happened twenty years ago, which meant that\nJurassic World must have started construction only a year or two after\nJP: III. It is not mentioned how they got control of the island (we saw\nhow well a dying company's last ditch effort worked in The Lost World),\nor how they even got funding. Their shareholders, realistically, dumped\nthem like so much cow dung after JP\u0085and if they hadn't then, they would\nhave after The Lost World. The company should have been going through a\nterrific melt-down of assets during JP: III, and be nonexistent by\nJurassic World. Even with the Marani corporation bailing them out, the\npublic should have avoided any new dinosaur theme park like the plague.\nSo we're left in wonderment as to how this highly advanced, popular\ntheme park Jurassic World was even constructed. In roughly 16 years,\nthe public has completely forgotten the dangerous islands and now\ntreats the viewing of a Stegosaurus akin to seeing an elephant in a\nzoo. Given the public's long memory of even a single animal incident\nsuch as Steve Irwin's death, this is extremely difficult to believe and\nwe are given no explanation as to how this came about. It simply is.\nEnter a wooden Chris Pratt, an ex-Marine who inexplicably has a rather\nadvanced view on animal behavior. He treats 4 raptors, named Delta,\nCharlie, Echo, and Blue, like large dogs. He tells them to \"stop it\",\nand wags his finger at their snapping and snarling like we would at a\ndisobedient horse. These raptors are quite possibly the worst design in\nJP history. The CGI looks cartoonish instead of terrifying, and the\nraptors don't move or act the same way we've become accustomed to. They\ndon't bob their heads like birds, they don't raise their tails high up\nin the air due to bird hips, they're more muscular rather than slender\nand fast with beefy heads and necks, and they parrot sound effects that\nare obviously cannibalized from the other films. While this last is\ntrue of the other Jurassic Park films, it stuck out like a sore thumb\nin Jurassic World. Noises we've come to associate with attacks, such as\nthe \"scream\", are thrown in casually as background noise. The overall\neffect cheapened animals that have been the cornerstone to Jurassic\nPark, and made me utterly unafraid of them. Of course an \"incident\" is\nthrown in with a feeding employee yanked into the cage after Chris\nPratt's character finishes training them, but it feels wooden and\nover-the-top. Cheap jokes are thrown in at the hapless new employee's\nexpense after our hero saves him from his 4 pet raptors. Enter easily\nthe most boring human villain on the planet, a fat InGen employee named\nHoskins who is the typical Guns, God, and America patriot. He wants to\ntrain the raptors to attack America's enemies and sell them to the US\nArmy\u0085nevermind that said army was called in at least 2 of the 3 JP\nfilms to extract desperate survivors of Isla Nublar and might have a\nlong memory concerning half-mad jungle occupants. Chris Pratt is\nagainst this, and emphasizes that the raptors are wild animals and\ncannot be trusted as such\u0085before he affectionately pets a snarling\nraptor with its head encased in a metal restraining device. It would\nhave been a lovely time to use the gorgeous animatronics JP is known\nfor\u0085but instead we get Pratt awkwardly rubbing his hands over a wiggy\nCGI insert. In fact, there is only one obvious animatronic dinosaur in\nthis film\u0085.a dying Apatosaurus gently petted and sobbed over as it dies\nof wound inflicted by the escaped Indominus Rex (which looks like a\ncrocodile mated with a baryonyx and was the epitome of disappointing).\nThe hapless Apatosaurus ends up looking like a pool toy, with none of\nthe exquisite detail previously handled by the gods of animatronics\u0085the\nJim Henson company. This movie was worse than the infamously-bad\nJurassic Park 3. It was worse than Gigli. Save your money.\n"
            },

But with the \r\nhelp of his trusted butler/ally Alfred (played superbly by Michael \r\nCane) grounds him, gives him moral support, and keeps him in check. Along with the original \r\ncast comes some fresh faces such as Aaron Eckhart, Maggie Gyllenhaal \r\nand more. Bale and Gyllenhall have MUCH better chemistry this time around \r\nmore so than Holmes. Even better, the fight sequences are vastly \r\nimproved and feature more brutal and bone crushing combat than \"Begins\" \r\nin addition to new technology at Batman's disposal.\r\n\r\nAlso worth mentioning is screenwriter Jonathan Nolan, who gives the \r\nfilm an added frosting to an already delicious cake.\r\n\r\nSimply put, The Dark Knight is totally more bad ass than \"Begins.\" The \r\naction is great, and the plot is more deeper and engrossing. I applaud \r\nChristopher Nolan, Christian Bale, and especially Heath Ledger (who \r\nsadly passed away earlier this year) and all those aboard for believing \r\nin Mr. Nolan's talents for this second installment. Although some may \r\nfeel a bit of melancholy over Ledger's death, but as a final note I \r\nwill say this sincerely from my heart: Remember Heath Ledger and honor \r\nhim in your minds and hearts not only for his performances, but as a \r\nhuman being and father to his daughter Matilda \r\nLedger. May we issue him best wishes for his family and friends and his \r\ndaughter for years to come. Remember . . . Honor him not only for this \r\nrole and past roles, but as an incredible individual and talented \r\nactor.\r\n\r\nRest in peace. Heath Ledger: 4/4/1979-1/22/2008.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "springsunnywinter",
                "reviewDate": "14 July 2008",
                "reviewTitle": "Batman at his best and beyond",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1507",
                "reviewUseful": "938",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nI thought Batman Begins was a very well conceived and put together \r\nmovie. We finally get Batman as a fully rendered character. We gain new \r\ninsight into his motivations and the variables he must contend with in \r\nhis role as protector of Gotham. We get to see Gary Oldman as an \r\nhonest-to-goodness good guy. And we get to see Liam Neeson conducting \r\nperhaps his strangest facial hair experiment yet.\r\n\r\nBut after seeing The Dark Knight, Batman Begins will forevermore be \r\nviewed (by me at least) as a handy little prologue to a FRICKIN' \r\nMASTERPIECE of a superhero film.\r\n\r\nTo say it's the deepest mainstream comic adaptation ever produced would \r\nbe akin to calling the Nolan/Ledger Joker 'a bit eccentric'.\r\n\r\nWhile watching it, I found myself thinking it was very long, which is \r\nusually a sign that it's TOO long, and therefore boring. But that's not \r\nactually the case here. The script is bulging with ideas, philosophical \r\nmusings, THEMES, which Christopher Nolan is not content to gloss over \r\nin favour of cool set-pieces (as many comic adaptations are), but wants \r\nto explore, wants to allow the characters to explore, at a logical \r\npace. So, what I guess I'm saying is, considering what it sets out to \r\ndo, the movie is long ENOUGH, while still constantly holding the \r\nviewer's interest.\r\n\r\nAnd that's not to say the thematic exploration comes at the EXPENSE of \r\nbig action, either. On the contrary, there is some truly awesome stuff \r\ngoing on here. The chase with the truck, for example, is fantastic, and \r\nthere's some great hand-to-hand stuff too.\r\n\r\nBut what engages us most is the characters, and, while the script is \r\nbrilliant (the dialogue is sharp, and quite funny for the first \r\ntwo-thirds, before the drama really kicks in), this mainly comes down \r\nto the cast.\r\n\r\nChristian Bale. Taller than Michael Keaton was. More menacing than Val \r\nKilmer was. Less like Adam West than George Clooney was. Solid and \r\ncommitted as always. He gives the character LIFE, and actually makes us \r\nfeel for him. The word 'tortured' keeps coming to mind...and I suppose \r\nit's pretty appropriate.\r\n\r\nHeath Ledger. Y'know, I'd heard talk of an Oscar nomination, and \r\nthought it sounded a bit dubious. A Batman villain? Winning an Oscar? \r\nIs that what it's come to? Then I thought, is it because he didn't get \r\none for Brokeback? Or more dubious still...is it because he...died? \r\nBut...well...how can I put it...? \r\n\r\nIt seems a bit blasphemous to compare Jack Nicholson to Cesar Romero, \r\nbut after seeing Heath at work...Jack (who once seemed so awesome) just \r\nlooks...well...lame.\r\n\r\nIf you've seen it, you hopefully get what I mean. If you haven't...you \r\nneed to. You will discover the true definition of commitment.\r\n\r\nMaggie Gyllenhaal. I didn't have any problem with Katie in the first \r\none (at the time), but I doubt she could have pulled off the more \r\nemotional stuff Rachel goes through here. Seeing recasting was \r\nnecessary (does Tom have a problem with his wife being involved with \r\nBatman? Too many bad memories perhaps? Why am I even talking about such \r\ngarbage here?) they could have done a butt-load worse than Maggie. She \r\nrocks.\r\n\r\nAs does Aaron Eckhart. But I'm not giving ANYTHING away. Suffice it to \r\nsay my mind was blown...AGAIN. Makes Tommy Lee Jones look like...you \r\nget the idea.\r\n\r\nMichael Caine. Still one of my favourite actors. Alfred is the shiz.\r\n\r\nMorgan Freeman. Morgan Freeman. AOK.\r\n\r\nGary Oldman. As in BB, no mania. No psychosis. No nervous tics. \r\nAbsolute subtlety. Manages to hold his own alongside Christian, Heath \r\nand Aaron without resorting to parlour tricks. Sign of spectacular \r\ntalent. Go Gaz.\r\n\r\nEric Roberts! William Fichtner! Michael Jai White! Tiny Lister!\r\n\r\nThe whole thing is just a big bag of thoughtful, well-executed \r\nentertainment. It's equal parts cerebral and visceral. Ideas and \r\naction.\r\n\r\nI've liked every Batman movie so far (okay, besides Batman & Robin), \r\nbut this one makes them all look pretty bloody ordinary.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "apfelkornmetijs",
                "reviewDate": "25 July 2008",
                "reviewTitle": "TDK, a solid superhero movie, nothing more",
                "reviewTotalVote": "148",
                "reviewUseful": "78",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nTime for a corrective. As I write this review, The Dark Knight is,\naccording to IMDb voters, the Best. Film. Ever. At the risk of\nincurring a hail of brickbats, I must demur. Yes, Heath Ledger delivers\nan excellent performance, as does Gary Oldman as Lieutenant--er,\nCOMMISSIONER Gordon--and it's always a pleasure to watch Michael Caine\nand Aaron Eckhart. But The Dark Knight is an overlong, over plotted,\nlogically flawed, and philosophically confused film that cannot (and\nshould not) be mistaken for great art. Compared to most comic book\nmovies, it's not bad. Compared to La Regle du Jeu, it ain't so hot. The\nfilm's first half is actually quite good, and seems to come to a timely\nconclusion somewhere around the eighty minute mark. Unfortunately, this\nbeing a summer blockbuster, there's another 70 plus minutes to go, and\nthe film's second half is a distinct letdown. Instead of ending on a\nneat and tidy note, The Dark Knight spirals off into a muddled mess of\nbizarre plotting (how DID that prisoner get the bomb sewn into him?),\nillogic (how does Harvey escape the hospital explosion--and why is he\napparently impervious to pain?) and confusing action (too many\nass-kickings in too little time). I don't expect 100% logical\nconsistency from my genre product, but there are so many flaws and\nelisions of simple common sense in Christopher Nolan's screenplay that\nutter frustration sets in around the two-hour mark. By the end of the\nfilm, we're expected to believe that, for some reason, the residents of\nGotham now need to revile Batman rather than reward him for his good\nwork, setting up a police pursuit into the sunset that presumably will\nend with our hero receiving a ticket for speeding on the Batcycle. So\nlet's tell it like it is: in terms of 2008 comic book flicks, The Dark\nKnight is inferior to both Hellboy II (which at least is charming and\namusing) and Hancock (which raises far more interesting questions about\nthe nature of the super hero).\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "49",

                "reviews": "\n'In the Heart of the Sea' is not 'Moby Dick'. Instead, it is based on\nNathaniel Philbrick's non-fiction book of the same name, which was\nitself drawn from real events surrounding the Nantucket whaling ship\nEssex that was allegedly sunk by a giant sperm whale in the western\nPacific on November 20, 1820. Out of the 21 men who made it out alive,\nonly eight eventually survived the ordeal in the open sea, and there\nare accounts from two \u0096 one, the ship's first mate Owen Chase; and two,\na 14-year-old cabin boy named Thomas Nickerson who waited 55 years to\nwrite his side of the story which ended up lost until 1980."

                "reviewTitle": "A Very Angry Whale.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "31",
                "reviewUseful": "24",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\n'Moby Dick' is the well known adventure of a whaling ship and its crew,\nrelentlessly hunting the legendary white whale that had been a\nproverbial thorn in any whaling expedition. But before Herman Melville\nwrote his most famous piece of work in 1850, the American author had\nreceived the inspiration for his classic from a real life whaling\nexpedition thirty years prior. The true story of the Essex and its crew\nreverberated around the world and had the potential to destroy the\nwhale oil industry at a time when the precious commodity was the\n'electricity' of the day. Its use in everyday life was common and was\nthe main source of heat and lighting in the nineteenth century. The\nhunt for the rich oil saw large numbers of whaling ships spending years\nat a time out at sea so the bright lights of towns and cities could\nburn before the introduction of electricity. How far we have all come,\neven from the recent past."

                "reviewTitle": "'This is not the whale you are looking for.......'",
                "reviewTotalVote": "75",
                "reviewUseful": "45",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nIn the Heart of the Sea is an Action/Adventure/Biopic based on the real\ndisaster that inspired Herman Melville's 'Moby-Dick'. The film follows\nthe voyage of the 'Essex', a whaling ship that was bought down in 1820\nby a Sperm Whale in the South Pacific, and is a tale of Adventure,\nDrama, Survival and Boredom. Obviously the main reason I and most other\npeople wanted to go and see this movie was to see this massive whale go\ntoe to toe with the Essex and its crew. Actual confrontations with the\nwhale in this film were few and far between but when they happen, man\ndo they make an impact. This whale was ginormous, he was grand and it\nwas such a spectacle seeing this huge beautiful whale on screen. The\nway they emphasise his size through juxtaposing him with the boats\ngives his presence much more weight. Confrontations with the whale were\nintense and serious edge-of-seat stuff. The CGI effects of this whale\nwere beautiful and incredibly detailed. This would have taken up a huge\nchunk of the budget as making this whale look as realistic as possible\nwas crucial to the enjoyment of the film. Some of the CGI in the wide\nshots were well done, but there were still quite a few scenes and wide\nshots throughout the film, especially in Nantucket that really just\ndidn't look right and did take me out of the film."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Matt Greene",
                "reviewDate": "18 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Technically Proficient But Super Flat",
                "reviewTotalVote": "16",
                "reviewUseful": "10",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nHeart of the Sea is a mass-produced still-life painting: technically\nproficient but as flat as the canvas it's on. Technically, it's fine;\nthe cinematography is interesting, the actors hit their marks, the\nsound is on point. But other than a few moments of nice humor and mild\nsea-faring thrills, the film lacks any spark. It's like director Howard\nand co. weren't that interested in creating an emotional, cerebral or\nexciting film, but more focused on simply getting the job done. The\nstory of 19th century whaler Owen Chase (played by an oddly-accented\nHemsworth), the influence for the literary classic Moby Dick, is a\nstory worth knowing. However, the giant scale and obsession inherent in\nthis tale is never fully conveyed, as Howard opts for computers and\ngreen screens, in lieu of the actual sea, to tell his story. So instead\nof a propulsive thriller or even a thoughtful psychological study, we\nget a generic and forgettable action/adventure, couched in boring\ncharacters. And much like the crew of the Essex itself, we are stranded\nin a seemingly endless sea of lackluster storytelling It also features\nsome of the worst cinematic framing ever. Instead of just filming Moby\nDick itself or just the story of real-life Owen Chase, they opt for a\nmessy mash-up, constantly cutting away from the Essex's voyage to a\nrecounting of the story to Melville; like bad narration taken to the\nnth degree. Even some marginally compelling moments showing the\nsurvival instincts of desperate people can't save this sinking ship.\nWatch Jaws, All is Lost, or Master and Commander if you want to take a\nworthwhile trip to the heart of the sea.\n"
            },

            },
            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Argemaluco",
                "reviewDate": "31 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "In  the  Heart  of  the  Sea",
                "reviewTotalVote": "2",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nForemost, let me calm the purists of author Herman Melville's down: In\nthe Heart of the Sea doesn't have much to do with the legendary novel\nMoby Dick. Yes, the film is obliquely related to the origin of that\nbook, but it's based on ANOTHER book (In the Heart of the Sea: The\nTragedy of the Whaleship Essex, written by Nathaniel Philbrick), and it\ndidn't end up being one of those \"literary re-imaginations\" such as\nAlice in Wonderland (2010) or Victor Frankenstein. Having said that, I\ndidn't find it a very good movie either, even though it managed to keep\nme moderately entertained and didn't make me feel like I wasted two\nhours watching tough individuals killing whales. I might be\nexaggerating. We only see the crew of Essex killing one whale, and\nscreenwriter Charles Leavitt finds an adequate balance between the\nheroic tone of such \"feat\" and the remorse of such an aberration to the\nnatural world (needless to say, I'm absolutely against that activity,\nbut I'm trying to be impartial). Besides, the point of the film isn't\nthe hunt of shark, but the revenge from a huge whale, perfectly created\nby the special effects magicians and \"portrayed\" by cinematographer\nAnthony Dod Mantle, whose impressive views of the ocean possess such a\nconsistency and naturalness that I didn't care about which ones were\nreal and which ones simulated. In the Heart of the Sea looks pretty\nwell, and much more credible than the obvious artificiality of Life of\nPi (my apologies to the fans of that movie, but I couldn't swallow the\nCGI excess saturating its scenes). Anyway, going back to the pertinent\nfilm, In the Heart of the Sea accommodates the supposed \"true events\"\ninto an innocuous and predictable formula, starting by the main\ncharacter, the classic tough but sensitive cinematographic hero divided\nbetween his family and the demands of the difficult job he has to take\nin order to support it. Then, we have the corporative villains,\n(figuratively) hungry of whale oil, for which they finance the Essex\ntrip with a rookie captain, when it's obvious that our hero would be\nbetter qualified to guide the dangerous sailing. And well, in order not\nto reveal more than I should, that's how In the Heart of the Sea\nproceeds, with few surprises, null suspense and only a bit of drama\nduring the second half, when the story takes a different (but not\nunexpected) road, leaving the adventure behind in order to examine the\nevents the narrator Nickerson kept in secret for various decades, until\nthe curiosity and interest from Melville inspired him to confess the\ntruth. It might seem I'm revealing too much, but it's not like that. In\nfact, there isn't too much to reveal, because, as I previously said,\nthe screenplay is firmly based on Hollywood stereotypes, and Ron\nHoward's direction doesn't do anything to distinguish the film in any\nway, leaving the previously mentioned technical achievements aside. The\nperformances are competent, despite the characters being hollowly\nwritten. Chris Hemsworth is credible as the hero, and the rest of the\ncast also makes a decent work, highlighting Benjamin Walker, Tom\nHolland and the great Brendan Gleeson. In conclusion, I wasn't left\nvery satisfied by In the Heart of the Sea. As a sea adventure, I found\nit moderately entertaining but forgettable; as a \"man against nature\"\ntale, it barely wakes the slightest tension. In the first category, I\ndefinitely prefer Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World; in\nthe second one, I liked Deep Rising or the original 20,000 Leagues\nUnder the Sea much more. And in the context of Howard's filmography, I\nprefer Backdraft and Apollo 13. In the Heart of the Sea aspired to the\nexcitement of the former and the human drama of the latter, but\nunfortunately, it fell short.\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "ironhorse_iv",
                "reviewDate": "16 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "This whale of tale movie was alright, but somewhat disappointing. It could had been better.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "2",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nWhale! Whale! Whale! You would think the inspiration for author Herman\nMelville's 1851's novel, \"Moby Dick\" would be amazing to watch. Sadly,\nthis 2015 biographical survivor film directed by Ron Howard, wasn't a\nbig splash with the audiences when it came out. For me, personally,\nthis movie was entertaining to a point; but the story about an angry\nsperm whale sinking a whaling boat really needed to be told, better. I\nreally didn't like the framing device in which, this movie is told.\nYes, it was mostly alright, that the movie had the whale return,\nmultiplies times after the sinking to show, how malevolently, the\ncreature can be, but this isn't 1975's Jaws or even 1956's Moby Dick,\nwhich were fictional movie based on true stories. This movie was market\nas the true-encounter that inspired the myth of Moby Dick. You can't do\nreally do that, if you're trying to be truthful, because it totally\nundermined and contradict the whole marketing message. For a film\nsaying, it's the realistic account of that story, it has to portray the\nwhale, more to what it truly is. A normal creature that only attack\nonce, not a symbol of God's wrath. This film wasn't even close to being\naccuracy to the real-life events of the sinking of the whaling ship,\nEssex in 1820 at all. I'm surprise, by this, because it's based on\nNathaniel Philbrick's 2000 non-fiction book of the same name; which in\nmy opinion was very accuracy. Several aspects of the story was indeed\nmissing like the burning of Charles Island & the resupply in Galapagos\nin this film. Plus, it didn't help that the film depart significantly,\njust to add a sub-plot where author Herman Melville (Ben Whishaw) goes\nto an old mariner, Thomas Nickerson (Brendan Gleeson) to get his\naccount of the events, despite being aware of the story from whaler,\nOwen Chase (Chris Hemsworth). It really seem, pretty odd that Thomas\nNickerson would know, a lot about Owen's relationship with his wife,\nand his boss, George Pollard (Benjamin Walker). It was a bit jarring.\nThe film's biggest problem over the entire film was the pacing. It\nreally took forever to get anywhere. A lot of the scenes were really\ndrawn out & quite boring. Whenever, something interesting comes into\nplay, the film sucks it out, by eventually abandoning the conflict;\nsuch was the case between how the ship should be run between Chase and\nPollard, or the will to survive between Chase and the White Whale. It\nfeels very anti-climax. The dialogue was also a problem. It was mostly\ndull exposition, with little to no character development in it. I\nreally, didn't get to relate to anybody in the crew, as much, as I\nshould had. I really thought, there would be great scenes that would\ngive us, some insight on who these men, are. The movie could also work\nbetter, with some inherent adventurous epic maritime life music to it,\neven if it's a tragic showing. It would really lighten this movie, up.\nIt would make the film, a lot more fun to watch. I love the use of CGI\nin this film. The whole whale attack really did stand out for the brief\nscenes, they had. It look really real to me. I also like how the film\ngoes all bloody and grizzly in its portrayal of how ugly, the whaling\nbusiness can be. Scenes like a young man being forced into a dead\nwhale's head was pretty interesting in its gory worst. However, it was\na bit weird for the PG-13 film to show that, but unable to show any\nscene of cannibalism during the surviving in the ocean parts. It seem\nlike it was a bit sugar-coated. What the hell, movie! However, I do\nlike the make-up work in this film. Some of the actors really did,\nlooking like they were starving to death. That 500-600 calories diet\nthat the actors had to do, was crazy. Acting wise, the film was also\npretty good. Chris Hemsworth was the obvious standout, he was able to\nshow off his acting talents quite a few times throughout the film, but\nstill it was nothing truly astounding. It's sad that he can't show,\nmuch of his acting chops, beside those Marvel films. The supporting\ncast was also mostly pretty strong, with Benjamin Walker, Tom Holland,\nand Cillian Murphy standing out. Overall: How does In the Heart of the\nSea compare to other tales of sea-voyage catastrophes? It was somewhat\nbelow average. While, braving storms, starvation, panic and despair,\nwill call into question the man's deepest beliefs, from the value of\ntheir lives to the morality of their trade, I never really got to\ninterested in the story to care if they live or not. While, this\nadaptation clearly had the big budget, it fails to connect emotionally\nwith me, like similar films like 2000's Perfect Storm or 2012's Life of\nPi. It's worth watching, but not much, replay value. See it, if you\nwant to.\n"

                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nAgreeable retelling , vividly played , in which a Captain called\nPollard (Benjamin Walker , though other actors that were considered\nincluded Benedict Cumberbatch, Tom Hiddleston, and Henry Cavill) and a\ntough first officer , Owen Chase (Chris Hemsworth) command a surly ship\nof whale hunters through sheer ruthlessness and ego . Fine rendition\nfreely based on Herman Neville novel : \u00a8Moby Dick\u00a8 , with enjoyable\ninterpretations from all-star-cast . Based on the true story of the\nship Essex , a whaling ship that was attacked and sunk by a sperm whale\nin the southern Pacific Ocean in 1820 . In this extremely loose\nadaptation of Melville's classic novel, George Pollard , Ahab-alike ,\nis revealed initially not as a bitter and revengeful madman . This\noceans saga features some survivors of a lost whaling ship and relates\nthe tale of a white whale as well as the captain Pollard's obsession\nwith desires for vendetta upon the greatest animal . It starts in New\nEngland , where an expert officer and harpooner signs aboard the\nwhaling ship along with rookie captain George Pollard . Both of whom\nmeet a motley crew formed by two-fisted sailors as Caleb Chappel (Paul\nAnderson) , Henry Coffin (Frank Dillane) , Richard Peterson (Osy\nIkhile) , Benjamin Lawrence (Joseph Mawle) , Ramsdell (Sam Keeley ) and\nMatthew Joy (Cillian Murphy) , among others . They are attacked by a\nhuge Cachalot that causes destruction and wreck havoc . Pollard ,\nsubsequently , consecrates his life to hunt it , full of hating and\nvengeance . He has a self-destructive obsession to hunt the white whale\n, carrying out obstinately his revenge and determination to seek avenge\non the beast that destroyed his crew and ship ."

                "reviewAuthor": "TheWanderingBohemian",
                "reviewDate": "2 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Holy Cow!! That is a Huge Whale.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nInspired by Herman Melville's Moby-Dick, In the Heart of the Sea, will\nmake you go, \"Holy Cow!!, that's a huge Whale\". The movie begins in\n1820, but I think its concerns are contemporary \u0096 the damage to whaling\nhabitats caused by hunting expeditions, humankind's dependence on oil,\nand nature's revenge at human intervention. The real battle is between\nthe men and a vengeful whale whose obsessive assaults on the ship\nprovide the film with its most spectacular and powerful moments. The\nspecial effects team kicks into gear once the Essex enters the water.\nThe battle between the whale and the humans has the unfortunate effect\nof creating empathy for the mammal, which appears rightfully outraged\nat the repeated attacks on members of its clan. After the damage has\nbeen done, the story floats just like the castaways, counting days to\nthe inevitable return home. The old-fashioned man-versus-nature yarn is\nthe best thing about In the Heart of the Sea. The cast performs\nefficiently, but they are dwarfed in every way possible by Moby Dick's\ninspiration. The movie has its several highs and some lows but looking\nat the grand picture it makes a pretty decent watch."

Ron Howard has yet again wowed us\nwith an epic tale combining action and adventure with the very sobering\nhuman element. Chris Hemsworth, who is both pleasing on the eye and\npleasant to the ear leads the cast of men into the watery unknown as\nthey work hard to help him keep his promise of return to his wife and\nunborn child. These were brave men going to sea on these ships but\nleaving them to climb into a small boat to take on the largest\ncreatures on earth seems foolhardy to say the least. The amazing\nspecial effects leave you wondering if any of the marine life we see\nare real or are they all CGI, but as wonderful as they look, this film\nin no way glamorises the whaling industry - in fact it highlights the\ndangers and hardships these men had to endure to provide the world with\noil the only way they knew how at the time.                 "reviewAuthor": "jackson-magaw",
                "reviewDate": "12 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Visually striking adventure with decent storytelling",
                "reviewTotalVote": "3",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nFrom the brilliant director Ron Howard (Apollo 13, A Beautiful Mind)\ncomes a fantastic retelling of the real-life events set in the 1820s\nthat inspired the writing of Herman Melville's classic novel 'Moby\nDick'. Chris Hemsworth plays Owen Chase, a husband and soon-to-be\nfather living in New England, who along with Captain Pollard, leads a\ncrew of sailors on a ship known as the 'Essex' on an expedition to\nacquire whale across the Atlantic ocean. In the process, the crew is\nfaced with a series of unpleasant situations including violent\nthunderstorms and an attack of a giant killer whale that leads to the\ndestruction of their ship. Faced with heavy casualties and plagued by\nstarvation, Chase and the crew takes some extreme measures to survive\nwhile stranded at sea in the middle of nowhere. This story is told by\nOwen Chase in his later years who tells the story to Herman Melville\n(played by Ben Whishaw) as he writes the novel. This film features the\nsupporting cast of Tom Holland, Cillian Murphy, Brendan Gleeson, Frank\nDilane, Gary Deadle, and several others."

                "reviewTitle": "The coolest action film you'll see all year",
                "reviewTotalVote": "807",
                "reviewUseful": "465",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nAt first glance, John Wick sounds like a terrible film on paper but\nwith the slickness of Keanu Reeves' performance as the titular\ncharacter and the sheer brilliance in its action sequences, this marks\nthe best action film of the year and one of the absolute best in the\npast decade. Following a brutal home invasion that leaves his beloved\ndog murdered by thugs from his past, John Wick vows revenge on the ones\nwho have taken what he loves most. Like I said, on paper, this seems\nlike a direct-to-DVD slopfest starring John Cena but as a film with\nKeanu Reeves as the lead, it marks the very welcomed return for Reeves\nto the genre. John Wick is insanely fun, violently brutal and an\noverall romp especially for those disappointed by The Expendables 3.\nJohn Wick is propelled by Tarantino-esque dialog mixed with the swagger\nof action stars from the 70s. Reeves literally emulates cool in this\nfilm and does it with such confidence, that we don't even doubt the\ncharacter...even when he kills countless bad guys with extreme force in\nsome utterly ridiculous and implausible situations. We don't doubt it\nfor a minute. This is EXACTLY what you want out of an action film. It\nis briskly paced, brilliantly shot and meticulously choreographed and\nkeeps you wanting more and more. The supporting cast filled with the\nlikes of John Legiuzamo, Ian McShane, and Willen Dafoe also keeps this\nfilm very interesting. These guys don't play good guys, hell, John Wick\nby traditional standards would be a bad guy in any other film. Every\ncharacter is more ruthless than the next and pushes John Wick to be\nmore ruthless than they are, creating a very cool dynamic between the\ncharacter and the plot regarding the idea of how far is too far?\nHowever, don't expect some revelation from John Wick regarding the\nmorality of bad and evil. This film wants you entertained and does so\nwith brute force, it never lets up, not even for a second. One scene in\nparticular that will have your blood pumping is a showdown between\nthugs and Wick in a nightclub. This action sequence remains the best in\nthe film and will have you grasping your theater seat because of the\nsheer intensity of it. Overall, John Wick is slick, violent fun that\nturns into a remarkable, surprising film that will catch you off guard.\nIt is THAT good. I highly recommend this film to action buffs\nespecially but I'm sure those who just like a good movie will love it\nas well.\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "611",
                "reviewUseful": "334",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nJohn Wick is something special. It takes as much time setting up\nelaborate action sequences as it does the world with which it all takes\nplace in. And what a world it is. It reminds me of Millers Crossing and\nit is cooler than any other recent attempt at noir. We are shown a\ncriminal underworld where, if you are connected, many powerful people\nknow who you are and show you respect. John Wick was connected but he\ngot out. He is the rare killer who has found peace, and he is grateful\nfor that peace. Some young kids steal that from him and he does what he\ndoes best, he wages a one man war against the Russian Mafia. It might\nsound like the film takes quite a leap but it all makes sense. The\nmotives of John and the people who get in the way of his bullets are\nall very clear, even if it does come across as rather simple. That's\nthe plot at it's most basic. Then there's the action. The film is\ndirected by Reeve's stuntman from The Matrix, so this guy knows action.\nThere are sequences that flow so smoothly it puts other action films\nand their quick cuts to shame. Keaunu moves so fluidly throughout the\nfilm and comes across as such a natural that the only disappointment is\nthat we have not seen him like this before. Along the way are plenty of\ncharacter actors, fans of The Matrix and The Wire will recognize a few\npeople then there are more obvious ones like Ian McShane and Willem\nDafoe. Everyone seems to be having a good time. That is another plus\nfor this movie. It get's dark at times but overall it is quite fun, not\nvery chipper, but fun. I cannot recommend this movie enough. I believe\nit is a must see for action fans and for anyone looking for something a\nbit different from the usual fare.\n"
