            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Daniel Wayno",
                "reviewDate": "29 July 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "General movie watchers opinion",
                "reviewTotalVote": "337",
                "reviewUseful": "225",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nAfter seeing and liking the first and the second part of this trilogy,\nthe third came off as a disappointment. There are only a few things\nthat actually work in this movie - Hathaway an Levitt gave very nice\nperformances, and were convincing despite of the ludicrously clich\u00e9\nlines they were given. Before seeing the movie, I presumed that (based\non the reviews I had read) they had only minor roles, but the two of\nthem guide the plot. Also some action sequences were well executed. But\nonly a minority of them. The majority was illogical and confusing. In\ncomparison with the second movie which I found to be, in its core (\neven with the occasional shabby lines), an intelligent and elegant\nmovie, this one lacks action. Of course that a movie shouldn't be\njudged by the amount of action, but in lack of it there must be a good\nstoryline. This movie has none. Its plot is full of gaps, frustratingly\nillogical. One of the things that induced from me a great snore was the\njail and childwhoescaped subplot. The idea of the jail is absurd. Whose\nprison is it, why are there no guards? Oh, I know it's inescapable...\nbut please. Its location is outside of some ancient city walls, but\nvery near it, and a modern complex is build only yards away (you can\nsee it on the edge of the screen when Bruce escapes \u0096 but I will get to\nthat). Bane (the Big Bad of the movie) escorted Bruce to the Asian jail\nhimself, made all that way just to tell Bruce that he will torture his\nsoul, and went back to Gotham, in the US, in the matter of hours. Why\nmaking that journey? It's impractical as hell. Furthermore, the man in\nprison, who are paid by Bane to keep Bruce alive (the man actually\nuttered the line \u0096 I'm paid more to keep you alive, when Bruce asked\nfor death), are helping him fix his dislocated spine (no, it's not\nbroken) and escape. Why? After a few tries, Bruce manages to climb the\nwell and emerges on the surface. He throws some big, fat rope back in\nthe pit. Where did that rope come from? Was it left outside just in\ncase someone climbed to freedom so he can free all the other prisoners?\nBruce himself had no rope \u0096 that was the whole point. Is the prisoners\nsafety rope actually tied at the surface? If so, why no one climbed the\nrope itself? Hell, my brother with whom I watched the movie actually\nthought that he threw down the safety rope to make sure nobody else\nwould escape. Then Bruce, with no money, no passport and no knowledge\nof the native language returns in the terrorist occupied and military\nguarded Gotham. He also, at the time, has no Batmobile, Batcopter or\nany other Bat-based vehicle. How did he get into the city? Fortunately,\nonce in the city, he found his Bat-copter lying on the roof of a\nmiddle-height building, a huge thing covered only with a nett, and\nvisible from air. With all the riots in the city, is it possible that\nnobody had stumbled upon it? Also, once in the Bat-copter, he\nencourages the not-long-ago buried police forces (who all have clean\nclothes and are clean-shaved after being underground for months) to\nattack the terrorists, but instead of helping them by shooting the\nenemy from air superiority, he lands the Bat-copter and seeks Bane for\na fistfight. Is this not idiotic? The only action scene that was good\nwas the one after the stock-market attack when Batman made a dashing\nescape. But, not even this scene can be compared with the ones from the\nsecond movie which were thrilling, masterfully directed and longer.\nThey were also simpler, there was no atom bomb, there were just guns\nand explosives, but it worked better, it was more realistic, and\ndarker. Unfortunately, what replaced action is load of parapsychology,\nthe endlessly recycled story of the orphan Bruce, with many annoying\nflashbacks from previous films. You know the movie is not doing well\nwhen there are flashbacks involved. What got on my nerves a lot was\nalso that all lectured Bruce, the man who sacrificed everything to help\nGotham and do good. Alfred was particularly pathetic. Bane is truly a\npoorly done movie villain. The comic book character is said to have\nsome intelligence. This was not present here. The opening scene, the\ndelivery of the plan of doctor Pavel's abduction: Bane has executed a\npointlessly expensive and complicated operation where he sacrificed\nunnecessarily three of his man, chopped up a plane and then used the\nalready seen skyhook (The Dark Knight), when he easily could have\nattacked the plane on land. The romance between him and Coltirald's\ncharacter is also redundant. His and Cotillard's background story could\nhave been left unexplained. Even with it, both of them lack motivation.\nThe rest of the movie Bane makes impressive entries. Actually a lot of\nthe movie is about walking on the street, walking through the sewage,\netc. And entering rooms. The romance between Bruce and Cotillard\ncharacter was redundant and not probable (I accept this only if Bruce\nwanted a quick shag after a long time of drought). The explosion,\nbeside the unnerving need of certain directors to explain in word what\nwe understood in picture (someone actually had said Explosion! after\nwe've have already seen the mushroom), was not realistic (no waves).\nBut, as a whole, the movie is sufferable, just don't expect anything\ngreat. The thing I hated the most is that Batman is missing from this\nfilm. Bruce was more out of the suit, than in it. Seems to me that\nNolan became a little bit too cocky with all the praise for the two\nprevious movies. It's a shame because the movie could have been a lot\nbetter if he hadn't.\n"

I think\npeople were expecting this to be right up there with the first three, but\nforgot to realize that this movie is the beginning of the\nsaga.....\nViewers also complained about the complexity of the plot with all the\npolitics....my thoughts are that we need to be informed of the fragile and\ncrumbling centre of the republic in order to completely understand the\nbirth\nof the Empire. But now that this has all been done, I believe that the\naction will kick into full swing with \"Attack of the Clones\" (Episode II)\nCheck out the documentaries on the Official site.....especially \"trying to\ndo my thing\" Take a look at our next Anakin.....I think we all will be\npleasantly surprised with what the next movie has to offer. Anyway my\nrating\nfor The Phantom Menace is a healthy 8.5/10."

                "reviewTotalVote": "48",
                "reviewUseful": "35",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\n\nWhen I was a small kid, I used to wonder what the Star Wars universe was\nall\nabout. Imperial soldiers, droids, flying spaceships and starfighters, Jedi\nKnights, Darth Vader, etc. I was curious with all of these stuff but when I\nwatched all the three Star Wars movies, I began to understand what George\nLucas, the creator of the popular sci-fi saga itself, was trying to\naccomplish: explore the awe and wonders of our ever expanding universe. And\nnow, 22 years after the release of the first movie, George Lucas and his\nentire crew at Lucasfilm bring the most anticipated movie of 1999, Star\nWars\nEpisode I: The Phantom Menace.\nI am truly impressed with this incredible film despite its noticeable\nflaws.\nThe evil Trade Federation has stopped all shipping to the peaceful planet\nof\nNaboo. To resolve that matter, the Galactic Republic decides to dispatch\nthe\ntwo Jedi Knights, Obi-Wan Kenobi and Qui-Gon Jinn to the Trade Federation\nBattleship to arrange a negotiation with the Neimodians. Unfortunately for\nour heroes, the negotiation never takes place and so they fight\nface-to-face\nwith thousands of battle droids, escape to Naboo, and there they meet the\nannoying yet kind-hearted Gungan, Jar Jar Binks as well as the beautiful\nQueen Amidala (ok, I know some of you out there complaint about her\nmake-up).  Later, our heroes meet Anakin Skywalker, a mysterious boy who is\nbelieved to bring the Balance to the Force. In my opinion, Anakin is such a\ncool person because he is a great podracer who never wins a single match\nuntil his recent confrontation with rival Sebulba (he is going to fly a\nNaboo starfighter too during the battle of Naboo. Bravo to Jake Lloyd!).\nYou\nneed to see the rest of the film if you haven't watched one\nyet.\nEpisode I: The Phantom Menace is a very enjoyable movie that may even\nattract those who are not widely known to the Star Wars universe. I\nespecially like the locations on some planets (the Naboo Palace and the\nwondrous city of Coruscant) as well as its awesome special effects. To\nheighten up the action, Darth Maul makes an incredible performance during\nthe climatic battle with the Jedi Knights. However, I never say that The\nPhantom Menace is a 100% perfect movie. The storyline is pretty weak  (gee,\nI wonder what George Lucas is thinking) and some characters aren't well\ndeveloped.  Still, this IS just only the beginning, and perhaps there will\nbe a major improvement by the time Episode II is released."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "TheLittleSongbird",
                "reviewDate": "24 October 2009",
                "reviewTitle": "Visually a marvel to look at, disappointing in terms of story",
                "reviewTotalVote": "38",
                "reviewUseful": "28",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nStar Wars: Episode 1- The Phantom Menace is definitely worth a watch,\nbut I do think it is one of the weaker movies of the Star Wars saga. I\nwill admit I wasn't expecting much after reading some very negative\nreviews on IMDb, but I do think this particular instalment did in some\nways exceed my expectations and disappointed as well. On a visual and\ntechnical level, it looks absolutely fantastic, with splendid special\neffects, stunning cinematography and fine scenery and costumes. The\nscript is fairly decent, perhaps lacking the sophistication of Empire\nStrikes Back or New Hope, but does have some memorable lines. The\naction is constantly exhilarating, and Darth Maul, well played by Ray\nPark is a very good villain. Of course though, Darth Vader is better.\nMost of the performances are very good, especially Natalie Portman as\nQueen Padma who looked stunning and Jake Lloyd as Anakin Skywalker who\nshone with his confident charm. And Jar Jar Binks is okay on the most\npart, and you have to love Yoda. And the music score by John Williams\nwas outstanding, definitely one of his best works. The quality of sound\nand direction are also impressive. However, there were things about\nthis film that did disappoint. One is despite the awesome visuals,\nstrong music score and good characters, the story never quite\ndistinguished itself. It did take a while to get going, and when it did\ntry to get going and you could tell it wanted to, it was further\ndisadvantaged by the uneven pacing. Liam Neeson is a fine actor, his\nperformances in Kinsey and Schindler's List are proof of that, and I do\nlike Ewan McGregor. But as Qui-Gon Jin and Obi Wan Kenobi, both stars\ngive unusually wooden performances, and at times looked even\nembarrassed. And as I said, the pacing is very uneven, there are some\nslow moments, and one or two scenes felt rushed. All in all, maybe\ndisappointing for fans of the saga, but it cannot be denied that\nvisually it is an accomplishment. 7/10 Bethany Cox\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "zaldymir",
                "reviewDate": "26 December 2001",
                "reviewTitle": "A great addition to the Star Wars legacy",
                "reviewTotalVote": "13",
                "reviewUseful": "11",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\n\nAfter a long delay (and much anticipation) we finally got the first part of\nLucas's story, and where the trouble all began. Many other people viewed it\nas a rather sub-par attempt, uncreative and unsurprising. I couldn't\ndisagree more. One could go with the impressive state-of-the-art digital\neffects, one could go with the great cast of new characters (the awesome\nLiam Neeson as Qui-Gon Jinn, for instance), the return of old favorites\n(Kenny Baker as R2D2 or Frank Oz as Yoda), John Williams' ever-wonderful\nscore, the complicated story (I won't bother discussing the plot; everyone\nknows what it's about by now) or the awesome action sequences (the light\nsaber duel at the end of the film is the best!). It's obvious this film was\nmisunderstood by many, and too many movie-goers set their expectations too\nhigh, which is unfair to Mr. Lucas to say the least. I was excited for the\nchance to see a new Star Wars film, but I took no expectations into the\ntheater with me -- I went in ready for nothing and walked away very\nsatisfied. I saw this film four times in the theater, something I don't do\nmuch of these days. Lucas did a great job, and since this film is really\nonly exposition for the overall series, how can one expect it to be a topper\nto the original trilogy? He's just setting everything up! Give Mr. Lucas a\nbreak. If this film had been released first, it would have been the rage of\nages just as A New Hope was when it first came out. Everything in this film\nwas very nicely done; the cast and crew all performed their jobs\nexceptionally. The story was far more complex and interesting than usual,\nwith more going on and more problems to solve. By the way, everyone, the\n\"Phantom Menace\" referred to by the title is so obvious that very few people\ntruly understood what it was... the Phantom Menace was the orchestrator of\nthe evil deeds, the driving force behind the attacks, the central villain of\nthe picture... a character we see mainly as a hologram (only once\notherwise): Darth Sidious. Darth Sidious is the Phantom Menace, and the evil\nsingle man who drives the entire plot. The movie was perfectly named. I\nloved this movie, and it has become one of my favorite Star Wars films\n(alongside A New Hope). I can't wait for Episode II!\n"

Rather, I normally don't\nreview just because I put a premium on my time, and don't want to spend\ntime repeating what others may have already said about a given film;\nuntil today, that is. In my inaugural review, I was very motivated (I\nmean incensed) to write this review now having come back for the\ncinema, freshly infuriated in the realization that I can't get 2.5\nhours of my life back after watching MI-5. I read glowing reviews\nbefore going to the film, to which I am now wondering if I saw the same\nfilm others who reviewed this film as \"highly enjoyable\". I am beyond\npuzzled how this film got good reviews, unless it is from reviewers who\nget easily bamboozled by special effects to forgive the need for a\nplot, or work for the makers of the film, or who are not of this earth.\nThe planet to which these people who did liked this poor excuse for a\n\"film\" I do not know. Yes, I knew it would be an action film, and yes I\nknew one has to suspend disbelief to enjoy a film like this, but\ndespite these prerequisites being in place in my mind going into the\ntheater, this film content was so vacant and vapid it boggles my mind\nthat I sat through its entirety and didn't walk out mid-film. The plot\nwas not in the slightest way possible to follow, and the reviewers\nshouldn't confuse plot complexity (which a good story can have)with the\nnonsensical incongruity of this film. Tom Cruise--who was truly\noutstanding in Jerry Mcquire,the Firm, Vanilla Sky and Eyes Wide Shut--\nwas hardly that as an international spy. Mr Baldwin--another\noutstanding actor and wonderful in the Royal Tannenbaums and Blue\nJasmine--but his role in this film was completely under-utilized. The\nother actors were alright, but its just that the plot and its\npresentation was just insulting to any intelligence. Endless product\nplacements for BMW, and then when the locale of different places were\nindicated when they showed in an areal pan shot its a bit much to say\nshow the US Congress and Washington Monument, combined with the need to\ntype in the upper right corner...\"Washington D.C.\", just to make it\nlook official and inform us that we are in Washington D.C. just in case\none didn't know..I can't remember if the pan shot of Big Ben was\naccompanied by the words \"London, England\". If you are looking for a\nsimilar action/conspiracy spy film with slick international intrigue\nwith believable characters, I highly recommend \"The International\" out\na few years back. In sum, please, save your time, stay at home and\nwatch paint dry for a more redeeming experience.\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "21",
                "reviewUseful": "11",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nI don't care what Tom Cruise's religious beliefs are. I don't care if\nhe acted like a pork chop on Oprah. I don't care if the tabloids love\nto hate him. The Cruiser is a one-of-a-kind megastar responsible for a\nconsistently excellent output of work since the eighties. Back for his\nfifth impossible mission at the spritely age of 53, he's showing no\nsigns of slowing down either. The ridiculous pre-credits aircraft\nstunt, where Cruise hangs on to the side of an Airbus A400 whilst it\ntakes off, attests to that. There's also a thrilling car-and-motorbike\nsequence (bringing back memories of the awesome Bourne Supremacy car\nchase) that sees Cruise commit to most of the high-speed driving/riding\nhimself. It's this willingness to go above and beyond, as well as a\npreference of practical effects over CGI, which imbues Rogue Nation\nwith nail biting tension and non-stop exhilaration. Not as stylish as\nJ.J. Abrams (M:I3) or Brad Bird (M:I4), writer-director Christopher\nMcQuarrie brings a hard-hitting brutality to the screen instead,\narguably delivering the most violent entry in the franchise.\nMcQuarrie's script is suitably meaty too, giving the cast plenty to\nchew on when not performing death defying acts, pummelling each other\nwithout remorse or manoeuvring in an assassination showdown. Cruise is\nreliably sensational as top dog and newcomers Rebecca Ferguson and Sean\nHarris are fantastic as, respectively, the femme fatale and unrelenting\nvillain, but Jeremy Renner looks bored and Simon Pegg overeggs it on\noccasion. With ballsy action scenes that pack a punch and a gritty\nstory to keep you excited, this is definitely worth forking out your\nhard earned to experience on the big screen.\n"

The film also\ncontains a lot of emotional acting which is usually seen in boxing\nfilms but not to this extent. It still\ncould get Oscar nods, but if every other award is to go by, Southpaw\nhas been greatly misjudged, which is a terrible shame. The acting\nall-round is excellent. While Sylvester\nStallone is rightfully getting awards recognition for his reprisal of\nRocky, Forest Whitaker is as good as Nick Nolte was in Warrior. With\nNick getting an Oscar nod, the same could be said for Forest, but it\nseems Southpaw has been written off for awards, which is a shame as it\nbelongs in the exact same boat as Creed.                 "reviewAuthor": "leonblackwood",
                "reviewDate": "3 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "An emotional movie with some real boxing scenes. 7/10",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nReview: I quite enjoyed this emotional movie and I definitely think\nthat Jake Gyllenhaal should be up for an Oscar for his amazing\ntransformation. The storyline did seem to drag after a while but I\ncouldn't wait for the big showdown at the end. Anyway, Billy Hope (Jake\nGyllenhaal) seems to have it all, with his big mansion, beautiful wife\nand loving daughter, and when the lightweight boxer wins all of the\nchampionship belts, life really can't get any better for this man who\nstruggled through his childhood. He then gets invited to a charity\nevent were he gives a speech about his life and his love for his wife,\nMaureen Hope (Rachel McAdams) but his whole life changes when a gun is\nfired during a punch up with his arch-rival, Miguel \"Magic\" Escobar\n(Miguel Gomez). The shot, mistakingly hits his wife, who dies on the\nspot, which leaves a distraught Billy Hope, to bring up his daughter\nLeila Hope (Oona Laurence). Whilst trying to defend his title, he\nbasically gives up fighting against his opponent and he ends up\nhead-butting the referee out of shear frustration. Now that he's lost\nhis title, it defaults a 3 fight deal that he has with a television\ncompany and he's being sued for the head-butting incident. With his\ndebts piling up and his boxing career in tatters, he turns to drink and\ndrugs for comfort and the depression from losing his wife, starts to\ntake its toll. He then ends up in hospital after crashing his car into\na tree, so the child protection agency are brought in, because they\nfound drink and drugs in his body while he was driving. A judge decides\nto put Leila into care while Billy sorts his life out, so he sells his\nhouse to clear up his debts and he gets a job in a gym, which he also\nuses to train. After much persuasion, he manages to get the gym owner,\nTick Wills (Forest Whitaker) to train him in his own unique way, which\nwill improve his boxing skills but his daughter refuses to see him\nbecause she blames him for being in care. He then gets a chance to box\nin a charity bash, we're he shows of his new boxing style and impresses\nhis old manager, Jordan Mains (50 Cent), who is now managing Escobar.\nHe offers him a chance to return to the big league by challenging\nEscobar to a championship bout but he only has 6 weeks to train and to\nget in shape. As he desperately needs the money to get his daughter\nback, he goes through some gruesome training with Tick and he manages\nto build a relationship with his daughter again. With his new trainer\nby his side and his daughter back in his life, he uses every muscle in\nhis body to fight against the man who was involved in the murder of his\nwife. I really enjoyed the intensity during boxing fights and the\nemotional scenes with his daughter. Jakes anger issues were performed\nextremely well and the love that he had for his wife was really sweet,\njust like Rocky with Adrian but I did find it a bit predictable.\nPersonally, I'm surprised that they didn't pick 50 Cent to play the\nboxer because of his physique and hard man mentality! Anyway, I enjoyed\nthis movie and the hero to zero to hero again, concept was well put\ntogether by the director. Enjoyable!"

In my opinion this isn't an error and it's set on purpose.\nProbably it wants to give the idea that even if he gets hit straight\ninto his face, he keeps fighting and trying, knowing that as in life,\nif you are there at the right spot and time, even if you might be\nbehind, you should never give up because you can have a great come\nback. More than that, later on, his life is taking a wrong turn and he\nloses everything, but again, he never gives up, he probably took a\n\"K.O\", but he gets up, fights and believes he can make. It's\nan efficient story but a sad one as it felt like Billy Hope (Jake\nGyllenhaal) couldn't get a break until 2/3 of the movie was finished.\nThe movie does not back down on Hope and this can get disheartening but\nmakes the ending much more powerful.             {
                "reviewAuthor": "leonblackwood",
                "reviewDate": "24 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Funny throughout! 7/10",
                "reviewTotalVote": "4",
                "reviewUseful": "0",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nReview: I really enjoyed this movie! I laughed all the way through\nthis, far fetched comedy and the mixture of top class actors, gave it\nthe shock factor. The funny script and impressive action scenes were\ngreat and it was good to see the funny side of Jason Statham. Melissa\nMcCarthy plays a desk bound CIA employee (Susan Cooper), who guides her\npartner, Bradley Fine (Jude Law) through his various missions and\nsecretly has a crush on him. Whilst on a mission to retrieve a nuclear\nbomb from Tihomir Boyanov, he accidentally kills him without getting\nthe bombs location. The only other person who might know the bombs\nlocation is Boyanov's daughter, Rayna (Rose Byrne), so Fine goes to her\nhouse to try and gather some information. On his entry, Rayna kills him\nwhile Susan is watching and she tells Susan that she knows the\nidentities of all of the agents. Susan then volunteers to become a\nfield agent so she can take-down Rayna and revenge Fine, so her boss\nElaine Crocker (Allison Janney) agrees on her terms, as long as she\ndoesn't have any contact with Rayna. One of the other agents, Rick Ford\n(Jason Statham), is disgusted with Elaine's decision to put Susan in\nthe field and he quits his job and leaves the agency. Susan is then\nsent to Paris to spy on Sergio De Luca (Bobby Cannavale) and she bumps\ninto Ford, who has turned rogue and has no faith in Susan completing\nthe mission. The next day, Susan sees an assassin exchanging Ford's bag\nwith a bomb so she tells Ford about the exchange and then she takes\nchase against the assassin, who she kills by pushing him off a balcony.\nSusan then follows De Luca to Rome and she meets her contact, Aldo\n(Peter Serafinowicz), whose and Italian agent, working for the same\nagency. She then follows De Luca to a casino but she's not allowed to\nget near him, so she goes to the bar, were she see's a man put drugs\ninto Rayna's drink. She decides to tell Rayna about the drugs, which\nsaves her life, so Rayna recruits Susan as her bodyguard. They then fly\nto Budapest, we're another assassin tries to kill Rayna on the plane\nbut Susan saves her life again and safely lands the plane. Rayna is\nconvinced that Susan is a CIA agent, so Susan tells her that her father\nhired her to protect her. In Budapest, Nancy Artingstall (Miranda Hart)\nis sent to keep an eye on Susan and another assassin tries to kill\nRayna, so Nancy takes Rayna to safety while Susan chases the assassins,\nwho turn out to be the CIA double agents, working for Rayna. Later that\nnight, they go to a party, were Rayna is due to meet up with De Luca's\nassociate Lia (Nargis Fakhri), so Nancy creates a diversion so Susan\ncan stop the meeting. After chasing down Lia, Susan ends up in a fight\nwith her in the kitchen and her life is saved by Fine, who faked his\ndeath so he can become Rayna's lover. Susan is then imprisoned with\nAldo in a bunker, were Fine tells her that he really faked his death so\nhe can get to the nuclear bomb. Susan and Aldo manage to break out of\nthe bunker and they go to De Luca's mansion, we're they are selling the\nbomb for diamonds. Susan poses as a double agent and when the bomb is\nrevealed, De Luca kills the buyer and his men and threatens to kill\nRayna but Ford appears, which distracts De Luca, so Susan can save\nRayna's life again. De Luca then escapes with the bomb and the diamonds\nin a helicopter so Susan takes chase and hangs on to the landing gear\nwith Ford hanging on to her. Nancy and Aldo arrive in another\nhelicopter and shoot De Luca but he isn't dead and he hangs onto\nSusan's necklace, which was given to her by Fine, so she unhook's the\nnecklace and De Luca falls to his death. Elaine then arrives to\nretrieve the bomb and Rayna is arrested, realising that she has found a\nfriend in Susan. Elaine then appoints Susan as an agent and gives her\nfiles for her next mission. The director really did spend his budget\nwell because he was able to get some top class actors, film in\ndifferent countries and have some impressive action scenes whilst still\nmaking the storyline witty and air tight. Jude Law proves that he\nshould be a candidate to play Bond and Jason Statham shows that he can\nplay comedic roles, so like Tom Cruise in Tropic Thunder, I hope he\nstars in more movies in this genre. Anyway, I really enjoyed this movie\nthe first time round but I doubt that it will have the same affect the\nsecond time round. Enjoyable!\u00a0"

                "reviewTitle": "Insanity doesn't even begin to describe it!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "109",
                "reviewUseful": "87",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nI'm not gonna lie! I love this franchise. Aside from the third movie, I\nenjoy each one of them. You can't ask for much more when it comes to\naction movies. This series has always been a box office attraction, but\nthe real story is Paul Walker's tragic death. I remember being really\nsaddened when I read about his untimely death. He had come such a long\nway as an actor. He was getting better and better, and the sky was the\nlimit for him. I was so pumped to go see this movie! My expectations\nwere pretty high. I'm happy to say that it not only met my\nexpectations, but transcended them as well. If you're looking for a\ngreat story, look elsewhere! This movie isn't about that. It has plenty\nof emotion and a decent enough story for this type of thing, but this\npuppy is all about action. I thought after the 6th one, they had\nnowhere to go after it. What else could they possibly do, how could\nthey top themselves? Well, they did it! In convincing fashion. This is\nlike 5 action movies in one. If you think you've seen it all, you\nhaven't! There are action scenes in this movie that I didn't think were\npossible. They are incredibly unbelievable and WAY OTT, but undeniably\nexhilarating. I thought some of the situations they got out of in the\n5th and 6th movies were ridiculous, this one takes the cake. It rarely\ngives you a chance to breathe! Just when you settle down, along comes\nanother action scene to amaze you. As an adrenaline junkie, I loved\nevery second of it. I'm not gonna list all of them, but I'll mention a\ncouple. One involves Brian and a huge truck at the edge of a cliff.\nIt's completely implausible, but I was on the edge of my seat! Another\ninvolves Dom and his destruction of vehicles. I won't spoil them, but\nthey are memorable. The acting is solid! Vin won't ever be known as a\ngreat actor, but he has a lot of presence and charisma. He is always\nreliable in these movies. Paul Walker is really good as Brian. I was\nreally happy with the tribute they did for him at the end. It was very\nmoving and touching. The Rock (Dwayne Johnson) Is a hoot as Hobbs. It\nsucks that he didn't have as much screen time, but his crazy antics\nwere a blast to watch! Great lines as well. Michelle Rodriguez isn't\nthe Letty we know. She's damaged and vulnerable. I'm so used to seeing\nMichelle playing bad-ass roles, so it was cool. Jason Statham is a fun\nvillain. You know what to expect when it comes from him. Kicking ass\nand taking names. Jordana Brewster doesn't have much to do, but she was\ngood. As a huge Kurt Russell fan, it was a treat to see him again. He\nwas hilarious and a lot of fun to watch. Ludicrous and Tyrese Gibson do\nwell in their roles. Special mention to Tony Jaa and Ronda Rousey! Tony\nJaa actually gets a chance to showcase his phenomenal skill set. His\nfight scenes with Paul Walker will get your adrenaline going. "

                "reviewAuthor": "zardoz-13",
                "reviewDate": "6 April 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "A White-Knuckled, Super-Charged, Adrenaline-Laced Actioneer",
                "reviewTotalVote": "109",
                "reviewUseful": "87",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nIf you didn't know actor Paul Walker perished in a fiery car crash back\non November 30, 2013, you'd never know it by watching \"Furious 7, the\nlatest installment in the \"Fast and Furious\" franchise. \"Saw\" director\nJames Wan and \"Wanted\" scenarist Chris Morgan had about half of this\nmammoth $250 million movie made when tragedy struck and claimed\nWalker's life. Altogether, \"Furious 7\" emerges not only as a cinematic\neulogy to Walker's ephemeral career but also as a white-knuckled,\nsuper-charged, adrenaline-laced actioneer. Initially, \"The Fast and the\nFurious\" (2001) crossed the finish line as an above-average, illegal\nroad-racing epic about an undercover cop that bolstered actor Vin\nDiesel's box office clout while it forged Paul Walker's career. Walker\ncarried on with Tyrese Gibson after a disaffected Diesel bowed out of\n2003's sequel \"2 Fast 2 Furious,\" but the chrome-domed Diesel gave his\nblessing to the chronologically out-of-sequence \"Fast and Furious:\nTokyo Drift\" (2006) with a post end credits cameo. Some consider \"Tokyo\nDrift\" the nadir of the franchise, but I contend that \"Tokyo Drift\"\nsurpassed its skid mark of a predecessor. The three sequels that ensued\nfueled the franchise with even more vitality. Not even Walker's demise\ncould put the brakes on \"Furious 7.\" Mind you, \"Furious 7\" doesn't\nqualify as an artistic magnum opus. Nevertheless, aside from either the\nJames Bond blockbusters or the Harry Potter series, can you name a\ncontemporary franchise with as many sequels as \"The Fast and the\nFurious?\" Whether we see an eighth entry, \"Furious 7\" has knocked the\nbottom out of the franchise. Wan and Morgan have concocted some\npreposterous high-octane stunts that defy gravity as well as logic but\nlook extraordinary. Jason Statham, Kurt Russell, Djimon Hounsou, and\nAsian \"Ong Bak\" martial arts sensation Tony Jarr augment the original\ncast and invigorate these improbable shenanigans. If \"Furious 7\" marks\nyour initiation to the franchise, you're going to have a blast catching\nup with the rest of us. \"Furious 7\" ranks as the top of the heap in a\nfranchise that has never throttled back. "

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Argemaluco",
                "reviewDate": "4 April 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Furious  7",
                "reviewTotalVote": "113",
                "reviewUseful": "89",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nThe films belonging to The Fast and the Furious saga have been\nincreasing the ambition of the stunts and action scenes with every new\nsequel, while the screenplays have been getting more tangled and\napparatus in order to guarantee the numerous cast to have enough\nmoments of individual showcasing. Furious 7 isn't the exception, and I\nfound it very entertaining, while it elevated the level of drama and\nmotoring stunts beyond any reason or logic... which is exactly what we\nexpect in a film from this franchise. Besides, the sad death of actor\nPaul Walker's brings a gravity to the story which the screenplay could\nhave never generated by itself. I think that, until now, I could found\nthe validity in the wordiness about \"family\", which has been repeated\nmany times by Vin Diesel in the films of this saga (I counted at least\nfour instances in Furious 7). I wish that this new emotional weight\nhadn't been due to such tragic reasons, but it undoubtedly influenced\nmy perception of the film. Anyway... what people want to see are the\naction scenes, and Furious 7 completely fulfills the expectations in\nthat regard, with a series of outlandish stunts which are totally\nimprobable but very entertaining. Screenwriter Chris Morgan found an\nappropriate balance between action and story, and director James Wan\nmade a fluid and dynamic work. Editorial comment: the quantity and\ncomplexity of the stunts displayed in Furious 7 are making some people\ntalk about the possibility of introducing a special category for stunt\ndoubles at the Oscars; and I think that's an excellent idea. There's\nundoubtedly digital manipulation in those scenes (erasing of cables,\nface replacement, general retouch), but there's still an extraordinary\nmechanic talent, pyrotechnic and logistical talent involved in the\nshooting of those scenes, something which would deserve a formal\nrecognition by the Oscars. There are currently two categories dedicated\nto the technicians who mix the audio of car crashes... and none to the\ndrivers who risked their lives? Ridiculous. End of the editorial\ncomment. The veteran actors of the saga do their usual stuff in Furious\n7, as it can be supposed. As for the additions of the cast, Jason\nStatham makes a perfect work as one of the villains, but the great\nDjimon Hounsou is completely wasted as the terrorist who wants to steal\na magic application of digital espionage. Kurt Russell brings an\nappropriate style and personality to his character. And the female\nfight scene between Michelle Rodriguez and Ronda Rousey is inferior to\nthe similar ones in which Gina Carano was involved in the previous\nfilm. I don't know whether this saga is going to continue without\nWalker; it probably will, considering the huge quantities of money\nthese films generate. My favorite movie from this franchise keeps being\nthe fifth one (Fast Five), but I can recommend Furious 7 as a very\ncompetent action film, and as a solid tribute/final chapter in case\nthey decide to stop here.\n"

This accident was not part of\nfilming, but did drastically change the story line and halted\nproduction for quite a while. Walker had not finished filming his\nscenes, but you wouldn't know it, as the filmmakers used a combination\nof amazing CGI and stunt doubles to add him through the entire film.\nIt's seamless and flawless in that aspect, and yes, there is a very\nmoving tribute to him at the end of the film, which might cause you to\nchoke back a few tears. I know I had too."

                "reviewTotalVote": "566",
                "reviewUseful": "337",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nWatchmen is the long-awaited graphic novel adaptation that has for a\nlong time been deemed un-filmable. There have been many different\npoints over the years where this movie was supposed to be made, which\nalways ended up not happening. But now Watchmen is finally here in all\nits glory, and it's probably the best adaptation possible of this\ncomplex graphic novel. The story takes place in an alternative 1985,\nwith Nixon beginning his third term as president, and the streets of\nNew York are gritty, dark, and violent. Within New York lives a group\nof costumed heroes that used to be loved by society, but are now hated\nby practically everybody. One night a depressed retired hero named The\nComedian is murdered by a masked person that breaks into his apartment.\nAnother hero named Rorschach, who wears a mask with shifting ink blots,\nbelieves that someone is picking off costumed heroes to begin their own\nagenda of destruction. Rorschach begins investigating and hunting down\nthe person that is responsible for The Comedian's death. Meanwhile we\nmeet another hero who glows blue, and has almost literally become a\nGod. His name is Dr. Manhattan, and although he has the power to save\nthe world he won't do it because he has lost many of his human\nemotions. The other main costumed heroes are Night Owl and Silk\nSpectre, who begin to fall in love amid the chaos of their secret\nlives. Any other attempt to describe the complex plot of this movie\nwould be nearly impossible."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "rufi-4",
                "reviewDate": "20 March 2009",
                "reviewTitle": "When is the good part coming?",
                "reviewTotalVote": "338",
                "reviewUseful": "198",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\n\"No. Not even in the face of Armageddon. Never compromise.\"-Rorschach\nWhile Rorschach's (Jackie Earle Haley) proclamation may be possible to\nuphold as a superhero, the refusal to compromise on behalf of the\nfilmmaker in the process of literary adaptation is impossible. As film\ntheorist Andr\u00e9 Bazin wrote, \"Faithfulness to form, literary or\notherwise, is illusory: what matters is the equivalence in meaning of\nthe forms.\" In other words, Bazin is arguing that each medium has its\nown modes of representation, thus the struggle for formal fidelity is a\nlost cause and that the main objective is that the adaptation should\ncapture the original work's essence. Bazin continues, stating, \"All it\ntakes is for the filmmakers to have enough visual imagination to create\nthe cinematic equivalent of the style of the original.\" Zach Snyder's\n(\"300\") attempt to adapt Alan Moore and Dave Gibbon's \"Watchmen\"\n(1986-1987) is compromised but that is the only possible way an\nadaptation can work as a film. He captures the Bazinian essence of\nMoore and Gibbon's work, a deconstruction of the superhero mythos, with\nan aesthetic that also captures much of the style of the original\ngraphic novel (to the degree it is possible in film). Will die-hard\nfans be disappointed? No doubt, but quite unjustly. Even with Snyder's\ncompromised ending, which ultimately can be interpreted as being more\ndevastating than the climax concocted by Moore and Gibbons (although\nthe film lacks a sequence on par with the opening pages of the comic's\ntwelfth volume), Snyder's ambitious attempt is the best that could be\ndone in a feature film."
            },

                "reviewTitle": "A Great Action Epic, But Nothing More",
                "reviewTotalVote": "699",
                "reviewUseful": "369",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nI am a movie and novel buff who has not read the book version of\nWatchmen. The book may be very good (friends tell me it is) but I can\nverify that the movie is awful. This is the problem: you fans of the\nbook come to the movie already caring about the characters, while\nmovie-goers depend upon the movie alone to give them a reason to care\nabout the characters and the world they live in. (Which brings me to\nanother problem: no one cares about saving the seamy rightwing version\nof the infinitely corrupt world of the 1980s. If that negative fascist\nfantasy dies in an explosion, good riddance. Isn't that the fulfilment\nof the rightist fantasy?) The movie fails mostly on this count, though\nthere are other weaknesses. (I'm talking to you, slo-mo spacecraft sex\nscene.) I found myself caring only about Rohrschach (well-acted by\nHaley). The big blue guy did not seem to have any real dilemmas and\nabsolutely no emotional depth, the diabolical plan of the hero-villain\nwas obscure until it was revealed and too late to care, and nothing\nlost seemed worth shedding a tear for. As for the rest of the world and\nthe characters, I just could not wait for the impending nuclear\nholocaust because then I would be able to go home. And I'm actually a\nvery peaceable person who in real life doesn't wish instant\nvaporization on anyone. Several people left early, which I have never\nseen in a movie theater before. (I guess I've never been to a movie\nthat spent this many hours being bad.) In sum, worth the money only if\nyou love all things Watchmen and, perhaps, if you really liked Forest\nGump and Moonraker. (Having said this, I could have watched a whole\nmovie about the giant blue guy winning the Vietnam War. That scene was\npretty cool.)\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "151",
                "reviewUseful": "81",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nAmazing film. Bringing a graphic novel as layered and complex as the\nWatchmen to the screen is no easy task and Snyder did a brilliant job.\nWatchmen was as unconventional, intellectual, cerebral, and unique to\nthe cinema world as much as the graphic novel was to the comic book\nworld. It's hard to not compare this to the novel but as a film it is\nbrilliant. Zack Snyder truly did the story justice. Look around online\nat where other filmmakers before him wanted to take the film. There was\neven one script where they updated it to be in present day and have the\nthreat be from terrorists. Snyder single handedly saved the Watchmen\nfrom a cinematic nightmare. He had the script reworked into the closest\nadaptation of any graphic novel to date. I would like to shake his hand\nand thank him for being one of the few filmmakers these days that\nactually cares about being faithful to the source material of film\nadaptations. Beyond being faithful, Snyder brought an amazing style and\nvision to the project. He brought an independent film sensibility to a\nbig budget picture which not many people have the guts to do. I don't\nthink enough can be said on what a great job he did. "

Granted, his 'Sucker\nPunch' may not share the sophistication of his former work (and I still\nhaven't tried 'Legend of the Guardians'; owls speaking in British\naccents almost screams 'Monty Python' to me), but every great director\nhas a dream project waiting to get made after a firm reputation has\nbeen established, and it can leave us either in awe (Inception!!), or\nwondering \"what the hell was he thinking?\" (but even 'Showgirls' had\nits merits).                 "reviewDate": "11 June 2009",
                "reviewTitle": "Awesome movie (with Disclaimer)",
                "reviewTotalVote": "16",
                "reviewUseful": "12",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nForgive me if I sound patronizing\u0097no, don't; I enjoy doing this--but\nbefore picking a movie apart people should know the first thing about\nconventions & about the little clues a (good) filmmaker leaves behind\nto set the context of his flick. See, here the U.S. won in Vietnam and\nNixon was still Prez in 1985. What Snyder is telling us with all that\nis that we shouldn't take any of this for real, that all is happening\nin a parallel universe; or if you prefer, in one made of cultural\nreferences, symbols, metaphors. This is a cartoon, just as Doonesbury\nis, but one for mature--and I would add, educated--people and anybody\ncomplaining about the \"inappropriate\" score, the excessive gore, the\n\"bad acting\" should better forget about it and go back to their\nTeletubbies."

Set in an alternative 1980s where President Nixon is in his third\nterm and superheroes exist. This is not a happy reality though; the\nsuperheroes have retired and for the most part are living ordinary\nlives\u0085 assuming they aren't dead or insane and the world is in the\nbrink of nuclear war as the Soviet Union prepares to invade\nAfghanistan. Against this backdrop 'The Comedian' one of the heroes is\nmurdered. Another of them, Rorschach, is determined to track down the\nkiller before any more of them are killed. As he searches we are\nintroduced to the rest of his group of superheroes, known as The\nWatchmen; we are shown their back-stories as well as learning what they\nare up to now; Dr. Manhattan is working on an energy source with his\nassistant the beautiful Laurie Jupiter, Adrian Veidt is the world's\nmost intelligent man and Dan Dreiberg is living a comparatively normal\nlife. It should be a good movie about aliens\nhunting down other aliens on earthly settings. Well its not a good\nmovie AT ALL. Oh boy is this one baaad...., this made me really\nangry... The actor has no talent at all he has like three facial\nexpression: the \"I am messed up\"-look, the \"I am angry\"-look and don't\nforget the \"awww I am totally like a cute puppy, are you girls feeling\nhawt already?\"-look and that's about it. And does he have a sense of nobleness or class? No. Does he\nhave a sense of danger or urgency? He keeps whining,\nthat he needs to blend in and stuff. Go ahead little\nfangirls get offended and rate me down for this, but this is PATHETIC.\nOh and if you want to make another crappy \"nerds and jocks and love in\nhigh school with odd girl and hawt boy\" its okay, fine by me, BUT don't\nLIE to me with a trailer like this movie had. I am sick and tired of these\nholly-jolly pink teenage love stories, please don't try to force them\ndown on my throat when I am promised to see a movie about aliens\nfighting for their lives.                 "reviewUseful": "42",

Especially the back and forth between the Thing and Human\nTorch but there is no team interaction in this film whatsoever. On top\nof that Sue Storm isn't even with the group when they get their powers!\nIn a time when technology is getting better and it's getting harder to\ntell when something is computer generated or not how does a blockbuster\nsuch as this get away with bad CG. Fant4stic could have addressed all\nof the previous complaints and would have still emerged as a pretty bad\nmovie; above everything else, the biggest problem with the film is its\nstory. Not just that it's poorly conceived and not fleshed out at all,\nbut that it's told in such a lazy, haphazard way. There's the usual\nprotracted pre-transformation set-up that's been mandatory since Batman\nBegins, which runs for the first half of the movie and falls flat\nthanks to the poorly written characters. Then bright lights happen,\npowers are given, heroes are captured and\u0085 we jump forward a year\ninexplicably. OK, so things are going to look at how they've changed in\nthat time, right? Nope. All of a sudden the third act motivation \u0096\nheralded by the return of Doom \u0096 appears out of nowhere and we're into\na rushed final sequence where the heroes' first attempt to stop the\ndestruction of Earth actually works. THE END. That's it. That is the\nmost measured way to present Fant4stic's narrative. I'd say it was\nwritten for an audience with a severely short attention span,\nconstantly mixing up the status quo just to make things appear vaguely\ninteresting, but the short run time suggests key development points\nwere actually edited out, leading to such incredibly choppy pacing.\nAgain \u0096 an explanation, not an excuse. Fant4stic is barely a movie.\nIt's a bunch of vaguely connected moments cobbled together to 100\nminutes so it can qualify for a cinematic release; the idea there's a\ncoherent narrative with a flowing story between its vaguely defined\nbeginning and end is so contentious it's insulting.\n"

It plays off of\nevery single action movie clich\u00e9 perfectly, without skipping a beat it\ngoes from clich\u00e9 to clich\u00e9 brilliantly. I love this movie and it will\nalways be one of the greatest ever made.\n"

I never liked the candy\ncoloured tone of the first one, admitting that its sequel was better. I\nprefer the darker and more serious tone of this one. I also liked a lot\nthat the movie took its time to develop the character, making them more\ncomplex and believable - even if this has the word: \"sequel\" written\nall over it. Especially Victor van Doom who is not the smug, arrogant\nand selfish villain, but a good guy who has been betrayed and now tries\nto protect his new world, even if this means the destruction of his old\none. So to sum things up: I believe anyone who claims the movie does\nnot do justice to its origin. However regarded as an action film on its\nown it has everything I want: good effects, good acting, believable but\nslightly broken characters and an interesting story even if it stays\nopen ended.\n"

But on\nthe other hand I like the darker look of the film and the\ncinematography was pretty good. Most of the VFX shots are pretty decent\n(apart from aforementioned ones) and the acting is fine (if you think\nthat was bad acting - see Cyborg). Another comment people have is that\nthe whole movie is exposition. What they mean is that there is actually\nto much talking and not enough wall-to-wall action but it helped the\ncharacters and I didn't find it a problem at all. After they get their\npowers they feel a bit like freaks and in the real world that would be\nthe case. You wouldn't go off playing a hero right out of the gate. I\nhave to say I enjoyed the movie and it does serve (or was intended as)\na bit as a setup for future sequels but it also works as a stand alone\nfilm.                 "reviewAuthor": "Isaiah Wilson",
                "reviewDate": "1 February 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Now This Is Some High Quality Crap!!!!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nIt is almost impossible to imagine that in 2015, as movie audiences\nexperience the golden age of superhero movies that there can still be\ncrap like this. Somehow, someway Fant4stic reaches into the depths of\nawful superhero movies, and takes the crown for being one of the worst\nsuperhero movies of all time. Lets start with the lack of story or even\na simple plot. For starters, we really aren't even introduced to some\nresemblance of a plot until an hour into the movie, and even then the\nplot essentially boils down to Doom sucking a hole out of the earth to\nsomehow build his own planet, which is completely bare. Considering\nthat synopsis, I think it is almost safe to say that this movie doesn't\neven have a plot (or one that at least makes sense). OK so the movie\ndoesn't have a \"genuine\" plot, that been the case with some other\nsuperhero movies. It should at least have some cool action scenes or\nprovide some worthwhile visuals. Nope! I honestly can only recall maybe\nfive minutes of some actual \"action\"' and even that was happening, it\nwas absolute crap. There were multiple opportunities throughout the\nfilm to showcase their powers, especially in the scene with Reed\nRichards and Ben Grimm, but instead, all we are left with is crappy\none-liners. Even in the last 10 minutes when we get the big battle, it\nends up being a boring, uneventful, clich\u00e9, and yes crappy letdown. So\nwe've got no story, no action, no villain (I won't even waste my time\nwith Dr. Dumb), how about some witty dialogue or a couple of humorous\nscenes. Wrong again. In its attempt to be the Dark Knight of FOX\nsuperhero movies, Fant4stic is stripped of all the humor and campiness\nthat at least made the earlier Fantastic Four movies watchable.\nInstead, we get a dark and surprisingly depressing film that doesn't\nevoke any sense of emotion from the viewer except for boredom. The\njokes are laughable (except there not) and just about all the\ninteraction between characters feels forced and inauthentic. OK. So by\nnow you get the idea. Fant4stic is an absolute crap-shoot of a movie. A\nmovie void of a plot, action, and OK dialogue doesn't even deserve to\nbe called by its name, hence the Fant4stic's. It makes the earlier\nFantastic Four movies look like The Avengers, and in the end, serves as\nan embarrassment to anyone associated with the film. And if you were\nwondering, yes, it is even worse than Batman & Robin. :0\n"
            },
            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Chase Bangerter",
                "reviewDate": "25 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "A Movie That Starts Out Promising, But Progressively Got Worse As It Goes On",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nStrangely enough, this is the fourth movie of the ill-fated franchise\nthat is simply known as the Fantastic Four. The one that came out\nduring the 2000's is one of my least favorite super hero movies I've\neven seen. I will say that while the new one is an improvement, it's\nnot saying that much. Fantastic Four is an origin story of our lead\nheroes as they try to do some interdimensional traveling and they get\nsuperpowers from the result of it. I will give it this, in the first\nhalf of the movie, I was actually pretty invested in the story. I\nespecially liked Miles Teller and Michael B. Jordan's characters as\nReed Richards and Johnny Storm. There is some intrigue about the\ncharacters and what's going on with them. There are some things in the\nbeginning that I felt could be done better (Sue Storm came off just a\nlittle bit weird), but overall, I thought it was pretty good. While the\nfirst half I don't have too many problems with, it's the second half\nthat I feel that the movie just deconstructed itself into nothing. It\nkind of shocked me that when I think about what happens in the middle\nof the movie, do I realize that almost nothing happens. I mean, there\nare some concepts in the second half that sounds interesting, but\nbecause of the way that it told its story, it felt like the filmmakers\nwasn't really trying. It just feel bland, generic, and nothing of\ninterest really happen. It doesn't really help that the climax of the\nmovie is one of the most boring climaxes I think I've ever seen in a\nlong while. it just doesn't felt like that there's anything at stake is\ngoing on. The action is about as underwhelming that you could possibly\nimagine and the effects were cheaply made. It also doesn't help that\nDr. Doom was wearing one of the worst costumes I've seen in recent\nmemories. So in the end, the last twenty minutes of the movie was\nterrible but it's hard for me to damn the whole movie just because of\nthe last half. Like I said, I think the first half was actually pretty\ngood but it felt like that the people behind it just gave up in the\nsecond half and considering the production problems that it had, I\ncould easily see why. Overall, while I do think it's not a good\nsuperhero movie, I don't think it's one of the worst. There's not much\nto recommend unless if you're curious about the movie but, overall,\nit's definitely worth the skip.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "nepalimac",
                "reviewDate": "5 June 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Better than the reviews will have you believe.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "25",
                "reviewUseful": "13",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nA little bit of context is in order for this review. I had heard tons\nof reviews for this film before I saw it in the theater. People had\ncontinuously mentioned plot errors and complaints about the CGI. I went\ninto this film expecting it to be mediocre at best. But I grossly\nmisinformed about this film. Director Brad Bird has blown me away once\nagain. Maybe I have such a high regard for this film because I expected\nit to be worse but I still stand by my opinion. So I would like to\ndiscuss things about the movie in both a Spoiler-free and spoiler\nfilled segments. SPOILER FREE: The film is incredibly stunning in\nregards to the camera work. There is a long shot near the beginning of\nthe movie that was done spectacularly. The acting is phenomenal.\nClooney steps away from his Suave type-casting and plays a grumpy old\nman in a great, great way. The main actress is perfect for the role.\nHer sass, optimism, and overall presence on screen is captivating. For\na film that has its plot based on a theme park ride, it dawns a script\nthat creates interesting,human characters along with a narrative that\nfeels fluid and realistic (as realistic as a kid's sci-fi movie can\nbe). SPOILER ZONE: Most of this has to do with the complaints. Many\nwere irritated at the villain's motivation. They said he didn't seem\nlike much of a bad guy at all. If anything he was misunderstood. I\nagree and disagree with this statement. Yes, he was very misunderstood.\nBut in context, how could a super genius who was given charge of\ncreating this world be anything but misunderstood? It would seem\nludicrous for someone of that position to be a complete psycho that has\nno motivation to do what he does. His writing makes sense in context\nand although that loses some of his villainy, it makes the story more\nwell rounded. Complaints about the CGI have come from the same type of\ncritics: people who prefer practical effects. Yes, practical is\nsuperior in many ways, but that does not mean CGI in today's film\nindustry cannot be astounding like it is in this film. Nothing feels\nfake, only futuristic and glimmering. Some people confuse this with\nunrealistic. Again, the long shot used in the film utilizes many\nartificial moments that are still breathtaking and fun. (And to the\nreviewer who said Mad Max had better effects because of its reliance on\npractical over CGI, I recommend they re-watch the Sand storm scene in\nthat film and tell me the CGI on that didn't make the movie a whole lot\nbetter). Lastly, people who were confused as to the premise of the\nfilm. Why would all the world's best and brightest be brought to a\nplace away from the world where they are needed? This is a good point.\nOne that I find difficult to argue. The point given in the movie is\nthat they are surrounded by pessimists who hold the \"dreamers\" back\nfrom their true potential. It's not much of an explanation and the\naudience is just left to deal with the fact that this movie was based\noff a Disneyland ride. This is partially why i gave this film only 9\nstars. END OF SPOILERS Everyone is entitled to their own opinions. And\nthis movie is no exception. Some people hate the movie because it\nstretched the definition of a PG rating (If you're worried, then see it\nwith your kid like the rating suggests). Some practical junkies are\nstill furious because the jet packs in the film weren't puppets on\nstrings. What they fail to notice is that this film is a humorous,\nwell- acted, well photographed film that deserves to be watched.\nThere's so much to this film that is enjoyable that it can't be\nignored. Sure, it's not perfect. No film is, or ever will be. But the\nnormal lover of movies knows that films aren't about being perfect but\nabout having a good time watching. My opinion of this movie is that it\ndeserves 9/10 stars. Sorry for the long post, but thanks for reading :)\n"
            },

But\nreally Brad Bird just wants people to get excited about the future\nagain, which I agree is something we should be doing. But people\ninstead say this movie is preachy and boring and sloppy and just rip\napart Bird's goal for this movie. I honestly think this movie is a\ngreat culmination of good storytelling and a good old ending that'll\nleave you inspired for the future... Or if your not me hating this\nmovie to death.                 "reviews": "\nIt's rare for a big movie studio to trust the future of a potential\nblockbuster franchise to a brand-new director. You'd imagine that there\nwould be just too much at stake when it came to translating James\nDashner's series of best-selling dystopian novels to the silver screen.\nBut it's easy to see why Wes Ball got the job - with this one film, he\ngraduates from short films to blockbuster movies with flair to spare.\nIndeed, The Maze Runner is such a cool, confident and thrilling blend\nof action beats and character work that it's hard to believe Ball has\nnever before commandeered a full- length feature film. It's true that\nthe narrative gets a little away from him by the end, making less sense\nas more secrets are revealed. He arrives at a primitive culture called The Glade with\nteenagers and boys, surrounded by huge walls, and he is welcomed by the\nleader Alby (Aml Ameen) that explains that his memory will return in a\ncouple of days. Alby tells that all of them have passed by the same\nprocess and now they survive working in their own agriculture plus the\nsupplies provided by the elevator once a month. Further, a new boy is\nalways brought in the elevator. When Alby is stung by a Griver,\nhe brings him back to the community. He is bullied by the strong Gally\n(Will Poulter) and they fight. He hits his head on the floor and\nrecalls his name, Thomas. Thomas decides to use one syringe\nin Alby and he recovers. However that night the breach on the wall is\nnot closed and The Grivers invade The Glade killing the boys. Will\nThomas and his friends survive? Will they find a way out from The\nGlade? Who is keeping them in that place?"

Well let him fight for three minutes, say some cheesy lines \r\nand then die.\" And Lucas or Hayden, you made me believe Anakin killing \r\nDooku would be the first step on his path towards the dark side. That \r\nhe would be torn apart by agony of his action and the inevitable \r\nsatisfaction of letting go of his hate. None of this happens. Anakin \r\nsays something like \"Oh perhaps I shouldn't have killed him lalalala, \r\nwell, well, nobody's perfect\". So Dooku is dead. But hold on we've got \r\nanother villain, General Grievous. Darth Maul was underused. It's even \r\nworse with Grievous only he's not cool. The idea of the mix between \r\ndroid and alien is great, however nothing of this is revealed. Grievous \r\nis just another stupid villain. And the actor that provided his voice \r\nfor him should seriously think about changing professional.\r\n\r\n\"Sh*t, I've already spent like 20 minutes of the film; I really need to \r\nmake Anakin evil now.\" So we see some more wannabe-sound-of-music love \r\nscenes where poor, poor Natalie Portman yet again has to fight against \r\nlines and dialog that is absolutely horrible. I pity her, she must \r\ncurse the day she signed on Star Wars. Not your fault Natalie, we know \r\nthe truth. Yes, Anakin has more nightmares and yes, it is shown in the \r\nsame bad way as the last time. And yes, the Jedi council that never \r\nseem to do anything useful, just sit and watch and do nothing (no \r\nwonder you all will die) appears in a few scenes.\r\n\r\n\"Oh my, I need to make Palpatine subtly persuade Anakin of the pleasure \r\nof the dark side. Should we say like 2 scenes are enough?\" Basically \r\nit's just \"Anakin join the Dark Side!\" \"No.\" \"Yes do it.\" \"No.\" \"Yes \r\ncome on now.\" \"Okay.\" No wonder you could not persuade Luke.\r\n\r\n\"Aah I still have to kill Grievous. Well, well more time for my lovely \r\nfellows of the ILM to show their skills.\" Let me say that Grievous dies \r\neasier than Maul did and have even less screen time. Rubbish\r\n\r\nNOW COMES WHAT BUGGERS ME THE MOST Finally after about 2 minutes of \r\npersuading Anakin, Palpatine reveals himself to be the Sith Lord. \r\nAnakin's life is shattered, everything he believed was in fact a lie. \r\nThis is dramatic, this is the purest betrayal. How does he respond? \r\nSomething like \"Oh really, hmm, I suppose I'd better alert the council\" \r\nEither Hayden is the worst actor or Lucas the worst director. Poor \r\nSidious, I reckon he wanted a better reaction than that. And when \r\nAnakin tells Windu about it, Windu who has dedicated his life to the \r\nRepublic and to destroy the Sith? \"Palpatine's a Sith Lord, damn, well, \r\nwell, I think we need to catch him, you reckon it can be done before \r\nlunch break?\" Yoda was humiliated to a mere action figure in AOTC. Here \r\nPalpatine gets the same punishment. The death of Windu is kind of cool \r\nthough (thanks Jackson for at least making Lucas fulfill our wishes \r\nconcerning that scenes)\r\n\r\nAnakin helps Palpatine kill Windu. How does he react? \"What have I \r\ndone? I'll do anything you want (to Palpatine)\" Yes that really does \r\nmake sense. Anakin you may have a high level of midi-chlorians (yes \r\nthey are mentioned) but your IQ-level is about zero. \"I fight for peace \r\nand justice and in order to achieve those I have to kill a bunch of \r\ninnocent children.\" Are you playing stupid games with me or something \r\nLucas? Which person would think that way? It is not logical, it's \r\npathetic. Every single scene with Anakin is in some way illogical.\r\n\r\nIn the end we have the Fight. With mystical dialog and with a tense of \r\nbroken friendship and love? No we get \"fast-forward\" 10 minutes of a \r\nblue blurring light. And yes cuts from when the emperor throws chairs \r\nat Yoda. You read it right.\r\n\r\nPoor Natalie is made to say her final cheesy lines and is then allowed \r\nto die. \r\n\r\nDarth Vader is awoken; he really doesn't seem to care about anything \r\nsave that he screams \"no\" that is a parody of the \r\nscreams-of-no's-movie-history.\r\n\r\nThe End\r\n\r\nThe dream is dead.\r\n\r\nLucas failed us fans, for him showing a 2\u00bd hour commercial of how great \r\nhe can make special effects were more important than conveying a \r\npowerful story.\r\n\r\nOn the night bus home a man clad in Jedi robes wept. We all felt like \r\nit.\r\n\r\nThis movie could have been everything we could have asked for. In hands \r\nof a better director, with corrections by a real writer, this could \r\nhave been a new TESB. Now we were watching a fallen hero. Not Anakin. \r\nLucas.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "parliamentmatt",
                "reviewDate": "20 May 2005",
                "reviewTitle": "Lucas has done it again folks!!!!!!!!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "145",
                "reviewUseful": "91",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nTo preface this little review, I used to be up until a day or so ago a\nfirm believer in George Lucas, not only his movie making ability, but\nalso his ability to redeem what has been an abysmal trilogy. I used to\nbe one of those fan boys who just couldn't admit that anything was\nwrong with the prequels, I remember walking out of episode one thinking\nthat it was a great flick, but have over time become aware that the\nprequels have been nothing but a total letdown... But to be honest I\nwas really looking forward to seeing Episode Three, not only because I\nhad read that a lot of you out there actually thought this movie was\ngood, not only that but it made up for the first two prequels, and even\neclipsed a few of the originals. A day after seeing Episode Three the\nonly thing i can say is that George Lucas fumbled the ball, and let not\nonly the star wars crowd down, but the movie watching public in\ngeneral. It was sloppy, forced, and the acting apart from McDiarmid,\nand McGreggor was just lousy. What I thought was going to be an\nexplanation of how Anakin Skywalker turned to the dark side, became an\nalmost agonizing countdown to the credits. Now before I bash the whole\nmovie to pieces, I will say that there were some parts of the movie I\nthought were great. The special affects, as always were great, the as\nsaid before there were a couple of good performances, and thats about\nit. Now for the bad, my first real gripe with this movie is how awful,\nand stilted the acting was. Portman, Christiansin, Christopher Lee,\nthose annoying Neimoidians and even the baddest man on the planet Sam\nJackson sounded like amateurs. this is surprising to me, because even\nthe worst one of them all Hayden Christiansin isn't that bad of an\nactor. I blame this mostly on Lucas' inability to write believable, and\neven tolerable dialog at all. Even the original Star Wars movies had\nthe same problem, but the actors pulled it off. This wouldn't be a\nproblem if it was only a small fraction of the movie, but for every\ncool, or good line, the audience had to sit through a bunch of crap\nthat just pulled the viewer out. My main gripe in this is the\nAnakin/Padme love story, and the hideous \"NOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO,\" that Vader\nutters near the end of the picture. Whether or not that was a homage to\nFrankenstein or not, that is something that should have never made it\ninto the flick. And what the heck was with Vaders voice when he got\ninto the suit. Props to Lucas for bringing back James Earl Jones, but\nwhy all the enunciation, did Vader develop an accent a few years after\nhe got the suit?? Another problem I had is that throughout both of the\ntrilogies, viewers are told what great warriors Jedi are, how all\npowerful they are, and how their use of the force helps them to sense\nthings before they happen. If this is the case then why is it that\nafter Palpatine passes his law, something 66, are the Jedi so easily\ndispatched. I can understand the little Padawan's being slaughtered,\nbut Ki Adi Mundi getting shot by clones without even a fight at\nall....thats just weak. The Jedi Purge is something that I thought\nwould make this movie great, instead its just a five minute montage of\nthe so-called greatest warriors in the universe getting pounded like\nPeter McNeely. My last huge problem is...Grievous. Why they even\ncreated him in the first place I cant figure out. He didn't do anything\nexcept cough, and spout out cheesy one liners for his short stint in\nthe movie, and then even though he's slaughtered countless Jedi, and\nhas been semi-trained in Jedi Fighting styles by Count Dooku, is man\nhandled by obi wan, like any of the other machines. Even his body\nguards gave obi wan a better fight then grievous did. This was very\ndisappointing to me, only because I was a big fan of the clone wars\ncartoon, and that made grievous look like a total bad a$$. Another\nproblem i had with grievous is the abysmal voice acting of whatever\nhobo they pulled off of the street to to the voice work. At one point\nLucas had Gary Oldman on to do his voice...what was Lucas thinking. One\nother small knit pick, Why was Chewbacca even in the movie, matter of\nfact why was that whole Wookie battle in it, it served no purpose other\nthat to make fan-boys soil themselves. I know this is going to just\npi$$ off every star wars fan that frequents this site. But to all of\nyou fan-boys I pose one question. If its possible for you, go see the\nmovie and just treat it like any other movie. If it didn't have the\nwords Star Wars in the title would any of you even like it?? To me this\nis just another missed opportunity for Mr. Lucas, and quite frankly\nproof that good old George is becoming nothing less than a self\nabsorbed HACK. I love the original Star Wars just as much as any fan\nboy out there...i used to be one of you guys!!! But after last night,\nand after Lord of the Rings Star Wars, just doesn't stack up. And if\nGeorge is reading this.... Mr. Lucas read a book, or better yet watch a\nQuentin Tarantino movie, maybe that will help you to write dialog...and\nfor anyone who still hasn't seen this piece of garbage, wait for the\nDVD, or better yet that special, special edition of the prequels that\nLucas will no doubt give us to squeeze the piggy bank. So...to close\nout props to Ewan McGreggor, Ian McDiarmid, and the people at ILM,\nbesides that for shame George.\n"

                "reviewTitle": "Not really worth a rental, but it wouldn't be a awful rental",
                "reviewTotalVote": "2",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nAlthough it ain't saying much but the 2007 version is better than this\none. And it's not only because you get to see Olga Kurylenko topless\neither. It seemed like they actually put some effort into the 2007\nversion of \"Hitman\" the movie. This one just seemed like a cheap\nattempt. Just about every potential in this movie is wasted, such as\nZachary Quinto. The whole thing suffers from Paul W. S. Anderson's\ndirection when it comes to video game to movie form. Except it doesn't\nstray that far from the source material. Audiences that doesn't know\nabout \"Hitman\" video games will find this movie odd for negative\nreasons. And the gamers that know about this video game franchise will\nbe left disappointed. Because the actor that plays Agent 47 does not\nresemble 47 besides the shaved head. And the way Agent 47 does things\nin the video game is very very different. Kind of like how Paul W. S.\nAnderson took a survival horror game into a straight up kung-fu action\nmovie with bullet time and people pulling off \"The Matrix\" maneuvers.\nWatching this was like watching a crappy version of \"The Terminator\".\nOn a positive note, maybe it's because this movie is just 1 hour and 30\nminutes but the characters weren't really annoying but they are still\neasily forgettable. The hand to hand fight choreography was choppy but\nalright as well. However I was just checking my watch throughout this\nwhole mess of a film, even though I try to give it a shot and see the\npositive aspects of it. I have just seen way way better action movies\nover this one. The whole premise and direction is lame and for a movie\nthat actually made it to theaters, the CGI in this is really bad.\nEspecially for a movie that made it to theaters in 2015. It's not\nreally worth a rental, but it wouldn't be a awful rental."

                "reviews": "\nNo, I've never played any of the many versions of the \"Hitman\" video\ngames that either Eidos Interactive or Eidos Interactive or Square Enix\nhave marketed since 2000. The first cinematic adaptation of the stealth\nvideo game series about a genetically-engineered, skin-headed assassin\nwith a bar code stamped on the back of his head and designated as Agent\n47 appeared in 2007 with \"Justified\" star Timothy Olyphant. Sources\nindicate that the $25-million budgeted actioneer raked in about\n$150-million at the box office. Mind you, Hollywood has produced\nsequels from less successful originals so it seems mysterious that\nTwentieth Century Fox has stalled a sequel for so long. Actually, I\nthought director Xavier Gens's fast-paced but formulaic \"Hitman\"\nqualified as bottom-of-the-barrel abysmal. Despite its strong cast and\nslick production values, the unrated DVD/Blu-ray \"Hitman\" release has\ndone nothing to alter my sentiments. Consequently, I approached\ndirector Aleksander Bach's sequel \"Hitman: Agent 47\" with dread.\nReportedly, \"Fast and Furious\" star Paul Walker had been attached to\nstar in this shoot'em up saga before he died in a fiery car crash.\nBritish thespian Rupert Friend of \"Homeland\" fame takes over the role\nfrom Timothy Olyphant. Friend adopts the skin-head look and delivers a\nperformance every bit as imperturbable as Olyphant. Surprisingly\nenough, however, \"Hitman: Agent 47\" turned out a 100 times better than\nits lackluster predecessor. As far as pistol-packing suspense thrillers\ngo, \"Hitman: Agent 47\" (**** OUT OF ****) ranks as one of the\npreeminent summer actioneers. I found myself entirely caught off guard\nby this sensational shoot'em up. Stunning Berlin and Singapore scenery,\nspontaneous combat sequences, a double-digit body count, and story\nsurprises galore distinguish this lean, mean, 97 minute, R-rated,\nbullet-riddled bloodbath about a daughter searching for her long-lost\nfather. Granted, movies about cloned, super-assassins have become a\ndime-a-dozen, but \"Hitman: Agent 47\" looms above all others with its\nimaginative Skip Woods and Michael Finch script and Bach's ambitiously,\noutlandish showdowns. If you love stimulating action movies, you'll\nappreciate this gripping movie that co-stars Ciar\u00e1n Hinds, Thomas\nKretschmann, Zachary Quinto, and J\u00fcrgen Prochnow.\n"
