            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Alex Vasquez",
                "reviewDate": "16 April 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "LA Review of 'The Avengers' (No spoilers)",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1011",
                "reviewUseful": "597",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nI'm sorry to say The Avengers isn't a good movie; it's a GREAT \r\nMOVIE!!!! It's not only the best team superhero movie ever made, but it \r\nmay just be the best comic book adaption made period!\r\n\r\nThe Avengers is the culmination of what began in Iron Man; and \r\ncontinued through The Incredible Hulk, Iron Man 2, Thor and Captain \r\nAmerica. It was only a few years ago that my son and I had just \r\nfinished watching Iron Man and as the credits were ending, Samuel L. \r\nJackson appeared on screen as Nick Fury and spoke to Tony Stark about \r\njoining Avengers Initiative\u0085in that short scene, the framework for \r\npotentially the greatest comic book movie of all-time had begun! \r\n\r\nDirector Joss Whedon, most known for the T.V. series Buffy The Vampire \r\nSlayer, takes the foundation that was built in the prior films and \r\nbrings together the greatest team of superheroes in film history, The \r\nAvengers: Iron Man/Tony Stark (Robert Downey Jr.), Captain \r\nAmerica/Steve Rogers (Chris Evans), Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Hulk/Bruce \r\nBanner (Mark Ruffalo), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson), and Hawkeye \r\n(Jeremy Renner) as \"assembled\" by Nick Fury. Whedon's scripts usually \r\ninclude clever banter, gripping action sequences and an air of mystery \r\nand The Avengers is no different. Whedon has an utter love for comic \r\nbooks, and it is proudly put on display in The Avengers.\r\n\r\nThe cast does a great job of bringing these iconic characters to life, \r\nbeginning with Robert Downey Jr. Unlike Iron Man 2, in which Downey \r\nseemed to skate through scene after scene, Downey plays Stark almost \r\neffortlessly, delivering his lines with relative ease allowing his \r\ncharisma, charm and smugness to shine through; Robert Downey Jr. IS \r\nTony Stark! Chris Evans' solidifies himself in the role of Captain \r\nAmerica. He was very good in his solo film, but truly owns the role \r\nstanding alongside Iron Man and Thor. Chris Hemsworth's Asgardian god \r\nThor has some incredible battle scenes and indirectly provides one of \r\nthe film's most funny moments. After being seriously underutilized in \r\nIron Man 2, Scarlett Johansson's Black Widow is provided a back-story, \r\nwhich helps in developing the character and provides an opportunity to \r\nprove she is much more than just a pretty face; she's as dangerous \r\npsychologically as she is physically. I could envision myself enjoying \r\na beat-down at the hands (and feet) of Black Widow. The character I was \r\nmost concerned about being given little story and the least amount of \r\nscreen time was Jeremy Renner's Hawkeye; happily, he's not left by the \r\nwayside and does a more than admirable job of developing the character. \r\nHawkeye stands alongside Robin Hood and Katniss Everdene (The Hunger \r\nGames) as the best archers to grace the silver screen. I'd like to see \r\nmore of him in a film of his own. Mark Ruffalo, the most recent choice \r\nto play Hulk, is far better suited to the role than Eric Bana (The \r\nHulk) and Ed Norton Jr (The Incredible Hulk). Ruffalo looks more the \r\npart of the nerdy scientist Banner and plays the part without looking \r\nangry in every scene. In The Avengers, the Hulk is at his most \r\nimpressive, both in his on-screen transformation and the violence he \r\ndisplays when the opportunity calls for him to \"hulk out\". If any \r\ncharacter appeared to stand out a little bit more than the others, for \r\nme it was the Hulk. Samuel L. Jackson's Nick Fury is finally more than \r\njust the guy making surprise appearances. Fury is finally able to \r\nstretch his legs some, and Jackson slides quite easily into the role. \r\nClark Gregg's Agent Caulson returns, and Cobie Smulders makes her \r\nMarvel films debut as Agent Maria Hill, and she is a welcome addition. \r\nThe film's main villain is Thor's adopted-brother Loki, played by Tom \r\nHiddleston. You would think the part would be a difficult one to play \r\nbeing opposite such powerful personalities and strong characters, but \r\nHiddleston does a fantastic job; the performance should not go \r\nunnoticed, because it's one of the strong points of the film. Loki is \r\nnot a villain without purpose and Hiddleston comes across as a devious \r\nmastermind without being cartoonish.\r\n\r\nAt a running-time of 2+ hours, The Avengers is well paced and time \r\nflies by. The effects are top-notch, the acting is very good, and the \r\nscript drives the movie elevating its strengths. For viewers that may \r\nnot have seen any of the other films (and if so, why not!?!?), we're \r\nprovided just enough information to bring everyone up to speed without \r\nfeeling overdone. Whedon provides more than just a standard comic book \r\nfilm, but a story with reason that's backed up with incredible action \r\nand humor. \r\n\r\nAlthough the film is filled with larger than life characters, none are \r\nshort changed; each character is given at least one great scene to work \r\nwith, and the opportunities don't go to waste. The film's finale \r\nprovides a deafening crescendo of action that is breathtaking. As usual \r\nwith Marvel films, be sure to stay around for the post credit sequence, \r\nwhich provides a surprising reveal.\r\n\r\nI went into The Avengers with unfairly high expectations, due to all of \r\nthose that were involved, as well as the films that came before it. \r\nAfter viewing the initial trailers and not being blown away, I had set \r\nmyself up for disappointment. It was only a matter of minutes after the \r\nfilm started that I was put at ease, and just minutes later when my \r\nexpectations were blown away. I never imagined that it was possible to \r\nput onto the screen, what I was watching. I'm happy that Marvel had the \r\nsense to keep these properties to themselves and to move forward with \r\nthese characters in the manner in which they did. Marvel Studios and \r\nDisney are going to make a boatload of money off this film, and \r\ndeservedly so; because there's never been another movie made of its \r\ncaliber.\r\n\r\nGrade: A+\r\n\r\n\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "cidliq",
                "reviewDate": "6 July 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "Solid fun movie",
                "reviewTotalVote": "47",
                "reviewUseful": "25",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nAs you well know by now, \"The Avengers\" is a large-scale superhero film\nthat was four years in the making, with no less than four individual -\nyet inter-connected superhero films - feeding into this film's overall\nstory. Joss \"Firefly\" Whedon was the director and co-writer on this\nhighly ambitious project that is an adaptation of the Marvel Comics\nsuperhero team co-created by Stan Lee (who also appears in a very small\ncameo, like almost every other movie adaptation of a superhero he had a\nhand in creating) and the late Jack Kirby. Steve Rogers/Captain America\n(Chris Evans), Tony Stark/Iron Man (Robert Downey, Jr.), Bruce\nBanner/The Incredible Hulk (Mark Ruffalo), Thor (Chris Hemsworth),\nNatasha Romanoff/The Black Widow (Scarlet Johansson), and Clint\nBarton/Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner) are the six misfits chosen by Nick Fury,\nAgent of S.H.I.E.L.D. (Samuel L. Jackson) to defeat the traitorous\nAsgardian misfit Loki (Tom Hiddleston) and his alien army from laying\nwaste to New York City. And of course, six characters usually\naccustomed to working alone have to work out their differences and come\ntogether as a team to save the world. What gets \"The Avengers\" many\npoints is that beside its big action sequences, fights and special\neffects, we never really lose sight of the characters (who are usually\nrelegated to the background in a movie like this) and who they are. I\nliked that the movie actually spent time developing the individual\ncharacters so that we get to know them all over again - even though\nthey've all already appeared in previous superhero films. It's all big\nsuperhero fun, with a knowing wink and an outstanding sense of humor\nthat manages to elicit some strong laughs from anyone viewing this\nthing with an open mind. Sit back and enjoy!"

Although it's impossible for\nthe San Andreas fault line to produce an earthquake more than 8.3, at\nleast it makes for a wonderfully heart-pumping movie. One earthquake\nstrikes after another, and then a tsunami, and by the end, San\nFrancisco is so demolished it looks impossible to rebuild it, but, of\ncourse, some people were still somehow able to survive. The movie was\nso unbelievably intense I thought I was going to have heart\npalpitations at some points. Although I have never been a big fan of\nDwayne Johnson, Carla Gugino, or Alexandra Daddario, they all perform\nwell here; director Brad Peyton and Dwayne Johnson have created a much\nbetter movie than the Journey movies."

                "reviews": "\nBefore watching Brad Peyton's \"San Andreas\" (2015), I expected to\nwitness all heck breaking loose in California and Nevada as the\nearthquake ravaged the west coast. I did not however, expect a love\nstory in the mix of events. Now, I must say, if you're expecting a\nchick flick, this isn't the movie you're looking for. Ray (Dwayne\nJohnson) known for his roles in Fast and Furious 6 and 7 as well as\nG.I. Joe, plays the role as a fire and rescue-chopper pilot divorced by\nhis ex wife Emma (Carla Gugino). The divorced couple travels across the\nstate of California in search of their daughter Blake (Alexandra\nDaddario) after Emma's boyfriend Daniel Riddick (Ioan Gruffudd)\nabandons her. Meanwhile, Blake tries to find her parents alongside two\nBritish acquaintances Ben (Hugo Johnstone-Burt) and his brother Ollie\n(Art Parkinson) that she met that day. At several parts of the film,\nthe action and realistic perspective leaves you breathless. The film\nmakers did an amazing job at bringing you into the action of the real\nevent of the earthquake that occurred. The film itself is best enjoyed\nby those with an interest in intense dramatic action and those with a\nlove of movies based off of real events. Steven Rea; The Inquirer\nstates \"San Andreas is awesome fun. Director Brad Peyton and his army\nof visual effects and digital artists have created a temblor tableau of\nwreckage in motion.\" Entertainment Weekly's Jeff Labreque claims that\n\"It seems familiar , lacks depth or perspective, and isn't based in\nscience.\" While this is in some ways true, Labreque misses the point.\nIf every movie was 100% accurate, the intended audience population as a\nwhole, would be a lot less.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "Robert W. (Robert_duder@hotmail.com)",
                "reviewDate": "27 June 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Rip roaringly entertaining, a disaster masterpiece",
                "reviewTotalVote": "52",
                "reviewUseful": "27",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nAnother reviewer on IMDb gave this a 10/10 and they said that this was\nall the best parts of every disaster movie you've ever seen. That's not\ntoo far from the truth. It has been a long, long, LONG time since we\nhave had a terrific disaster flick. Nowadays its all about the special\neffects and it becomes so ridiculous that you lose sight of what made\ndisaster movies so great. San Andreas still goes for the jugular of\nmodern day special effects but it also goes back to the disaster roots\nand uses all the familiar recipe ingredients to ensure this is\nferociously enjoyable and it is!! It will never win Oscars (not\nincluding special effects) and its not some critical masterpiece but it\nis purely entertainment. It is the sort of popcorn, theatre flick that\nwe rarely see anymore. Its the type of movie that reminds you why we\nall fell in love with movies. I smiled, I cringed, I cried out loud, I\nteared up...it was remarkable. I could watch this again and again\nwithout hesitation. The characters might be typical and some of the\nscenes predictable but it has been so long since someone got the\ndisaster movie recipe right that I loved every minute of it. This is as\nmuch of an homage to the 70's Disaster era as it is a modern day\nspectacle of effects."

                "reviewUseful": "3",
                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nLet's honestly put our bias aside and look at this film not from a\nTerminator 1 fan or a franchise or comicon fan. Without a doubt, the\nproducers remained true to the franchise \u0096 much more so than they did\nin Terminator Salvation and this instalment is a very creative tie up\nand, I hope, ending to the saga. Being the fifth instalment, things\ncould have gone way bad by now with really bad production values,\nridiculous scripts and inappropriately cheesy lines. Instead Genisys\nstays true to the essence of the franchise, considers its cheesy\nmoments very carefully (I still here Pops saying \"I might be older, but\nI am not obsolete\") and gave us a really good tie up of events \u0096 even\nif the base idea was stolen from the Star Trek reboot. Let's compare it\nto many other franchises like Batman and Superman and Alien, which by\nmovie 4 really went off the rails \u0096 not even Uma Thurman could save\nthat script... A lot of reviews complain about Salvation (which I also\ndid not enjoy either) and Genysis (which I though was a good recover).\nThe film is filled with Easter Eggs of moments referencing other\npopular Arnold Schwarzenegger movies as well as the original three\nfilms. And to be honest\u0085this is Terminator we are talking about \u0096 we\nare not expecting the Bond flick. So the fact that the film is flawed\nfrom a critical point and often does not cover its own continuity aside\n\u0096 it does stick to the reality it created and the time-space\ndiscrepancies are easily forgiven. All in all it is well worth the\nmoney I spent on the movie and the popcorn, for the awesome use of\neffects, revisiting old favourite moments from the series and a story\nthat actually is not that bad \u0096 come one, I can hear someone saying\nthat it was a weak storyline\u0085.but I repeat\u0085this is Terminator we are\ntalking about\u0085\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "34",
                "reviewUseful": "18",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nRemember when \"Terminator\" was something special? Congrats, you must be\nover 30 years old. \"Terminator 3\" (2003) has already been a major\ndisappointment and the sequel \"Salvation\" (2009), while at least trying\nsomething new, was incredibly lifeless. \"Genisys\" picks up the\nnostalgic approach of \"T3\" again and turns soon into a parade of\nreferences to the seminal first two movies. But while in those the\nelement of time travel was just a storytelling twist that set up the\nmain plot, the latest sequel makes the mistake to turn it into the\nmajor propellant of the happenings on screen, so expect a lot of blah\nblah about alternate time lines, \"Nexus points\" (there is an exposition\nabout this nonsense, yawn) and whatnot, but it's just a ploy to cobble\ntogether variation of scenes we already know from the preceding films.\nWorst of all is the fact though that the film seems to feel very smart\nabout this approach, yet there is no inherent logic to all the time\ntravel stuff and the writers even had the balls to state that a lot of\nit will be explained in the sequel- which I hope never realizes. The\nacting is mostly rather bad. I have never seen \"Game of Thrones\", but\nEmilia Clarke did not impress me here with her shrill interpretation of\nSarah Connor. Jai Courtney is wooden as always and B-movie face Jason\nClarke must be the least intimidating Terminator on screen so far.\nArnold seems a little lost and his role is reduced to that of Mr.\nExposition and Dad Surrogate. The action is not very impressive either,\nit misses the inventiveness and precision of Cameron's direction. Some\nof the physics are just ludicrous, even for an action movie. Bad CGI\nreinforces the feeling that nothing is at stake, a feeling that is\nalready established by the fact that the time travel shenanigans opened\nthe door for all kinds of randomness.\n"

                "reviewTitle": "Garbage movie - designed to make money for Brad Pitt",
                "reviewTotalVote": "323",
                "reviewUseful": "237",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nThis film gave me a feeling of initial distaste, which rapidly grew to\nanger, and yes FURY, as the story line progressed. Compared to the\nmasterful 'Saving Private Ryan' this film was a prime example of how to\nmake a piece of garbage and, with a major star in the leading role and\ngood marketing, turn it into a box office winner. Where do I start?\nWell, the tank crew is a bunch of thugs who look as if they just came\nout of jail - yeah we saw it all before in the 'Dirty Dozen', the\n'Bridge at Remagen' and so on. But these guys had no redeeming features\nat all - just a bunch of psychopaths with guns. Even the Brad Pitt\nleading character took pleasure in killing enemy prisoners and\nencouraging the innocent young recruit to do likewise. Yes, these ugly\nincidents did happen in the war, and US soldiers were often guilty of\nsuch 'heat of the moment' atrocities, but they were exceptions, NOT the\nrule! And to make this behaviour seem normal is highly irresponsible,\nnot to say defamatory to the US Army. Then there is the perpetuation of\nthe old myth about the Waffen SS being cruel maniacs etc when in\nreality they were highly disciplined and effective soldiers who often\nbehaved more correctly than the Wehrmacht. The apex of stupidity came\nin the long climactic final scene in which the Pitt character and his\nthree colleagues kill hundreds of SS troopers with a single broken down\nSherman tank before finally being overwhelmed and killed - the naive\nyoung recruit being the only survivor. I could not believe what I was\nseeing. This is war for the video gaming generation, not for anyone who\nhas actually gone through this hellish experience. The Germans ran\naround like headless chickens and let themselves be mowed down by\nmachine gun fire like turkeys. This is so unbelievably moronic that it\nmakes one cringe with embarrassment. I felt I should have asked for a\nrefund after watching such crap. Awful.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "db-beurylaw",
                "reviewDate": "7 April 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Attack of the Nazi Zombies, oh brother",
                "reviewTotalVote": "8",
                "reviewUseful": "7",
                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nThere should be a second rating for truth and accuracy. I read an\narticle in the New York Times that praised this movie for being very\naccurate. The Times got it wrong and the film makers got it very, very\nwrong. Why is it so hard to make an accurate movie about World War II?\nMany of the participants are still alive and they are always very\noffended with filmmakers present nonsense, like this movie. First of\nall the film makers chose to have this story take place in April of\n1945, then they ignore the situation as it stood at that time. The war\nin Europe ended on May 7, 1945. The fact is that the five man crew of\nthis tank had to know that the war was almost over as they were\nfighting deep in Germany. At that time the Allies (US, Britain, USSR\net.al.) had more than twice as many soldiers and way more equipment\nthan the Germans. Most of the German army was trying to get to the West\nto surrender to the Americans because they knew that they would be\ntreated better than being captured by the Russians. In April alone 2.3\nmillion German soldiers surrendered. To watch this movie one would\nbelieve that the Germans outnumbered the Allies and outrageous acts of\nvalor were required. In fact, the allies were aware of the mass\nsurrenders and trying to minimize their casualties. It is true that the\nUS Department of war gave the armies inferior tanks. They chose to\nmanufacture Sherman tanks which had far less armor and artillery. It\nwas chosen because it was cheap and could be manufactured in greater\nnumbers and the allies had far more of these tanks. But the German\ntanks were better, that much is true. As a result the Allies attacked\nin mass formations. Not one loan tank. This brings us to the final\nclimatic scene. The five man tank crew are all alone in a broken down\ntank. There is battalion of about 250 Germans coming they're way. Pitt\ndecides to stay there and battle the 250 Germans alone. In a broken\ndown tank. In the last month of the war. His heroic (stupidity)\nattracts all four of his comrades who agree to a pointless fight to the\ndeath. The terrible part is that the Germans mindlessly walk into the\nTank's line of fire as if they were Zombies. Maybe they were left over\nextras from Pitt's last movie World War Z. Maybe Hitler was so\ndesperate for soldiers he enlisted the very old, the very young and\neven the recently undead. Anyway, even though the Germans co-operated\nin being slaughtered by the Americans they eventually overwhelm them.\nBut there is more: in the closing scene we see scores of dead Germans\nsurrounding the disabled tank. Notice that none of the dead Germans\nfell on the rough road. They all managed to die on the soft grass. I\nthought for a moment that the newly arrived troops moved the bodies off\nof the road, but they would have laid them in rows. This was not the\ncase. The Germans were lying about as they had fallen. Just not on that\nrough, dirty road!\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "trublu215",
                "reviewDate": "15 October 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "Fury captures the horrors of war perfectly",
                "reviewTotalVote": "473",
                "reviewUseful": "239",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nFury pits a tank filled with five American soldiers at the tail end of\nWorld War II as they struggle to fight off a small army of Nazi\nsoldiers that are closing in on them. David Ayer directs this brutal\nand grim war film with no romance to it. Ayer's film is grim, bloody\nand unrelenting and fully captures the absolutely horrific nature of\nwar. Brad Pitt's Wardaddy is far from Lt. Aldo Raine in Inglorious\nBasterds, he is a man who is truly run ragged by this war. So much so\nthat it is all the character knows. Followed by his brigade of\nmiserable men played by the likes of Michael Pe\u00f1a, Shia LaBeouf, Logan\nLerman and Jon Bernthal, Fury depicts not only the atrocities of war\nbut the ideology of brotherhood with this film. Each of these actors,\nespecially LaBeouf, give their all in roles that are merely supporting\non paper. Ayer has an extremely keen eye for chemistry on screen and he\ndirects each of these actors to deliver performances that are well\nbeyond anything that could be scripted. These men truly feel as if they\nare brothers in arms and you buy into every second of it. The film on a\ntechnical level is terrific. Ayer ditches his hand held method for\nstill shots and dolly rigs and it pays off ten fold. The film is\nvisually stunning, a pure grit to the desaturated frame is present from\nstart to finish. As I touched on before, Fury is a violent war film\nmuch so in the vein of Saving Private Ryan and Lone Survivor. You are\nsubjected to every bullet wound, every explosion of sharp shrapnel,\nevery wound with the utmost visceral imagery. It is disturbing yet\nnecessary for a film like this. Deapite these dark tones and brutality,\nFury does feature lighter moments especially with Logan Lerman who\ngives a seemingly bare-bones performance as Norman Ellison that is\nsubtle but extremely effective as he slowly becomes desensitized to all\nthe violence around him. His performance is constantly evolving along\nwith his character, letting us see layer after layer until he comes\nfull circle in a bloody final act. The best way to describe Fury is by\ncomparing it to Wolfgang Peterson's Das Boot just with a tank instead\nof a submarine. Its claustrophobic, up close and personal, making the\nscenes of harrowing violence even more effective. Overall, Fury is a\nbrutal war film that shows war exactly how it should be shown. Its\ndisturbing, its violent, its scary. Fury really hits a home run between\nthe sweeping cinematography, the phenomenal performances and the near\nperfect direction, it is one hell of a film that shouldn't be missed.\n"
            },

                "reviewAuthor": "Dominic LeRose",
                "reviewDate": "24 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Brad Pitt leads his team into his second round of Nazi ass-kicking.",

                "reviewUseful": "4",

The entire film features awesome war scenes with multiple\nexplosions and machine gun fires, but never does anything else. \"Fury\"\nis handled well by director David Ayer because he stays clear on what\nhis purpose is.             {
                "reviewAuthor": "Likes_Ninjas90",
                "reviewDate": "22 October 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "It's a film disturbingly unconcerned by psychology or battle scars but celebrating how many kills a single tank crew can score for their country",
                "reviewTotalVote": "66",
                "reviewUseful": "35",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nSet in the final year of the Second World War, Fury is the story of how\na young man enters combat and becomes a killing machine. How the film\nand its director David Ayer feel about the premise is ideologically\nconfused and contradictory. On one hand the film is a brutal\nrepresentation of the final tank battles of the war and how merciless\nthe Allies were to Germans and their prisoners as a way of saving their\nown hides. Yet the film's fascist politics are exemplified by showing\nhow young men become accepted into the brainless, macho brotherhood of\ntheir peers once they are capable of murdering enemies without\nhesitation. Some will dismiss the film as a silly boy's club adventure,\nbut this does little to dispel the unsavouriness. Fury's timing is as\nmisjudged as it is deliberate. In an era of contemporary global\nwarfare, it's a film disturbingly unconcerned by psychology or battle\nscars but celebrating how many kills a single tank crew can score for\ntheir country. "
            },

                "reviews": "\nThe Matrix\" is a visually dazzling cyberadventure, full of kinetic\nexcitement, but it retreats to formula just when it's getting\ninteresting. It's kind of a letdown when a movie begins by redefining\nthe nature of reality, and ends with a shoot-out. I've seen dozens if not hundreds of these exercises in\nviolence, which recycle the same tired ideas: Bad guys fire thousands\nof rounds, but are unable to hit the good guy. Then it's down to the\nfinal showdown between good and evil--a martial arts battle in which\nthe good guy gets pounded until he's almost dead, before he finds the\ninner will to fight back.             {
                "reviewAuthor": "William Yaku",
                "reviewDate": "19 April 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "A young man joins forces with a group of rebels to fight against The Matrix, the system that controls the world they live in.",
                "reviewTotalVote": 0,
                "reviewUseful": 0,
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nThe Matrix (1999): Dir: Andy Wachowski, Larry Wachowski / Cast: Keanu\nReeves, Carrie-Anne Moss, Laurence Fishburne, Joe Pantoliano, Hugo\nWeaving: Confusing film that assaults our senses with strange theories\nand exhilarating action sequences. Keanu Reeves is picked up by agents\nwho force a mechanical object in through his navel and he awakens in\nhis own bed. Laurence Fishburne informs him that the Matrix is\neverything around him. It is destined to keep people under control.\nReeves is presented with two pills. One will allow him to awaken\nwithout memory of the incident, and the other one allows him to\ndiscover whether or not he is the Missing Link. Directed by Larry and\nAndy Wachowski showcasing distracting action scenes and interesting\ntheories. This is certainly a departure from their earlier film, Bound.\nReeves is appealing as someone thrusts out of ordinariness into the\noverwhelming unknown. Fishburne makes for a fine instructor as he\nallows Reeves the freedom of choice but cautions him on the\nconsequences. In other roles are the electrifying Carrie-Anne Moss, and\nthe double-crossing Joe Pantoliano as the villain.                 "reviews": "\nI went to this movie because I was curious -- Owen Wilson NOT in a\ncomedy?? I was pleasantly surprised. Yes, this situation has\nbeen done a zillion times before (for example, THREE \"Taken\" movies) --\nbut I've never seen it done with this much intensity. The movie's focus\nwas not on the \"action.\" Rather, the focus was on the interplay between\nthe parents/kids, how they dealt with each other and the various\nsituations, providing a deeply human touch against a horrifically\ninhuman background (a massacre). And it was this extreme contrast, of\nthe human vs the inhuman, that kept me on the edge of my seat\nthroughout the movie."

The movie hits a high point 15 minutes in\nand doesn't let up the entire time. The movie is tense, exciting and\nextremely fast moving. This is a movie that will surpass your\nexpectations and is one that needs to be watched. I just cannot say\nenough about this movie. Watch this today. Overall, tense, gripping and\nextremely fast moving. One of the best action movies of the year. Watch\nthis today! I give this an A.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Argemaluco",
                "reviewDate": "9 October 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "No  Escape",
                "reviewTotalVote": "7",
                "reviewUseful": "5",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nThe story of No Escape seems deceptively simple, but it offers\nuncountable complications and opportunities to put in danger to the\nleading couple, who unexpectedly doesn't possess any \"special\nabilities\", except their tenacity and wishes to live. It was a pleasant\nsurprise having entered to the cinema expecting another inept variation\nof Taken, and finding a more realistic and personal tale, based on\nhuman emotions instead of shootouts and explosions. Let me clear out\nsomething: there are abundant shootouts and explosions in No Escape,\nbut they aren't employed as visual ornament or pyrotechnical fetish,\nbut as a dramatic auxiliary which complements the desperate situation\nof the Dwyer family. Owen Wilson and Lake Bell bring very good\nperformances in the leading roles, equally dominating the family drama\nand the tense chases in which their characters have to make things they\nconsidered themselves incapable of. I think this is Wilson's first\naction role since Behind Enemy Lines (back in 2001), and it suits him\npretty well, because it doesn't rely on his physical development too\nmuch, but on the internal strength his character must build, well\nhandled by his performance. The same applies to Bell, whose usual\nhumorous roles tend to hide her capacity to transmit quite an intensity\n(even though she had already displayed her wide histrionic range in\nBlack Rock). Pierce Brosnan also brings a decent performance, but his\ncharacter feels a bit clich\u00e9d. Director John Erick Dowdle forged\nhimself in the horror genre (Quarantine, Devil and As Above, So Below),\nand it seems that having handled zombies, demons and ghosts was a good\npreparation for the more mundane (and also more frightening) horrors of\na civil war and a family in danger. His direction feels very natural,\nbut without forgetting some visual tricks which bring style to the\nmovie. Despite not being something great, I found No Escape a competent\nand very entertaining action thriller with more substance than usual,\nwith the additional benefit of eliminating any wish to visit the Asian\nsoutheast. I understand why the country the Dwyer family moved to is\nnever mentioned... doing that, there's no risk of demands or\ninternational incidents.\n"
            },

                "reviewAuthor": "CleveMan66",
                "reviewDate": "28 August 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "\"No Escape\" is the most intense and enjoyable action thriller in a long time.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "13",
                "reviewUseful": "8",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\n\"Intense!\" That's the word I heard myself use most often as I was\ntelling another member of the Movie Fan Community Facebook Page staff\nabout \"No Escape\" (R, 1:43). That is the single best word I know to\ndescribe this action thriller. The film is SO intense that it almost\nfeels like a horror movie. No wonder. It was directed by John Erick\nDowdle, who previously directed the underrated \"Quarantine\" (2008),\n2010's \"Devil\" and 2014's \"As Above, So Below\". In addition to helming\nthis one, he also co-wrote the script with his brother, Drew Dowdle, as\nhe did with \"Quarantine\" and \"As Above\". Yet, \"No Escape\" is not a\nhorror flick. This movie's thrills don't come from outer space or any\nsupernatural realm. The dangers in this film come from what can be the\nmost frighteningly real source of all \u0096 our fellow human beings."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "PWNYCNY",
                "reviewDate": "11 September 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Lots of gratuitous violence, yet a strong story.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "6",
                "reviewUseful": "4",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nThis movie is the latest of Hollywood's ongoing program of bashing\nforeign countries at the expense of Americans who once again are\nportrayed as hapless victims of mindless rage. This time the offending\ncountry is Thailand. (Yes, Thailand.) Why are the Thais, the land of\nlovely ladies, in such a tizzy? Well, without becoming a spoiler, let's\njust say that it is for a reason that is far-fetched and leave it at\nthat. Yes, it's only a movie, and yes, there is something known as\nliterary license, but still, they could have come up with a more\nplausible explanation. But, so what? It's still a good movie. Owen\nWilson does a great job, showing his talent as a dramatic actor. True,\nan entire nation, which has been a staunch ally of the United States\nsince the end of World War Two, is maligned and depicted as an enemy of\nthe United States but such an unlikely scenario provides the background\nto heighten the story's intensity. Yet, rarely has an entire people\nbeen more thoroughly disparaged in a movie than the Thais. After\nwatching this movie, one can reasonably wonder if the Thai people are a\nbunch of marauders who understand only one thing: violence. The nature\nof violence and mayhem perpetrated by the Thais in this movie is\nextreme. Throughout the entire movie mobs of Thai men are shown running\namok. They are rampaging all over the place, burning, pillaging,\nraping, shooting, that is, committing all kind of heinous acts, even\nusing tanks and helicopters as instruments of terror, driven by some\nvague grudge against a handful of hapless Americans who have no idea\nwhat is going on, which in that context makes the behavior of the Thais\nseem even more bizarre. Why a Hollywood movie would want to target\nThailand for such an unsavory depiction is a matter for speculation.\nHowever, one thing is for certain: if you are an American thinking\nabout traveling to Thailand, after watching this movie, you may want to\nthink about changing your plans. If that seems far-fetched, watch the\nmovie.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Robert W. (Robert_duder@hotmail.com)",
                "reviewDate": "3 September 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "An incredibly intense, politically charged thriller",
                "reviewTotalVote": "6",
                "reviewUseful": "4",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nIf No Escape doesn't wind up on my best 2015 list I'll be awfully\nsurprised. This is one of those movies that I went into almost blind. I\ndon't think I ever saw a trailer and I had read the synopsis but that's\nit. So I'm not sure what my expectations were but whatever they were,\nit exceeded them exponentially. Not only is the acting absolutely\nexcellent but the story is so intense, you will literally be on the\nedge of your seat the entire time. Other people in the theatre gasped\nand cried out and you will find yourself holding your breath more than\nonce. There is a distinctive feeling of reality to this film. You know\nthat this happens in the world and it brings it to the forefront so we\ncan't ignore it as we so often do in Western society. The critics of\nthis film all seem to say the same, politically its too simple, its\nracist in its portrayals of the rebels?!?! First of all...it doesn't\nneed to be complicated. The outbreak of violence is clearly and simply\nexplained. There is no more or less to it. Second of all...pulling the\nrace card is ludicrous. There are groups of rebels out there that\nbehave in this manor. We all know genocide happens in the world and now\nwe see it. There are good people in this country, victims and there are\nthe people involved in the uprising. Whether or not you believe their\ncause is justified is totally up to you but the film is the furthest\nthing from racist. If anything there is a particular scene that almost\njustifies their anger."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Gen S2rt",
                "reviewDate": "12 January 1999",
                "reviewTitle": "...and the trilogy is finished with yet another great film.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "68",
                "reviewUseful": "51",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\n\nAfter \"Star Wars: A New Hope\" redefined science fiction, and \"The Empire\nStrikes Back\" redefined \"Star Wars\", it's hard to believe that the third and\nfinal film of this trilogy can manage to be as good as the other two, but\nthis one really does a nice job.  The first part of the film resolves the\ncliffhanger left by the previous one, with an elaborate escape plan that is\nin keeping with the incredible suspense and action of the first two films.\nThen the film moves back to the rebel alliance and what's going on in the\nwar.  There is a lot of action in the scenes building up to the rebellion's\nfinal confrontation with the Emperor.  When the battle begins, the audience\nis already on the edge of their seats from everything leading up to it, and\nthis final battle is even more intense than those from the other films.\nThis climax is definitely more dense with action than any other part of the\ntrilogy, with the most at stake for the rebellion.  This is continually\nchanging between a ground battle between the rebel strike crew on land\n(including Han Solo, Chewbacca, and Leia), the battle raging on in space\n(including Lando), and a confrontation between Luke and the Emperor on the\nnew Death Star, which leads up to another duel with Darth Vader.  It is\nreally intense since the rebels constantly seem to be losing the battle that\nwill determine the outcome of the war, and there seems to be no escape.\nAlthough I think the idea of Ewoks overpowering stormtroopers is a bit\nfar-fetched, it didn't seem very unrealistic since they were more of a\ndistraction that the rebels could use, rather than an actual threat to the\nstormtroopers, although they did have some luck fighting them.  There is\nalso a twist or two at the end that nobody saw coming, which may not be\nquite as stunning as that of \"The Empire Strikes Back\", but still complete a\nvery spectacular trilogy very well.  With the light tone of \"A New Hope\" and\nthe more sinnister tone of \"The Empire Strikes Back\", this film really\ncompletes them by combining the two in this grand finale.  The Special\nEdition for \"Return of the Jedi\" concentrated on what would have been nice\nto change, since not much of the original really needed it.  Fifteen years\nof technology advancements didn't seem to make up for fifteen years of\ndeterioration as far as the rancor scene is concerned, and there still is\nthe occasional disappearing TIE fighter, but other than that it was good.\nThe gaping non-threatening Sarlaac's mouth was given moving tentacles and a\nhuge fly-trap looking head that emerged, which definitely added to the\nsuspense.  Also, the disco was taken out of Jabba's palace, and the lame\nending of the original was replaced by a huge victory celebration spanning\nthe entire galaxy, instead of just a small Ewok village, which was the case\nof the original and that didn't really end a story this big the way it\ndeserved.  It's hard to say which of the three films was the best, but since\nit's all part of the same story, the over-all trilogy is like one big,\noutstanding film.  A THIRD must-see for film fans.\n"

                "reviewDate": "5 October 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Its fun, but full of holes and inconsistencies",
                "reviewTotalVote": "9",
                "reviewUseful": "6",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nIn many ways, Return of the Jedi cut firmly against the brilliant grain\nset by Empire Strikes Back. The reason Empire was so effective was that\nit showed us the rebels were still losing, you can't just destroy the\nDeath Star and have everything go away. But here, Lucas rounds out the\ntrilogy with another climactic space battle and everything wraps up\nreally nicely with no questions ask. Return of the Jedi is clearly the\nleast impressive of the original trilogy. It is full of holes, tonal\ninconsistencies and plot implausibilities. I'd chalk this up to Richard\nMarquand not being half as competent as Irvin Kershner, and the\ndeparture of Gary Kurtz from the project. Kurtz reportedly left because\nhe and Lucas couldn't agree on whether story or spectacle should take\npriority (Lucas was obviously in favour of spectacle), and you can tell\nbecause Return of the Jedi's story makes absolutely no sense in places."

                "reviewTitle": "Underrated, and completely satisfying",
                "reviewTotalVote": "4",
                "reviewUseful": "3",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nSome people have disliked this film, and I truly don't see why. \"Return\nof the Jedi,\" does not, contrary to popular opinion, ruin the original\n\"Star Wars\" trilogy but rather ties it up in a perfectly satisfying\nway. The opening scenes at Jabba the Hutt's palace are well done. Jabba\nis a much meaner and scarier villain here than the short clip in the\n1997 re-release of \"A New Hope\" showed him to be. Luke Skywalker is\nforced to make his most difficult choices in this film, and the\nintensity of the film's last half-hour is some of the most compelling\nfilm-making I've ever seen. The themes and messages of redemption and\ngood vs. evil are superbly done here. \"Return of the Jedi\" is a very\nexciting and engaging film, memorable and worth watching many times,\nespecially now that Episode III has been made. It's not as perfect as\nthe previous two Star Wars films were, but it is a very pleasing and\nhappy conclusion to an amazing story. The fourth best in the saga,\nbehind the two originals and Episode III. Nearly perfect."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "trublu215",
                "reviewDate": "19 December 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "Brutal and Powerful; American Sniper ranks among the best of the year",
                "reviewTotalVote": "957",
                "reviewUseful": "509",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nAmerican Sniper is Clint Eastwood's harrowing take on Chris Kyle's life\nand his service in the Navy as a SEAL sniper who killed nearly 200\nenemy soldiers. The film is relentlessly violent and disturbing but\nhonors the life of the late Chris Kyle in a very admirable way. It\ndoesn't show this man as an invincible legend, it shows him as a mere\nman with a heart and soul that are clearly broken due to his sacrifice\nfor his country. Bradley Cooper delivers the best performance of his\ncareer as Chris Kyle. Cooper didn't merely bulk up for the role, he\nbecame this man without any hesitation and doesn't hit a false note.\nClint Eastwood proves that he can still deliver a phenomenal film even\nin his mid-eighties. It isn't only impressive for his age, but American\nSniper is an impressive film in general. It doesn't wallow in classic\nwar film clich\u00e8s, it tells Kyle's story the way he told it in the book\nand while some creative liberties were taken in telling the story\nregarding pacing, it is an excellent film. It isn't an all out war film\nlike The Hurt Locker, it is a heavy drama with plenty of gut wrenching\nscenes both on and off the battle field. The most interesting part of\nthis film is the parallels between Kyle's life as a sniper and Kyle's\ndeteriorating life state side. It is an interesting dynamic to add to a\nfilm like this and echoes past films from the 70s such as Coming Home\nand The Deer Hunter. On a technical level, American Sniper sores with\ngreat cinematography that is a bit more colorful when compared to\nEastwood's past films and excellent sound design. You see every wound\nand hear every gunshot with realistic velocity. It is a truly great\ncinematic experience. Overall, American Sniper is a great film that\nwill tug at your heart strings much like last year's Lone Survivor and\neven goes one step beyond that film and gives us grade A entertainment\nwith grade A acting. It stands as one of the best films of the year.\n"

It's not flashy, and it tells the story without adding to\nit like Hollywood tends to do with all war movies, especially ones\nabout the recent wars our men have served in. You feel like you know at\nleast a portion of what a sniper and his Seal team went through while\nserving in the Iraq War. But, most importantly, it also tells the story\nof an Extraordinary Man, a true American Hero, who devoted much of his\nlife to his country, taking multiple tours to keep \"his men\" safe, and\nto protect his country. While highlighting Chris\nKyle's success as a dominant force in the navy seals, Eastwood also\ndelves into the more sensitive and intimate parts of Chris Kyle's life,\nsuch as his marriage, his children and most significantly the mental\nanxiety which is derived from war.             {
                "reviewAuthor": "John Panagopoulos (japamo@hotmail.com)",
                "reviewDate": "9 April 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "This War Movie is Both Straightforward and Ambiguous, Like Its Protagonist, Who Emerges as a Bit of An Unknown Soldier.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "53",
                "reviewUseful": "34",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nAt least in the post-Vietnam era, arguably, good war movies should make\npoor military recruitment videos. In other words, they should make you\nwant to stay as far the hell away from the hell of war as possible. By\nthis standard, director Clint Eastwood's \"American Sniper\" (hereafter\n\"AS\") is at least partially a good movie. Even though its protagonist,\nChris Kyle (Bradley Cooper), appears to be a decent, good-old-boy,\npatriotic Texan eager to enlist in the U.S. Navy and become a Navy SEAL\nafter hearing of U.S. embassy bombings, his Iraqi Gulf War military\nexperiences, I don't think, would make most people want to visit Iraq\nand kill terrorists. Nevertheless, \"AS\" also seems to retain some of\nthe gung-ho spirit of straightforward pre-Vietnam movies to make the\ncase that this is a \"worthwhile\" war in the sense that it was necessary\nto protect American security. Perhaps AS is both straightforward and\nambiguous, both in its depiction of wartime heroics and atrocities, and\nits depiction of a soldier that revels in, and is damaged by, his role\nas a sniper."

                "reviewAuthor": "zardoz-13",
                "reviewDate": "29 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Above-Averge Heist Thrillers",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\n\"Tournament\" director Scott Mann's generically entitled robbery\nthriller \"Heist\" with Jeffrey Dean Morgan, Robert De Niro, Dave\nBautista, Morris Chestnut and Gina Carano is a good, solid actioneer\nthat probably wouldn't have lasted long in movie theaters.\nNevertheless, this is an entertaining but formulaic contemporary\nmelodrama with enough fast-paced, excitingly stage action to keep you\nwatching it for its minimal 93-minutes. \"Watchmen\" actor Jeffrey Dean\nMorgan is competently cast as a casino croupier named Vaughn who works\nfor The Pope (Robert De Niro of \"Raging Bull\") at his dockside casino.\nVaughn is a sympathetic protagonist primarily because he has a sick\nchild who needs costly medical treatment that he cannot afford.\nEssentially, Vaughn doesn't have the $300-thousand to ensure that she\nreceives proper treatment. He appeals to The Pope, and The Pope turns\nhim down without a qualm. Robert De Niro makes a glacially cold villain\nwho smokes electronic cigarettes now because he is about to die and his\nown daughter Sydney (Kate Bosworth of \"Straw Dogs\") wants nothing to do\nwith either his fortune or him. Meantime, another casino employee named\nCox (Dave Bautista of \"Spectre\") approaches Vaughn about sticking up\nthe casino. Cox brings along two other thugs and Vaughn briefs him at a\nlocal diner about how they can pull off the heist. The heist itself\ngets off to a rough start because they have to kill one employee and\nthen one of their own panics and leaves them high and dry in the\nparking lot as he careens off in their getaway car. The Pope's chief\nmuscle, Dog (Morris Chestnut of \"Identity Thief\"), goes after Vaughn\nand company with a vengeance. Matters aren't helped because one of them\nwinds up wounded, and they have to scramble for transportation. They\nwind up hijacking a bus driving by Bernie (D.B. Sweeney of \"Chi-Raq\")\nand they force him to hit the highway. A lone sheriff's deputy, Kris\n(Gina Carano of \"Haywire\"), gets into the act, too, and scares off Dog,\nbut things change again when a hot-shot lieutenant, Marconi (Mark-Paul\nGosselaar of \"Dead Man on Campus\") gets involved with the pursuit."

                "reviewAuthor": "leonblackwood",
                "reviewDate": "23 January 2016",
                "reviewTitle": "Average movie with some decent story! 4/10",
                "reviewTotalVote": 0,
                "reviewUseful": 0,
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nReview: This movie seemed a bit safe because we have all seen this type\nof concept before but I still enjoyed the film and the acting wasn't\nthat bad. It's about a casino worker, Luke Vaughn (Jeffrey Dean\nMorgan), who desperately needs money to pay for an operation that his\ndaughter needs to save her life. Out of desperation, he turns to casino\nowner Francis \"The Pope\" Silva (Robert DeNiro), for the cash but he\nturns him down, which leaves Luke in a tricky situation. After seeing\nall of the cash that goes through the casino, Cox (Dave Bautista)\noffers Luke the opportunity to rob the casino and when Pope turns down\nLuke for the loan, he takes the job and they put together the\nperfection plan, with Cox's 2 close friends, Julian Dante (Stephen\nCyprus Sepher) and Mickey (Tyson Sullivan). On the night of the\nrobbery, they manage to put $3 million in bags, after cutting the power\nbut when they try and escape with the cash, they bump into Pope's main\nhenchman, Dog (Morris Chestnut), which leads to a shootout in the\ncasino. Dante gets shot while there trying to make it to the getaway\ncar and when they finally reach the pick up point, they see Mickey\ndriving away in a panic because of the shots being fired from The Dog\nand the casinos security. They then jump on the nearest bus and they\ntake the passengers hostage, whilst being chased down by the police\nwith the loot. Luke talks to the police officer who is taking chase,\nKrizia (Gina Carano) and he shows sympathy towards the passengers but\nCox is in a panic about getting caught and he tries to help Dante, who\nis in a lot of pain. They then see that the bus is running out of fuel,\nso Luke asks for a fuel truck for the exchange of 2 of the passengers.\nAfter a successful transaction, they try to make there way to Texas to\nmeet up with Cox's friend, but there journey is interrupted when a\ncorrupt cop, Detective Marconi (Mark-Paul Gosselaar), who works for\nPope, kills Dante with a lethal injection whilst offering him help with\nhis injuries. Cox desperately wants to Marconi but Luke knows that\nthere life's wouldn't be worth living if they killed a cop, so they\nthrow him off the bus. The chase then continues and the police manage\nto stop the bus by shooting out the wheels after sending in an elite\nsquad team. Cox then holds the bus driver at gunpoint and threatens to\nkill him if the cops don't let them go but Luke doesn't want to kill\nany innocent people so he kills Cox but everyone thinks that Cox has\nkilled the driver. Luke then gets a call from his daughter and Krizia\ntells him that she knows about everything. As he saved the drivers\nlife, he comes up with the idea to exchange the bus being fixed for\nletting most of the hostages go, so the police accept the trade and the\nbus carries on its journey. Luke manages to get of the bus with the\nhostages but the police are still chasing the bus, hoping to find the\nrobbers. Luke then tries to get to safety but he comes face to face\nwith the Dog, who takes him to the Pope. They then realise that the bag\nof cash is empty because Luke had given the cash to one of the\npassengers, who was acting as if she was pregnant and turned out to be\nhis sister. Krizia sees her giving the money to a doctor to pay for\nLuke's daughters operation but she turns a blind eye because she knows\nthat he had good intentions. As the Pope had a troubled relationship\nwith his daughter, because of his dodgy business dealings, he stops Dog\nfrom killing Luke by shooting him. He then let's Luke go and he calls\nKrizia to find out how his daughter is doing and once he finds out that\nthe doctors are preparing her for her operation, he knows that the\nwhole crazy situation wasn't for nothing. It's not the most original\nstoryline and it did have \"Speed\" written all over it but there is a\nsense of tension throughout the movie, which made it a decent watch.\nAlthough the movie made a big lose at the box office, it really isn't\nthat bad and it's basically what it says on the tin. You can't go wrong\nwith DeNiro playing a gangster and Bautista as a thug so the casting\nwasn't bad but the storyline could have done with some originality or\nsome major twists. Watchable!"

                "reviewTitle": "Narrow, conventional and kind of boring",
                "reviewTotalVote": "4",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "5",
                "reviews": "\nThis is a pretty straightforward movie and for the most part it's\npretty darn predictable. It sort of reminded me of \"Speed\" mixed in\nwith robbery and this time around the robbers are in the bus with\nhostages. But what makes this movie sort of stand out is the dilemma\nthe characters has to deal with. Not everyone is straight up 100% good\nor 100% evil, but the circumstances pushed them to make certain\nchoices. Robert De Niro once again takes on the role which made his\ncareer, he basically plays a gangster. In this film a gangster with a\ncode that is driven by greed, but his conscience also plays a part as\nwell because of his daughter. I am glad Jeffrey Dean Morgan is back as\nthe leading character, not that I think he is a amazing actor or\nanything like that. He just seems like a really likable guy in real\nlife. Same goes for Dave Bautista. This is a passable movie for a\nstraight to DVD, but I would never see it in theaters. It just isn't\nworth it. It's passable for a rental, but not one of the top movies to\nrent out. It isn't a awful movie, but it's still easily forgettable and\ndoesn't bring anything new to this genre. And like most of these\nstraight to DVD like movies, some of the action sequences and decisions\ndon't make much sense. I however did like one of the message in this\nmovie, which I thought was impactful. It goes somewhere along the lines\nof \"Love is built on sacrifice, not dollars\"."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "julian_dax",
                "reviewDate": "20 June 2013",
                "reviewTitle": "Secret of the \"S\"",
                "reviewTotalVote": "116",
                "reviewUseful": "64",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nSince no one seems to be giving this movie the review it deserves, I'm\nhere to go to 'bat' for the best movie I've ever seen. I'd love to get\nan original copy of the script so I could read the dialogue over and\nover; as someone with a short attention span, four pages is perfect.\nAnd I like the intellectual thrill of reading \"and then ___ punches ___\nfor the other 156 pages. The subtle political messages of this movie\nare so important for our generation, like the expenditure of finite\nnatural resources and the fact that no matter how many little people\nget sacrificed in pursuit of a greater enemy such as General Zod, the\nfate of the world is better served without his overacting. I loved the\nemotional intensity when Clark turns to General Zod and says \"You're a\nmonster...I'm going to stop you.\" I also loved the last seventeen\nsuperhero movies that used the same line. As someone who was born in\nKansas, it truly warmed the cockles of my heart to see it portrayed as\nsuch an upstanding paragon of American patriotism - that, and fat,\nsmall-minded ginger kids who victimize people until they realize the\nerror of their ways and settle down to pathetic, menial jobs and eating\nat IHOP (and other people with bad teeth). The more important thing is\nthat we saw KU playing ball. I felt like the moral dilemmas were so\nreal, yet they are as timeless as Plato, which Clark so obviously read\nand understood when he exercised his godlike powers to level a city and\nkill thousands of innocent bystanders - clearly, that was the ideal\nform of the state that Plato envisaged, united under the martial rule\nof a tyrant in tights. At least he understood the chain of command, and\ngot military authorization first. If my family member had been part of\nthe collateral damage, it would alleviate my grief to know that a\nsuperior being had considered whether my loss was at least\nproportional, as I'm sure it comforts families in Pakistan. Superman\nhas always been such a good guy; I like the change where he doesn't\nsave people any more, it's so much cooler when he's a thug and\nextra-judicial assassin. And even though Lois and Clark only spent\nabout fifteen minutes of the almost three hour movie on screen\ntogether, it in no way cooled the passion of their first-basing on top\nof the rubble and corpses of Metropolis. I was so glad that they\ndisposed of conventional ideas of Superman, like narrative, foundation,\nmotive, character development, and plot continuity. They really seemed\nto focus on realism - nothing so implausible as Kryptonite - just a\ncodex that has the genetics of every future Kryptonian pre-programmed.\nBut all that I've said falls woefully short of the grandeur of the\nactual film - the incoherence of this review cannot possibly outrival\nit.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Brent Hankins",
                "reviewDate": "21 May 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "Sets a new high-water mark for the franchise.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "113",
                "reviewUseful": "70",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nAfter the disappointing and directionless X3: The Last Stand and the \r\nabysmal X-Men Origins: Wolverine, prospects for the continuation of the \r\nfranchise had gone from great to grim in just a few short years. \r\nDesperate to breathe life back into the series, 20th Century Fox turned \r\nto director Bryan Singer to help right the ship, and although Singer \r\ndidn't return to the director's chair, he oversaw production of X-Men: \r\nFirst Class, an origin story centered on the friendship between Charles \r\nXavier (James McAvoy) and Erik Lensherr (Michael Fassbender) in their \r\nearly years.\r\n\r\nA critical and commercial success, First Class set the stage for an \r\nexpanded X-Men universe featuring younger versions of the mutant \r\nsuperheroes, but many fans still clamored for more adventures featuring \r\nthe original cast. With Singer back at the helm, X-Men: Days of Future \r\nPast aims to balance precariously between the two, giving the original \r\non screen mutants one last chance to shine, while simultaneously \r\npushing the younger generation forward, and fixing a few glaring \r\ncontinuity errors along the way.\r\n\r\nThe film opens with a tremendous action sequence in the near future, \r\nwhere an army of mutant-hunting robots called Sentinels have driven the \r\nX-Men underground. This sequence of events was set into motion some 50 \r\nyears earlier, when Mystique (Jennifer Lawrence) assassinated Bolivar \r\nTrask, a military scientist and anti-mutant activist whose experimental \r\nSentinel program would only be accelerated by his untimely demise.\r\n\r\nWith only a handful of their kind remaining, and their numbers \r\ndwindling seemingly by the second, the elder Xavier (Patrick Stewart) \r\nand Magneto (Ian McKellan) discover that Kitty Pryde (Ellen Page) has \r\nthe ability to transport a person's consciousness into their younger \r\nself. It's a painful experience, one that Xavier is far too fragile to \r\nwithstand, but thanks to his innate healing ability, Wolverine (Hugh \r\nJackman) is the perfect candidate to be sent back to alter the events \r\nthat led to the destruction of the mutant race.\r\n\r\nWaking up in his 1973 body, Wolverine is tasked with tracking down and \r\nreuniting Xavier and Lensherr to stop the assassination of Trask. Easy \r\nenough, right? Unfortunately, Xavier has become a bitter, reclusive \r\nalcoholic, wasting away in his mansion with his only remaining friend, \r\nHank McCoy (Nicholas Hoult), while Lensherr is incarcerated in the most \r\nsecure building in the United States after being implicated in the \r\ndeath of President Kennedy. After all, as Xavier puts it, \"who else \r\ncould curve a bullet?\"\r\n\r\nGetting Lensherr out of trouble is a seemingly impossible task, but \r\nWolverine knows a guy. That guy is the young Pietro Maximoff, better \r\nknown as Quicksilver (Evan Peters), and his handful of scenes are some \r\nof the most entertaining moments in the film, particularly an escape \r\nsequence that conveys his super-speed abilities by shooting at 3000 \r\nframes per second. There have been glimpses of this moment during the \r\nfilm's trailers, but the scene as a whole is staggeringly beautiful, \r\nand the character's bizarre sense of humor provides a sense of joy and \r\nplayfulness that are noticeably absent from the rest of the film.\r\n\r\nThat's not to say X-Men: Days of Future Past is not enjoyable - on the \r\ncontrary, it's a thrilling experience from start to finish, with plenty \r\nof emotional resonance to go along with all the action and special \r\neffects. Jackman's performance is less growling menace and more wise \r\nmediator, adding yet another dimension to an already complex character. \r\nMcAvoy and Fassbender still have remarkable chemistry, but the film \r\ntruly belongs to Lawrence, whose ability to emote through layers of \r\nbody paint and prosthetics makes Mystique more relatable than ever \r\nbefore.\r\n\r\nWhile it's a shame that most of the original X-Men cast are relegated \r\nto cameos, those minor appearances tend to come during jaw-dropping \r\naction scenes. The futuristic battles between the Sentinels and the \r\nlast remaining mutants are a joy to behold, with Iceman (Shawn Ashmore) \r\nfinally using his abilities in ways that fans have always wanted to \r\nsee, and newcomers like Blink (Fan Bingbing) and Bishop (Omar Sy) \r\ngetting an opportunity to kick ass alongside the veterans.\r\n\r\nThere are also plenty of references to the previous X-Men films, as \r\nDays of Future Past attempts to bridge the gap between the original \r\ntrilogy and the reboot. William Stryker (Josh Helman) is a looming \r\npresence throughout the film, with his work evoking images of the \r\nWeapon X program, and the final moments are full of fan service cameos \r\nthat effectively close the book on the original characters. For the \r\nmost part, it succeeds, and while there are still a few questions \r\nremaining, there's so much to love here that the minor details no \r\nlonger feel relevant.\r\n\r\nX-Men: Days of Future Past is a return to form for Singer, whose \r\ndirectorial efforts since the first two films have been rather poorly \r\nreceived. His emotional connection to the material and his love for the \r\ncharacters has never been more evident, and the X-Men have never been \r\nmore compelling or entertaining. This latest installment proves there's \r\nstill plenty of life left in the franchise, and we can't wait to see \r\nwhat comes next when the mutants return in 2016.\r\n\r\n-- Brent Hankins\n"

                "reviewTitle": "Should've been titled: X-Men days of future plot holes!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "14",
                "reviewUseful": "9",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\n(Spoiler Warning) I'm really scratching my head on this one guys, this\nmovie's been hailed as \"The best x-men movie ever!\" I'm sorry, but I\nREALLY have to disagree on this one. Before I state all the reasons why\nI hated this movie, let me start off with two positive comments: Hugh\nJackman is still good as Wolverine, and the character of Quicksilver,\nwas pretty cool. Now for the numerous reasons as to why I hated this\nfilm. So we start off looking at a destroyed, post apocalyptic,\nlandscape that looks like it was ripped off from the first two\nTerminator movies. We then get some narration from Charles Xavier. He\nexplains that most of the mutant population has been enslaved or killed\nby these killer machines known as sentinels. Then we see a small group\nof mutants who are both hiding, and trying to fight the sentinels.\nXavier tells them that the only chance for the mutant race to survive,\nis to go back in time to try to prevent the assassination of a\ngovernment scientist, which in turn prevents the deployment of the\nsentinels. So Wolverine is sent back through time, and must prevent\nfellow mutant Mystique, from doing the deed. You would think that a\nplot involving time travel would be intriguing and interesting right?\nWell not in this movie! There's almost no action, The actors are bland,\nand you couldn't care less for any of the characters! That's only the\ntip of the iceberg folks! What really kills it is the fact the the plot\nhas more holes in it than a slice of Swiss cheese! Before I talk about\nthat though, let me back up a bit. When \"X-men first class\" came out, I\nthought to myself: Okay cool, they're rebooting the x-men franchise and\nmaking a whole new series.\" Turns out they weren't, the only reason why\n\"X-Men first class was made, was so that they could create a whole new\ncontinuity that they could smash together with the old continuity. The\nresult of this, is a clusterf*cked mess! This film won't leave you\nfeeling good or entertained, it will only leave you with a head full of\nquestions. Such as these: Why is Xavier alive in the future, when we\nclearly saw him being killed by the phoenix in part 3? Why does\nWolverine have bone claws in the past, but metal claws in the future?\nWhy does Xavier claim to have known Mystique since she was a child,\nwhen there was no indication of that in the original films? Why does\nWolverine claim that in the future he and Hank McCoy (Beast) are\nfriends when there was no previous indication of that? In the climax of\nthe film, the sentinels have already been built. Even though they\nsucceed in their mission, what's there to stop someone else from using\nthem? How does Wolverine survive for so long underwater? Did Mystique\nperform the adamantium experiments on Wolverine? Why and how are\nCyclops and Jean Grey alive again at the end? This movie doesn't even\nso much as attempt to answer any of the questions that it leaves the\nviewer with! Frankly, it would be easier to solve a Rubik's cube on LSD\nthan it would be be to figure this movie out! So far, I've never been\nimpressed with ANY of the X-men films. 1 and 2 were lame, 3 was\ngarbage, and this one was even worse! I'm done with this franchise! I\ndon't care what they do with the next film, I've put up with all the\nincompetence I can take! From now on, it's just the x-men comics and\ncartoons for me. Sorry 20th century fox, but you guys blew it!\n"
            },

                "reviewUseful": "6",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nThis is the best movie in the series and of the year! Let me start off\nby saying I'm a huge fan of the x-men. I read the comics, I watched the\n90's cartoon, their my favorite comic book title from Marvel and 2nd\nonly to batman. The x-men film series is my personal favorite film\nseries of all-time! I think 20th century fox has done a great job\nhandling the series and I'm happy with every installment. But even\nthough I couldn't wait to see this movie I was a little worried about\nthe time line & continuity in this film, there were already continuity\nissue starting with \"first class\" but Singer said he wanted to fix\nthose problems. And since this film has wolverine going back to 1973, I\nwas worried about how that fits with \"origins\" and I was also worried\nabout the fact that the sentinels were created in the 70's but no where\nto be found in the original x-men trilogy. But I'm very happy to say\nthat the story works perfectly and dosen't really contradict the other\nfilms! Before I talk about the great actors and special effects I must\ntalk about how great the story is and Singer did \"fix\" the continuity.\nFirst off they explained how professor X was able to walk after getting\nparalyzed in \"first class(FC) because that was one of the major\ncontinuity problems in that we saw Xaviar get paralyzed in \"FC\" but in\nflashbacks of \"origins\" & \"last stand\" which took place in the 80's he\nwas walking but here they explain he can walk thanks to a serum by Hank\nso that gives a good explanation for that. They did a good job\nexplaining how the sentinels fit into the previous story line, so in\n1973 professor X was depressed & magneto was locked in prison so\nmystique was left on her own and she killed Trask but was briefly\ncaptured where scientist took her blood & 50 years later they used her\nblood to create sentinels that can shape shift to adapt to whoever\ntheir fighting. So that perfectly explains why there were no sentinels\nin the previous x-men films. Mystique killed Trask in '73 so no\nsentinels were created. And they didn't know that mystique's blood\nwould be used to create unstoppable killer robots 50 years later. So in\nthe background of X1, X2, X3 and the wolverine Trask industry was\nworking on bringing back the sentinels until they had the technology to\nuse mystique's blood for the sentinels. But this movie does make me\nwonder what happened in the original time line, I mean how did\nprofessor X get out of his funk & started the school again and how did\nmagneto and mystique get out of custody but the good thing there's\nstill like a 30 year gap between the events of '73 and the 1st x-men\nmovie so a lot could of happened. So seeing a middle age professor X &\nMagneto in a flashback in \"last stand\" where they meet a child Jean\nGrey dosen't seem to be out of place in the continuity. And wolverine\ntraveling back to 1973 dosen't contradict too much with \"origins\".\nWolverine has the bone-claws like in origins and I like how they made\nhim wake-up in the 70's, he had another life going on. I like when the\nwomen called him Jimmy which was revealed to be his real name in\n\"origins\" so I liked that connection. The only problem is that William\nStryker in this film is a young man in his 20's or maybe early 30's but\nin \"origins\" he meets wolverine & Victor in Vietnam & he was in his\n40's. But other then that it fits pretty well. Stryker probably met\nWolverine & Victor in Vietnam and soon after joining him, wolverine\nleft to be alone for 6 years. But since there was no specific year\nshowed in \"origins\" you can be flexible there. My only criticism is\nthat we don't see more of the horrible future but maybe it's for the\nbest 'cause it was pretty dark & sad. But I think they could of\nexplained a little more like how professor X came back alive after\n\"last stand\". I would've liked to see more of storm, iceman, colossus\nand Bishop. But at least we got to see them do some cool stuff with\ntheir powers. All the actors did a great job & despite playing\nwolverine for 6 movies Jackman is still awesome, his gruff personality\nis so appealing and I like that even in the horrible future he's still\nsmoking his cigars. McAvoy & Fassbender are perfect as the younger\nXaviar & Magneto. Peter Dinkalege is great as Bolivia Trask. I like how\nWilliam Stryker works into story. I love the look of the sentinels, the\n\"future ones\" look really scary and the \"past ones\" looks perfect to\nthe iconic comic book version. The plot is unpredictable and leaves you\nwith doubt about if they can save the future. It's a really well\nwritten story with great emotional depth & strong performances from\neveryone. I love Jennifer Lawerence as mystique. I love the actor\nplaying quicksilver, his look & personality was just like in the\ncomics, he was funny and stoled every scene. Of course Fox wanted a\npiece of the pie too, but I'm sure they knew that you need quality to\nmake lots of money, so they invested a lot and secured Bryan Singer for\nthe director's chair. He was already around to produce and write First\nClass but this time around he got control of the whole film. Fox then\nokayed the x-men series most complex story for the film. Thought the\nscript was written by Simon Kinberg, who already fell short with the 3\npart back in the day but for some reason Singer trusted him with it.\nFirst off the film is good, maybe even the best yet. Of course the\nbiggest question everyone has been asking is will it give the Avengers\na run for its money and that's a harder question to answer. Compared to\nother comic book adaptations and other Marvel films the two are very\ndifferent, so it's hard to compare them, but I have to point out the\nquality wise it's up there with Ironman. I don't think that it will be\nthere money wise. They did rewrite the original story from the comic\nbook, but that didn't cause problems. I was mostly worried about how\nthey would sew the 5 x-men films together but that was done perfectly.\nSo the story is okay. As is the script. There are humorous parts, but\nthey aren't over the top. Just enough. The actors are genius, none of\nthem forgot how to act since the previous installments. This was a give\nthough cause the casting was always super. Evan Peters as Quicksilver\nis so good, that it almost becomes his one man show. I maybe just\nexpected a little more from Peter Dinklage. Let's look at the other\ncharacters, as opposed to the other films Wolverine isn't completely in\nthe main focus, and the funny thing is that this isn't a problem.\nMagneto, Xavier and Mystic step up to the plate, but just to sooth the\nfans he doesn't fade into the background. But this still brings us to\none of the problems, there is not enough time for all the characters;\nIt's one team but two time zones, some characters got larger roles like\nMystic, and a few were left to fade away, but Singer manage to fix this\nproblem, way better than with x-men 2 by having huge action scenes in\nthe film. They are done well and are brutal. So we don't really have\ntime to get into which characters are lost in the background. You're\njust whiplashed by the action, action that is not the least bit\npointless. There is always a believable story behind each one. All in\nall it's a step forward from First Class, and it was a quality step\ntoo. It's not just a 5th part. Which is huge. So I give it a 9/10 Max -\nhttps://www.youtube.com/user/silverscreenreviews1\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "cjs343",
                "reviewDate": "19 August 2013",
                "reviewTitle": "A Fantastic Commentary Above the Understanding of Many",
                "reviewTotalVote": "30",
                "reviewUseful": "19",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nUnderstandably, the film wakes much rejection. A quick view or not\nreflective enough can mislead us to believe that it is superficial. On\nthe contrary, Harmony Korine's film is a bitter satire (at times\ncynical) about the American youth culture and, in large part, global.\nThe shallowness of the characters is deliberate. The three crazy\ntravelers do evil in pure boredom, the banality of evil is presented\nhere in an ironic contrast to the free and unlimited sexuality and drug\nuse, the Holy Grial of these girls. At times, the three chicks seem the\nwitches of Macbeth, messengers of death and emptiness. Harmony Korine\nis a moralist, his film denounces the horror that lurks behind the\nglamour of drugs and free love. But Korine delivers his message with a\nstyle that copies and reproduces the mechanisms of fashion, so that a\nteenager is attracted yet shocked by what you see on the screen.\nWatching this movie, it is impossible not to remember Less Than Zero,\nthe novel that enabled Bret Easton Ellis earn his place under the\nCalifornia sun. The state of affairs is certainly catastrophic for\nKorine: a. The pursuit of happiness is reduced to get lost in a\nperpetual orgy. b. The perpetual orgy is slightly threatened only by\nreligious zealots as the only challenging force. c. No more parents and\nadults, no more institutions concerned with the physical and mental\nhealth of its citizens. d. Youngsters' paradise is depicted as one of\nthe many faces of hell.\n"
