Directed and\nwritten by Harmony Korine, the film highlights the mindless U.S popular\ncultural event known as 'Spring Break'. Spring Break serves as a break\nfrom the social norms, where youth can relax from the stresses of life.\nOver the years, Spring Breaks celebrating in Florida with each\ngeneration has got more extreme and stupid. I don't have a problem with\nSpring Break, as it's does boost the local economy, but I do see this\nsort of party fascination is blindly controlling youth in the worth\ndirection. Colleges are become less and less about teachings of proper\neducation, and more and more about majority in being a drunken fool,\nlately. I hate dumb young people. The film depicts the shallowness of\none such event, and the extreme examples of letting loose of society\ncontrol. It's pretty sad to see four gifted smart college students\nallowing themselves to do dumb things that seems 'cool' because of\nthese YOLO phenomenon. Ideas like long drinking binges, whoring\nthemselves out, and lots of drug use. These bad behaviors are cause by\ntwo factors: A fear of not being good enough (the fear of failure) &\nthe fear that his or her life's not going to be good enough (the fear\nof loss). Sadly, this movie doesn't explain it well. There is little to\nno amount of intellectually subtle social commentary in this movie.\nIt's not even that thought-provoking. It gives no insight, message, or\nunderlying theme. I found this to be the most depressing part of the\nfilm. We never truly know why this girls do the most despicable acts\nand behave with such depravity. If the movie had more inside of the\ncharacter's home or school life, maybe we can understand what they're\ngoing through, but no. This movie doesn't know if glorifying the\ndemoralizing activities portrayed, if it is a satire it, or its just\nmindless shock value. It's in no way, a comedy as the majority of the\nsexual, and violence content is actually presented in a dramatic or\nuncomfortable fashion. Very rarely is it meant to be comedic or taken\nlightly. I just have to say, it was painful to watch. No amount of eye\ncandy, and nudity shots can make this movie any better. Most of the\nControversial of this film comes with the fact that the four college\nstudent turn robbers are mostly ex-Disney TV teen idols. Seeing Selema\nGomez, Vanessa Hudgens, Ashley Benson and Rachel Korine in this film is\na bit disappointing, as they all could had pick better adult themes\nroles. I'm not talking about roles that degraded women to being near\ndumb sex objects like this movie does. They really need to follow the\nEmmas (Emma Stone, Emma Watson, and Emma Roberts, who majority in my\nopinion, start in pretty good movies). Emma Roberts was supposed to\nstart in this film, but dropped out in early 2012, reportedly after\nhearing she would need to gain body fat for her role. Good for her.\nThere is little to no character development, but glad the movie shows\nthat at less two of girls came back to their senses, as less I think.\nSo I guess, that counts. If there is a protagonist in this movie, it\nwould be the development of Faith (Selema Gomez). I doubt this movie\nwill hurt Selema Gomez's movie career. James Franco as the\nweapon-dealing, wannabe rapper Alien is pretty bad in my opinion. I\nknow a lot of people like his performance, but I found it to be\nannoying as hell with his looping voice of Spring Break is forever. At\nless, it wasn't real rapper Riff Raff playing Alien. That would be\nworst off. I give some credit to the movie as some scenes are pretty\nbeautiful shot. I like how it was shot like a weird dream, with its\npoignant use of slow motion, and its use of bright beautiful colors. It\nwas well-shot kinda, with a few scenes that are going a bit too\nsoft-porn. There's a beautifully crafted scene during their robbery of\na restaurant that features one of the girls rolling the car around the\nbuilding, catching glimpses of what they were doing inside. There is\nsomething disturbing about having seeing two maniac women kill people,\nand be OK watching My Little Pony: Friendship is magic. There is a\npretty good scene where Alien is with the girls around a piano singing,\n'Everytime' by Britney Spears. The electronic techno dubstep music by\nSkrillex is pretty catchy. The movie is pretty smart with its\nforeshadowing. It does it with sounds. The movie is broken into roughly\nfour segments, and the transition between each is a specific event that\nhas a distinctive sound. The sound is worked into the edits and shot\nchanges in the scenes leading up to their events. Specifically, sounds\nof crashing and hammering leads up to the fast food robbery, sounds of\nthe jail cell door leads up to the arrest, and sounds of gun fire leads\nup to one of the characters being shot. The bloody ending is a bit a\nstretch of being unrealistic with season gangsters that can't shot at a\ntarget that is wearing bright colors; while a bunch of teenagers with\nno marksmanship skills are able to kill people. I do feel disturb\nseeing a bunch of white girls killing a bunch of black people shortly\nafter the Trayvon Martin killings in 2012 in Sunrise, FL. I doubt the\nproducers care. About the people saying its feminist. I really doubt\nthat, too. Killing men isn't feminist. It's more sexism than ever.\nOverall: I have to say, Spring Breakers isn't the worst movie ever, but\nit's no way, good.\n"

                "reviewTotalVote": "3",
                "reviewUseful": "3",
                "reviewUserRating": "3",
                "reviews": "\nThis film largely gets a bad press. It is criticised heavily and pushed\nto the sidelines, but when I watched it I wondered why. I loved it. I\nmean I can understand why so many people hate it, it's an easy film to\ncriticise, it's not perfect by any means, but at the same time there's\na very special meaning to much of it which is delivered in a very\ndifferent way to other meaningful films. I think that this message is\nhugely overlooked in this film and as such this work bludgeoned by film\ngoers. It provides a subtle and neat critique\nof all that is wrong with our modern selves; the now factor, the\npsychopathic lack of remorse for actions, the party as hard as you can,\nthe vulgarity and tackiness of the pursuit of money.                 "reviews": "\nIf you are approaching this film expecting an experience following the\nprinciples of naturalism and realism, you'd pick up on the plot and\ncharacter flaws almost straight away and perhaps miss the more artistic\ntechniques . But for me this film felt like an artistic attempt at\npointing out the obvious and being quite boring in its doing so. I\nappreciate that the film aims to identify and expose the consumerist\nand media-fuelled world that we now live in, especially for its target\naudience, which I took to be young adults around the age of college\n(Uni) study. For example, Alien's repetition of the words 'spring-break\n(forever)' reflects the repetition of marketing slogans and\nadvertisements that attempt to persuade us that whatever being sold is\namazing and perfect. Director Harmony Korine also highlights the\ndisenchantment of sex and the loss of sexual privacy; it is continually\nassociated with money in this film, as are most things, but it's also\nperformed in public (swimming pool), illustrating its cheap value and\ncommon practice in modern youth culture and media."
            },
            {
                "reviewAuthor": "natmckn",
                "reviewDate": "12 August 2013",
                "reviewTitle": "Ignore the hate, and enjoy the ride.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "7",
                "reviewUseful": "5",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\nI'm sure there's a lot of detractors who would call it \"sexist\" or\n\"exploitative\" or whatever, but that's not what's important. What's\nimportant is that this movie is BORING. Sure, it's well produced, but\nwhat does that matter when you have a two hour movie with maybe three\nscenes worth mentioning? And going back to that controversial stuff,\nthere's been some debate as to whether it's female empowerment or\nsexist exploitation. I've heard it argued both ways. In fact, I watched\nthis in a film class I'm taking, consensus seemed to be that it was\nsome sort of commentary on how the kind of life you see in music videos\nmakes for a nice fantasy, but isn't all it's cracked up to be. While I\ncan say there's some merit to that theory, as it certainly feels like a\ntwo hour long music video (and I say that as a bad thing), frankly, I\nhave a bit of a tendency to take things at face value. I would honestly\nsay the writer/director (whom I can't remember the name of) just\ndecided to make the movie sleazy and exploitative as a substitute for\nactually having anything interesting going on. And since it made more\nthan 4 times its budget at the box office, apparently it worked! I\nguess there's a market for two hours of horny women in bikinis doing\ndrugs and committing crimes! As a gay male, it's clearly one I'm not\nin."

                "reviewAuthor": "georgeolds",

                "reviewTitle": "More than liked it",
                "reviewTotalVote": "9",
                "reviewUseful": "6",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nSpring Breakers by Harmony Korine is a very polarizing film. I\nthoroughly enjoyed myself when I watched this movie. The only reason\nfor this was because I knew exactly what I was in for. A lot of people\nthought it was going to be a deep, meaningful movie with a complex plot\nthat comments on today's society. These people were wrong! Spring\nbreakers is a true black and white film that shows what can happen on\nspring break. It was very visually interesting and the violence and\nsexuality was extremely prominent, but what else can you expect from a\nspring break movie. There will obviously be sex and drugs. The acting\nwas decent and the plot was not the greatest, but it was still a great\nmovie. Anybody who saw this movie for the cast or to discover the\nhidden meanings behind it were disappointed because that's not what\nthis movie was made for. Yes this movie has some big names, but if\nthat's all you saw this movie for or all you will see this movie for\nyou will hate it! You have to know what to expect when seeing a movie\nand you can't always expect perfection (you can't expect Lord of the\nRings from a movie like Napoleon Dynamite!) Spring Breakers was not\nperfect, but it was a damn good movie! So just keep in mind that this\nisn't for everyone and keep an open mind while watching it and you'll\nprobably like it too.\n"

                "reviews": "\n\nThere is a school of thought that says all movies should be compared on an\nabsolute scale.  It would say that movies must have a high level of\ncredibility or familiarity in order to be \"good\" movies.  People who fall\ninto this category simply should not watch Top Gun.  They won't enjoy it.\nOther people take the opposite, but no more valid approach of looking a\neach\nmovie individually, disregarding all else but the movie.  For these people,\nno outside reality or credibility is important, because for them, a movie\nexists to entertain in whatever way it chooses to.  These people would\nenjoy\nTop Gun very much.  It is extremely doubtful that the producers ever even\nconsidered making Top Gun as a portrait of a fighter pilot's life, and this\nis why it is entertaining.  It is a rare type of movie, one that no one\ndares to make today, one that not only transcends reality, but wears it as\na\nmask into the world of fantasy.  Everything from the wild dogfights to the\nfake love to the over the top glamorized (or should I say canonized)\ncharacters lets you know that this is a good old American hero drama.  That\nis why it is a horrible and fraudulent portrait of reality, and that is why\nI love it.\n"

However the story does work\nwell\nin drawing you into the world of Maverick and his fellow naval aviators,\nCruise forms an excellent rapport with Anthony Edwards as Goose, and the\ndialogue is snappy and eminently quotable. The film is backed by\none\nof the best soundtracks of the decade, and a very strong supporting\ncast.\nIn my opinion, the film succeeds in everything it sets out to achieve. A\ncracking script, a gripping story, and simply stunning aerial photography.\nYou have to see this film.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "Rusty F. Ammerman (magicmanra@aol.com)",
                "reviewDate": "30 May 2005",
                "reviewTitle": "A film that holds a special place in my heart.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "11",
                "reviewUseful": "7",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nTop Gun is a big piece of 1980s cheese. Definitely a Hollywood product,\nit was however very successful at the box office. The success is mostly\ndue to the action and to Tom Cruise and his winning smile. The aerial\ncombat shown in Top Gun is exciting, but it's not always logical or\nconsistent (shooting down Soviet fighter planes would result in war in\nreal life). What makes it better is the film's soundtrack. Catchy\nupbeat rock & pop songs back the action and the romance on screen.\nThat's pretty much the film's appeal. There are plenty of faults, but\nin the end it's entertaining and makes one feel good. The fighter pilot\nlife seems so appealing in Top Gun that registrations to join the navy\nin the USA went up significantly after the film was released. According\nto the film in order to become one of the top fighter pilots in America\nyou have to be a) a male b) have an attitude c) be good-looking d) be a\ngood fighter pilot. Oh, and you have to believe that America is always\non the side of good. Come to think of it, was there even a brunette in\nthe film? It seemed to me like all the women were blondes. Yeah, but at\nleast the dogfights are some of the best in film history. There's no\nTop Gun program in reality though. Still, while you're there \"playing\nwith the boys\" you feel cool and like you belong. Val Kilmer makes an\nimpression, but it turns out he didn't want to be in the film. He had\nto play the role of Tom \"Iceman\" Kazansky because of contract\nobligations. Top Gun is not a bad film. Even if everything in it is by\nthe numbers it's still a notable 1980s flick (in my opinion \"Take My\nBreath Away\" is an annoying and corny song). The film is bright, it's\naction-packed, it's sometimes touching, it's at times funny. I\nrecommend it.\n"

The royal was part of a\nfamily looking for profit from creating life on suitable planets which\nare then farmed for their body fluids to produce immortal bath salts\nfor those who can pay. Cra* concept and an even worse script,\ndirection, and character development has resulted! It is all CGI, but\nfor what? The characters are totally uninteresting. Even the evil\noffspring of the dead royal, who just ooze 'orribleness and are of\ncourse played by British actors (including star of the moment Eddie\nRedmayne!), are one-dimensional. The hero, half wolf, half man,\nChanning Tatum, remains stony faced and just jets about on a set of\ngravity boots better than Superman! The only interest is Sean Bean and\nwhether he will last beyond the second reel. From the trailer he looked\ncertain for an early demise but he keeps hanging on! The script is just\na series of bang crashes, and scenes of jeopardy for our two leads and\nhow are they going to get out of them - yawn, yawn! The CGI is boring\ninside two minutes. And the whole film is a derivative sham. You will\nrecognise 'Star Wars' 'North by North West' 'Jurassic Park 2'\n'Superman' 'Flash Gordon' and particularly 'Dune' as well as many\nothers. Oh, it is truly awful!!!!!!!!!!"

                "reviewDate": "3 May 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Paints a great socioeconomic picture",
                "reviewTotalVote": "10",
                "reviewUseful": "7",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nAlright, this is my first review of a movie. I read so many reviews\nabout this film, and so many of them are saying how much the movie\nsucks. Here is why I think the movie does not suck: The plot of the\nmovie and the story behind it paints a picture of our world (Earth)\ntoday and its socioeconomic mindset, but on a mind boggling universe\ngrand scale. It makes you think how vast the universe is, how many\nspecies (perhaps or most certain) there are out there with more advance\ntechnologies than ours, and it makes you ask yourself: \"If what they\nare doing in the movie, the fact that royalties harvest entire planets\nfor their personal interest and profit, is morally wrong, then why are\nwe humans doing or allowing the exact same thing happening on our own\nplanet? We use each other and that needs to stop. We all share this\nplanet and we need to learn how to co-exist with nature and all life on\nit. What could've been better in the movie is the evolution of the\nplot. It happened too fast and it felt like some parts were missing.\nEither the movie should have been longer in that case, which I would\nnot prefer, or some fighting and action scenes should have been shorter\n(some of those last as long as 5 minutes of pure action - a bit too\nlong). The special effects where outstanding throughout the movie\nexcept in rare occasions it was indistinguishable of what is going on.\nTatum did an OK job, not an outstanding performance but not so bad\neither. Mila Kunis was a bit \"cold\" at times. So to sum it up, the\nreason I gave it an 8/10 is mainly because the plot although it felt\nlike it missed some parts, and the action scenes were a tad too long.\nOther than that, the movie paints a great socioeconomic picture we all\ncan learn from.\n"

                "reviews": "\n\nI happen to be one of the folks who really has enjoyed these films in the\nprequel trilogy. What has been bothering me\nhas been some of the reasons people are giving for hating these new films...\nthey are childish, they have too many special-effects, the acting is bad,\nthe writing is bad, Lucas has sold out and has lost his touch... it makes me\nwonder if people are actually remembering the original trilogy correctly. \nDon't get me wrong, I love the original trilogy, but they weren't exactly\nwell-acted or well-written movies.  We didn't love them because they were\nthese great Shakespearian works of art; we loved them because we were little\nkids totally enraptured by this exciting fantastical world.  It seems that\nthose same kids that loved the films 20 years ago have grown up into stuffy\nold yuppies that have no idea how to have fun anymore.  Our generation has\ngrown up and it seems that we wanted Star Wars to grow up with us, to morph\ninto some new R-rated grown up version to satisfy our more mature needs. \nWell, we didn't like the original trilogy because it was all grown up and\nserious.  We liked it because it was silly and fun and awesome to look at. \nI am personally glad that George Lucas did not make the prequels into a new\ngrown up version.  I like the adventure and excitement and I challenge the\none major complaint that says that they do not live up to the originals. \nLet's look at what people have complained about when comparing these to the\noriginal trilogy."

                "reviewAuthor": "The_Crow666",
                "reviewDate": "3 June 2005",
                "reviewTitle": "An insult to the great original Star Wars Trilogy.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "185",
                "reviewUseful": "102",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nThis is a film that took three of the most beloved films of all time\nand sold their souls to CGI. The original Star Wars Trilogy were not\nlabelled as the greatest films ever made because of Light Sabres, or\nStorm Troopers, or groundbreaking motion capture special effects, but\nbecause of the human side. The quality of the acting from Sir Alec\nGuinness, the chemistry between Harrison Ford and Carrie Fisher, the\nexcellent dialogue that made every line a memorable quote and the\ncontext of faith and religion are what made them so everlasting. In\nthis film Ewan McGregor's acting is surprisingly wooden for such a\ntalented actor, Hayden Christensen has less chemistry with Natalie\nPortman than a 12 year old student's test tube, the dialogue is boring,\nthe lines are cheesy and clich\u00e9d, there does not seem to be any actual\nemphasis on plot, it just being an excuse to glue one over-long action\nset piece to another, so the intrigue disappears fast and the themes\nand contexts are given a back seat to (admittedly impressive) CGI. It\nseems that George Lucas thought that what made a good film was as much\nsoulless eye candy as possible."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Roland E. Zwick (magneteach@aol.com)",
                "reviewDate": "12 June 2002",
                "reviewTitle": "not up to par but worth seeing",
                "reviewTotalVote": "127",
                "reviewUseful": "69",
                "reviewUserRating": -1,
                "reviews": "\n\nSay what you will about George Lucas, you have to give the guy credit for\nsetting himself a difficult task in `Star Wars: Attack of the Clones' (and I\ndo mean beyond trying to deliver a film that will meet the almost impossibly\nhigh expectations of his millions of fanatical followers).   By choosing to\nplace Anakin Skywalker front and center as the story's main focal point,\nLucas does what few others in this business are willing to do \u0096 which is to\nrisk making a crowd-pleasing epic without a likable central `hero.'  After\nall, since this film is a prequel and not a sequel to the original trilogy,\nwe all know that this brooding young man will end up turning into the\nirredeemably evil Darth Vader.  Of course, Luke Skywalker fulfilled the\nrequirements of conventional hero for the original series and even Han Solo,\nthough he was a bit of a rogue and a scoundrel, always allowed his virtuous\nside to break through when the chips were down.  Anakin, though, for all his\ninternal struggles in this film, is predestined to go over to the Dark Side\n(certainly in the next installment).  The pre-knowledge the audience is\nprivy to from our acquaintance with the later chapters gives the film a kind\nof poignant sadness at times - or at least it would if Lucas had done a\nbetter job as both writer and director in bringing it out.  Unfortunately,\nthe dialogue is so poorly written that Anakin comes across as little more\nthan a petulant, peevish, moony-eyed schoolboy most of the time \u0096 hardly\neither the `greatest Jedi knight' we keep being told he has the potential to\nbecome nor the future Hitlerian dictator we know he will one day be.   His\nromantic, puppy-love interludes with Senator (former Queen) Padme Amidala\nare embarrassing at best.  We have indeed come a long way from the fun love\ntriangle involving Luke, Han and the feisty Princess Leia."
            },
            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Daniel Loe",
                "reviewDate": "19 June 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Slow at times, but the story and action make up for the flaws",
                "reviewTotalVote": "10",
                "reviewUseful": "10",
                "reviewUserRating": "7",
                "reviews": "\n*WARNING MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS* If you remember, I was one of the few\nwho did not hate The Phantom Menace, in fact, I gave it a positive\nrating. If you'd like to get a different opinion on the prequels,\nplease be sure and check that review out as well, but now, let's talk\nabout The Attack of The Clones. This movie has a few rough spots,\nHayden Christensen and Natalie Portman don't have very good chemistry\ntogether, despite both of them giving decent performances in the rest\nof the movie. No, Hayden Christensen isn't that bad, he's a bit wooden,\nbut I think he plays a believable confused young man who has been\nisolated all his life. In fact, I think that most of the hate\nsurrounding Christensen is less about how he plays his role, and more\nabout what role he's playing. People don't want Vader to be a bitter\nand over- reacting teenager, but in the scenes where Christensen is\nable to show who he'll become, he's great. Besides, this is all about\nhow Anakin becomes Vader, he can't start out as Vader in Episode II.\nThe movie also gets heat for other stuff, too boring, too much CGI,\netc. The CGI effects look great, it makes it look like a more advanced\nculture, by having surroundings that we can't yet physically create.\nNow, maybe a few practical effects wouldn't have been amiss, but I\nthink the use of CGI is a relatively minor complaint, and one that\ndoesn't really effect the over-all quality of the film. The plot may be\nslow at times, but don't forget, we have lots of action in here as\nwell. A full scale battle at the end, a high speed chase through\nCourscant, a duel between Obi-Wan and Jango Fett, etc. Yes there are\nslow stretches, but there are also plenty of scenes that are really\nfun. I know Yoda fighting with a light-saber, you know, a Jedi's\nweapon, is supposed to be just like heresy or something, but I can't\ntake that complaint seriously. How else would Yoda have fought? With a\nstick? It's not like he doesn't use the force or anything! But enough\nwith the negatives, let's talk about why this movie is genuinely good.\nEwan McGregor as Obi-Wan is great! He brings the right level of\nsophistication and intelligence to the character, while still managing\nto seem like a less experienced version of the character in A New Hope.\nJango Fett is a really good villain, he brings in great action and is\njust over all a really cool character. I already said I like Hayden\nChristensen, who I think accurately displays youth, and provides a\nrelate-able character for everyone who's ever been a teenager ever. The\naction is top-notch as well. The speeder chase on Courscant is a great\nstart to the movie; humor, good effects, and very fast-paced. The\nfinale is very well done also, and it's a blast to see the first full\nscale battle in a Star Wars movie (the gungans don't count). The story,\nthought admittedly a bit muddled, is interesting enough (let's be\nhonest, Star Wars isn't story based, it is driven by characters and\naction). I understand very few will agree with this review, but I\nwanted to give my own opinion on the Star Wars movies, so, I started\nreviewing them. I'll try to have my Revenge of the Sith review up soon!\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Steve Ellesmore",
                "reviewDate": "16 May 2004",
                "reviewTitle": "Episode II \u0096 Attack of the Clones - Exhilarating!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "62",
                "reviewUseful": "35",
                "reviewUserRating": -1,
                "reviews": "\n\nAfter what many perceived to be a weak entry in the prequel trilogy of\nthe star wars movies with regards to TPM. Lucas still 'did his own\nthing' and produced one of the most breathtaking, exhilarating and\nfantastic star wars films to date. In this film we have already\nestablished characters thrust upon the cinema screen once again. The\nopening scroll is simpler than in TPM, it doesn't require us to think,\nit just puts us into the right frame of mind to pick up the story. As\nsoon as we see a ship gliding through the foggy clouds we see straight\naway that something is amiss in the republic. The bright and breezy\nrepublic in the previous film seems to be bathed in fog. Difficult to\nsee the dark side is. Lucas said these are silent movies and the\nvisuals tell their own story and it happens a lot in this film, like\nthe Darth Vader silhouette that had no digital tinkering whatsoever .\nThe footage of Anakin with his robes on was basically a mirror image of\ndarth vader but without the helmet. The footage of Padme next to him\nwas strikingly reminiscent of Emperor Palpatine in Return of the Jedi.\nAbsolutely everything in this movie is intriguing, Obi-Wan Kenobi\ninvestigates a clone facility on the planet of Kamino. A mysterious\nSifo Dyas placed an order for the Clone army based on a template of a\nBounty Hunter called Jango Fett. Jango Fett states he was employed by a\nman called Darth Tryannus. We find a former Jedi, Count Dooku knows all\nabout the corruption in the senate, even if the Jedi arnt yet aware and\nplans to do something about it. Secretly creating a new order with the\ngoal to build an army powerful enough to fight the Republics army. A\nrepublic army which was mysteriously started at the Clone facility even\nthough the Jedi Council were not aware! Confused? No\u0085intrigued? Most\ndefinitely. Anakin Skywalker also gets given a sole mission on his own.\nIts here that the much vaunted love story begins. To be honest, it's a\nbit choppy and seems rushed. Its not a smooth romance like in The\nEmpire Strikes Back, instead it's a romance which reeks of desperation,\nas if the characters themselves know about their impending doom and\nthey just want to be as one before the inevitable happens. The deleted\nscenes on the DVD really should have been implemented within the film.\nThey are gold, with regards to character motivations and shows little\nglimpses of their affection to each other. Would have made the final,\ndeclaration of love scene less jarring. In fact, would have been\ncompletely smooth and believable. The final showpiece in this film is\nthe Clone Wars, they begin on a planet called Geonosis and this is\nwhere the film gives us a scene so wonderful it just keeps on piling\nthe cherry's on top of the cake. A superb full scale war better than\nanything in any star wars movie happens, its absolute mayhem and its\nabsolutely brilliant. But it doesent end there, we have not one\nlightsaber fight, not two, but three. With the third being one of the\nmost memorable of all time. Also, a plot point that culminated in A New\nHope makes its entrance here and it left me absolutely gob smacked\nBasically, this film is everything you would want in a star wars movie.\nIs it the best star wars film out there? Quite possible, difficult to\ncall. Had George Lucas just gone with the flow and put in the\nPadme/Anakin deleted scenes plus toned down the over bearing nature of\nAnakin in the fireplace scene (after reading an earlier draft there's\nsome vocal foreplay at the beginning that would have been great to have\nin the final movie) then this would have been the best Star Wars film\nwithout a doubt. We see intrigue, we see action and we see the galaxy\nbegin to rot away in a very obvious way. The beginning of the end."

                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nStar Wars Episode II: Attack Of The Clones is the eagerly anticipated\nsequel to Star Wars Episode I: The Phantom Menace. After three years\nsince the original let-down, we find out that this one won't include\nJar Jar Binks as a central character, or won't have an irritating ten\nyear old who'll play Anakin Skywalker, we even see a glimpse of what\ncould be everyone's favorite bounty hunter, Boba Fett! We all reassure\nourselves that Star Wars would get better now, and stay true to that\nclassic style we all cherished. But the same thing with The Phantom\nMenace occurred again, most fans didn't like the movie for reasons\nwe'll explain throughout this review. This movie, like The Phantom\nMenace suffers from a bad script, though not as bad as The Phantom\nMenace's. Firstly the dialog between Obi Wan Kenobi and Anakin\nSkywalker in the elevator scene at the start of the film. It's a nice\nlittle bit where the two exchange words about their previous adventures\ntogether and show a friendship. Though we as an audience don't know\nwhat they're talking about because we haven't seen those adventures.\nGeorge Lucas can't just simply explain to us that in that one minute\nscene that they're friends, you have to show it in the actual movie,\nlike they did with the Lethal Weapon franchise. Like when Martin Riggs\nreminds Roger about the time he was stuck to a toilet in case a bomb\nwent off in part 2, the two smile remembering that bizarre moment and\nwe as an audience remember it too, relating to the friendship. Here the\nscript takes one short scene in an elevator to tell us that the two are\nfriends because... They were meant to be good friends according to Obi\nWan's story to Luke in Episode IV. Then for the rest of the movie they\ndo there own separate things showing concentration in the wrong area.\nObi Wan's off finding this Clone Army on the planet Kamino and Anakin's\non Naboo protecting Padme from an assassination. Now people criticize\nthe film for Anakin's (Hayden Christensen's) acting performance in the\nfilm, but this is a false claim. The actor does very well if the right\nscript is given to him, the bad acting is a result of poor direction by\nGeorge Lucas. For some reason the love story dialog between Padme\nAmidala (Natalie Portman) and Anakin is so horrible because... Of the\nway Hayden Christensen says the lines!? Almost every character in this\nmovie has to say stupid lines too, why does all the critique come down\nupon Hayden!? Although Ewan McGregor as Obi Wan makes his lines sound\nmuch better, seeing that he is in fact a better actor. Now another\nreason why everyone dislikes this movie is in fact for the love story,\nthey say it's awkward and forced but we say it's beautiful though very\nclich\u00e9d. There really is no problem with the love story other than it's\nclich\u00e9d as hell, and that great John Williams score doesn't help\neither! But with all the beautiful backdrops and locations, who cares,\nwe think it's perfect how Anakin and Padme fall in love. The movie also\nuses too much CGI, but it makes for some thrilling action scenes, this\nmovie has he best actions scenes out of the whole entire saga. It's got\nthe Bounty Hunter chase through Coruscant, Obi Wan VS Jango Fett, the\nJedi Battlle in that arena, the beginning of the Clone Wars, and Yoda's\nepic light saber duel. Although Yoda having a light saber totally\nclashes with everything he stands for in Episode V, it's still pretty\ncool to see him whipping out and wielding his very own light saber.\nThen Jango Fett, the father of Boba is also a very cool addition to the\nStar Wars Saga, we maybe even prefer him to Boba, just for his awesome\nbattle with Mace Windu on Geonosis. It is also interesting to see\nChancellor Palpatine take his first step into becoming the Emperor in\none of the ending scenes, as he controls the Clone Army. Another great\nthing about the film is Anthony Daniels as C-3PO, back in his old comic\nself again. But another major flaw is the brief relationship between\nAnakin and Owen Lars. At the end of Revenge of the Sith he receives the\nchild of his stepbrother (Anakin) from a guy he didn't even know (Obi\nWan). Anyway, comparing these positives, Attack of the Clones is a\nthrilling space adventure film featuring new awesome planets we love\nlike Kamino and Geonosis. It pushes the action to new heights, and is\nour personal favorite of the saga, making it number one. Though for\nsome reason George Lucas writes Anakin as a bad apple. Anakin is not\nmuch like Luke Skywalker at all, for he is not totally being a good guy\nin this film, this is seen after his mothers death when he mindlessly\nslaughters countless Tusken Raiders. And when he attempts to run at the\nmovies' villain with a light saber with hate and anger! Though there\nare some scenes where he's kind-hearted, most of it is just him being\narrogant, but this doesn't really bother us. Another great thing about\nthe film is Count Dooku, he makes the film very enjoyable but the\nslightly UN-EVEN pacing of the film makes him enter a full hour in!\nEpisode II is an epic story that goes in depth at the look of how the\ndeath of Anakin's mother will influence his fall to the dark side and\nhow his love for Padme will cross a forbidden Jedi rule. The only thing\nwrong with this film, that bugs us enough to point out is the\nrelationship between Obi Wan and Anakin, which should have been\nexpanded. Nonetheless Episode II is the strongest of the saga but\nsuffers from an onslaught of under-ration by fans just because of a few\nreasons they that can't even explain...\n"

The galaxy's in a real\nturmoil, because of the separatists that want to leave the Republic. The\nstory has a wonderful pace I'd like to compare with Episode IV. There's\nnot\na single second one feels bored or one feels strange about anything. All\nthe\ndifferent subplots are developed perfectly and find their climax in a\ngigantic battle in the end of the movie.\nThe actors all deliver excellent performances. Especially Hayden\nChristensen's performance marks the perfect portrayal of the later Darth\nVader. You can really feel his inner battle with the dark side. He is a\ngood\nperson with a good heart, but certain things make him turn. In Episode II,\nduring one of the highlights of the movie, Anakin is confronted with his\nfirst dark actions. The Jedi-Master shows the audience why he is the greatest\nJedi of all time and also proves that the advance of digital animation\ncan't\nbe stopped...... The Special Effects are totally exciting, excellent and\nbrilliant, but\nthey never stand above the story, no, they drive the story forward and\nunderline all the aspects of the movie. The CG-characters in this movie\nlook\nso realistic (especially Yoda) that you just won't believe it. Compared\nwith\nSpider-Man (a very good movie, too!) where the animated Spider-Man can be\nrecognized during a lot of scenes as an animation Episode II's\nCG-characters\ninteract perfectly with the real actors. And talking about technical\naspects...... I didn't see any hint that the pictures were entirely shot\ndigitally!\nThe picture looks brilliant, colourful and very rich!\nThe sound effects are superb and John Williams' score perfectly underlines\nthis motion picture experience!\nWhat else to say than well, I already have my tickets for the midnight\npremiere on Wednesday/Thursday and I'll again enjoy a hell of thrill-ride\nwatching this movie that tells us a story of good versus evil from a long\ntime ago in a galaxy far, far away...\nMay the force be with you!                 "reviewUseful": "62",

                "reviews": "\nWith the imminent \"Avengers\" movie coming next year, only one hero's\norigin story remains untold\u0085until now. Falling in line with \"Thor,\"\n\"Iron Man,\" and \"The Incredible Hulk,\" \"Captain America\" showcases the\nrise of Steve Rogers as the title character. Unlike the other films,\nwhich take place in modern times, this one goes way back to WWII,\nshowing the Captain kicking Nazi butt! With a lot of \"Wolfenstein\"\nstyle occult mystique and a slight \"Indiana Jones\" sense of adventure,\nthis movie has a number of solid action sequences, and plenty of\nimaginative special effects and setpieces. With its references to\nvarious characters and concepts of other Mavel movies, it fits into the\nfranchise really well. It might take some stretch of the imagination to\nbelieve that Nazis could be this futuristic, but for a superhero movie,\nit's all good fun."

                "reviewAuthor": "ministryman678",
                "reviewDate": "24 July 2011",
                "reviewTitle": "Clich\u00e9's Tour de Force",
                "reviewTotalVote": "222",
                "reviewUseful": "119",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nI knew nothing about Captain America prior to viewing this Marvel film.\nMany people were skeptical about Chris Evans being cast as the man in\nred, white, and blue mainly because he is previously known for playing\nJohnny Storm in the not so fantastic Fantastic Four movies. Despite,\nthe fact that he had a lot of pressure going into this film, I thought\nhe did a fare job. I personally don't think this was the best Avengers\ntie in movie but it was fine. The first half of the movie did a very\ngood job of establishing the story behind the creation of this man and\nhow he was initially just an experiment and then turned into a\npropaganda piece for the war in order to excite people and inspire them\nto fight the fight. Afterward, when he finally does take initiative and\nattempts to infiltrate and destroy the enemy, the movie turns into a\npretty standard and generic action movie. Hugo Weaving is cast as the\nvillain known in the comics as the Red Skull. Despite a good looking\nface (a red face), he never really becomes too menacing and isn't given\nenough screen time as the red skull to really effect us. Tommy Lee\nJones is in his realm as an army commander who is in charge of\noperations including Rogers and is very funny as well as delivering the\nlines extremely well. Speaking of lines, this movie doesn't have the\nbest or worst script and I think they (the writers) could have spent\nmore time developing better dialogue that didn't sound so rushed.\nDirector Joe Johnston who is know for The Rocketeer brings the 1940s\nWorld War feeling to the screen brilliantly and with great set\ndesigners and art direction. Tony Starks father plays a fairly\nsignificant role as the man behind the suit and weapons of the Captain.\nPlayed by Dominic Cooper, we get an inside look at how Stark got his\nattitude and knack for building new technology. The 3D added nothing,\nwhich is not unusual nowadays. The only time it was ever apparent was\nwhen the shield was thrown towards the screen which happened maybe\ntwice. This movie does a nice job of finishing the tie in movie for the\nupcoming epic Avengers movie die to release next year. My only hope is\nthat all of this build up with the individual super hero movies is not\nwasted. This is worth a rental and I will probably buy this on blu-ray\nwhen the price is greatly reduced.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "C. Sean Currie (hypestyle)",

                "reviewTitle": "Captain America has star spangled Action",
                "reviewTotalVote": "48",
                "reviewUseful": "30",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\n\"Rocketeer\" director Joe Johnston's \"Captain America\" amounts to a\ntimeless David versus Goliath tale set in the Marvel Comics' universe\nwhere good always trumps evil. Unlike \"Thor\" and \"Green Lantern,\"\n\"Captain America\" ranks as a thoroughly spectacular but\nlarger-than-life extravaganza with a genuinely charismatic hero\nstruggling against a marvelously malignant villain. Chris Evans'\nengaging performance as the 'First Avenger' is something else, too! If\nyou recall, Evans had the time of his life several years ago playing\negotistical Johnny Storm, aka 'the Human Torch,' in the two \"Fantastic\nFour\" flicks. Make no mistake; Evans is nothing like he was in those\ntwo super heroic sagas. Indeed, \"Captain America\" boasts some amazing\nspecial effects, but its best special effect is the sincerity that\nEvans brings to the role of Steve Rogers. Whether he plays Rogers as\neither a scrawny, 98-pound zero or a brawny, fleet-footed hero, Evans\nimparts heart to this $140-million thriller. During the first half of\n\"Captain America,\" Johnston gradually builds the momentum to let us\ngrow accustomed to Evans as a scrappy little fellow who suffers the\nwrath of bullies. This pathetic weakling refuses to let anybody keep\nhim down, and it's fun because Evans makes it look so authentic despite\nthe obvious CGI effects. Hugo Weaving registers as the ideal villain\nwho holds the upper hand throughout most of the supercharged\nshenanigans. Tommy Lee Jones and Hayley Atwell co-star respectively as\nCaptain America's superior and his love interest."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "DonFishies",
                "reviewDate": "31 July 2011",
                "reviewTitle": "A wildly entertaining summer adventure",
                "reviewTotalVote": "102",
                "reviewUseful": "55",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nAnother perk of serving our country... an advance screening of a great\nfilm! Intelligent comic-book popcorn epics are rare and this one is\ndefinitely a cut above the usual fare. Besides being a tremendously\nsmart and even emotional film, it's also refreshing to see a lead hero\nbe just that... a hero. Steve is no morbid vigilante or narcissistic\nself absorbed anti-hero. He's the real deal. His tough life hasn't made\nhim bitter or jaded. In fact, it's done just the opposite. He's needed\nto develop character because his body didn't develop. This is the key\nto Cap both in the books and in the film. Heart and character trump the\nphysical elements and are what truly makes the character itself\nspecial. Even after he's given the great gift of being a \"super\nsoldier,\" he still continues to do the right thing. It's not to prove\nanything to anyone other than himself because he has a high moral code.\nI love the fact that they choose his character for the experiment\nbecause he wouldn't take advantage of the gift. That's smart writing.\nCap's first assignment from the U.S. government is to be the\ncenterpiece in a traveling USO show, building morale and raising money\nfor the war effort. Eventually, he finds he's wasting his new abilities\nand NEEDS to break away on his own to fight the Nazi menace. This\nbrings him to conflict with the awesomely diabolical Red Skull. The\nSkull is one of Marvel's best crazed villains and they captured that\nperfectly. Here, the Red Skull was a guinea pig for a similar Nazi\nsuper soldier experiment that went very wrong. These clashes and\nconfrontations are everything they should be and more. Shades of gray\nare great in film (and there are those tones present here) but\nsometimes it's good to have character of pure heart, pure integrity and\ntrue morality take it to what history and everyone knows was pure evil.\nIt's refreshing to sit back and root for the ultimate good to take it\nto the ultimate bad guys. It's why I loved Raiders of the Lost Ark and\nit's why I now love this film."
            },

Instantaneously\nRogers becomes a poster boy for the Second World War and puts on about\neighty pounds, he now runs faster and is stronger than any other human\non Earth. But he is not alone in his abilities and he soon finds\nhimself embroiled in the war he was so desperate to be a part in. Can\nthe kid from Brooklyn be the hero his larger than life heart preordains\nhim to be? If you're expecting this movie to be full of gross\nAmericanisms and lots of flying the flag basically the ultimate U.S.\npropaganda spectacle and admittedly there is much that would appease\nthe American sensibility. I have to say, Chris\nEvans's leading performance is rock-solid, and the performances by\nHayley Atwell, Tommy Lee Jones and Hugo Weaving are no disappointment\neither. The entire film's production is top-notch, ranging from\nexcellent sound design to eye- popping visuals, to a solid film score\nby Alan Silvestri. Some of the action sequences feel a bit too comic\nbook-ish in my opinion though, and at some point you feel like you're\nwatching a trailer rather than an actual movie. But, nonetheless, at\nother times they are brilliantly executed and I have nothing to\ncomplain about. The driving force of this movie is not delivered trough\naction or CGI though, but trough the emotional connection between the\ncharacters, especially the one between Steve and Bucky, his friend.\nAnyway, I won't be spoiling anything, overall it's a very solid,\nhumorous and action-packed superhero movie, and it's one of the best\nMarvel movies to date. It was a pleasant surprise, and is definitely\nworth the ticket.\n"

                "reviews": "\nAvatar, undoubtedly an amazing experience, will redefine the boundaries\nof modern cinema. The magnum opus of the master craftsman James\nCameroon delivers magical screen realization to innovative imagination.\nIt took over a decade for the fast-paced technology to catch up to\nbrilliant imaginations of James Cameroon.It is the movie of the decade\nin terms of cinematic imagination (even crossing the earlier standards\nset by LOTR trilogy) and movie of the generation in terms of CG. The\nadvantage of Avatar is that the movie not only revolves around the hype\nof $300 million and IMAX 3D, but has an involving political statement.\nIt brings into light, three major issues. Firstly, the movie itself\nstands as metaphor of the US invasion of Iraq. Secondly it unveils\nimperialism's cold blooded face in disrespecting and demolishing\ncultures. Lastly it has a profound green political statement that\ninsists on bio-diversification. Even though it doesn't indulge itself\ninto individualist philosophies, Avatar is not philosophically void. It\nis illuminated (like the illuminating insects and plants of Pandora) by\nthe philosophy of universal identity believed by the Na'vi tribe. The\nconcept of Eywa really matches with the base theory of coexistence of\nmany human civilizations. Some may say story of Avatar is old wine\n(pointing Dances with wolves, The Last Samurai and all). But, the\ninvasion on aboriginal cultures and human civilizations by imperialist\npowers is repetitive - it happened during civil war, it happens in\nIraq. So the story isn't loosing its relevance but deserves the\nretelling."

While there had been other Sci-Fi movies with a theme\nof conflict in outer space, the 'Star Wars' trilogy filled our\nimaginations like no other movies before them. The fantastic, strange\nworlds were presented almost like we were there too. Aliens sitting\naround a tavern, enjoying drinks and speaking in all sorts of\nlanguages. Nothing before had approached the sheer size of the space\nships depicted here, huge cities traveling all over the galaxy. And how\nabout the jump to hyper speed, then disappearing from the screen as the\nspeed exceeds light speed! And the light sabres of the Jedi Knights.\nThe Jedi Knights, a striking parallel to the Japanese Samurai."

In the 1977 Star Wars, there is a clear reliance on simplicity\nin\nsome parts. In The Empire Strike Back, the first\nthing\nthat we are treated to is the traditional scrolling text along a\nbackground\nof stars, depicting what has happened between the last film and this one,\nand reminding us of the things that were mentioned in the last film but\nnever explained."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "KlinePatsy",
                "reviewDate": "5 August 2007",
                "reviewTitle": "The dark heart of Star Wars",
                "reviewTotalVote": "8",
                "reviewUseful": "6",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nStar wars is a Saturday morning breakfast serial, with the upbeat\n'let's have an Olympic medal ceremony' ending...Empire discards the\nfluffiness and moves away from its simplistic predecessor's obvious\nappeal to the child fanbase, without scaring everybody away in the\nprocess. The 2nd Star Wars film takes the original cast and subjects\nthem to 2 hours of major discomfort...A forbidding icy planet replete\nwith nasty creatures. There are ugly bounty hunters, monsters hiding\nout in the depths of asteroid fields, and Luke's foray into the black\nswamp of the Degobah system. It's a more taut, curiously downbeat film\nthat slows almost to a halt in places, as Luke meets the Jedi Master\nwho will teach him the ways of the force. The set pieces more than make\nup for the lack of pace...The opening battle on the Ice planet is a\nvisually effective affair, and the stormtroopers have never looked as\ncool when they don their winter outfits. The asteroid chase and cloud\ncity sequence are visual treats, that take you into the mysterious\nheart of the Star Wars Universe. The character development glues\neverything together. Luke's maturing process in the darkness of\nDegobah..Han and Leia's romantic chemistry, the droids comic relief and\ninterplay with Chewbacca solidifies the group together and establishes\na team spirit that was coming together at the end of Episode IV. The\ncentrepiece of the film is the epic showdown between Luke and\nVader,with that massive revelation, which inevitably ranks as one of\nCinema's all time memorable moments. And it's a great sequence, from\nVader's sobering welcome 'The force is with you young Skywalker, but\nyou are not a Jedi yet' to the almost surreal climax. The forces of\ndarkness loom large at every turn of the film...you get the feeling\nthat the rebels are just slightly out of their depth. There is an\nunderlying menace at work that heightens the dramatic tension..Vader is\nnever as beautifully evil as he is in Empire. We finally see just why\nhe is (Emperor aside) the top dog in the galaxy, as he lays waste to\nhis own generals in ruthless fashion. We get some great new\ncharacters...Han's old buddy Lando Calrissien (sp?) is the slimy\nadministrator of cloud city, who finds himself in a no-win situation,\nand there's the legendary Boba Fett..bounty hunter with balls of steel,\nand an outfit so cool it instantly establishes him as a Star Wars icon.\nAnd of course, the emperor rears his ugly head, and we get a taster of\nhis malevolance. Any faults? It's hard to find much complaint. Some of\nthe dialogue strays into cheeseland, the pace is interrupted with the\ncurious but necessary Degobah scenes, but all in all, the sum of the\nparts adds up to a supremely effective, tightly woven sci-fi drama, the\nmost deliciously dark of all Star Wars movies, and the most mature.\nClassic entertainment, stuck in a time capsule of its own, with enough\nmemorable moments to ensure its place in the higher echelons of cinema\nhistory.\n"
            },

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Sean Lamberger",
                "reviewDate": "5 December 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "A Timeless Space Opera, The Perfect Sci-Fi Epic",
                "reviewTotalVote": "2",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "10",
                "reviews": "\nTop of the line for a majority of Star Wars geeks, and for good reason.\nIt's the ideal melting pot of George Lucas's vast, quirky imagination,\nhis influences' knack for dark, large-scale epics, and his key\ncontributors' determined efforts to retain a central humanism amidst\nall the creatures, effects and operatic indulgences. A wildly ambitious\npicture, it's genuinely amazing just how much territory is covered over\nthe course of two hours. Lucas and company manage to leap from the Hoth\nbattle to Yoda on Dagobah, the asteroid field to Lando and Cloud City,\nbefore finally climaxing with the classic Luke / Vader showdown and\nrevelation. That's an awful lot of set pieces, not to mention some\nseriously powerful plot points, but smooth talking and a few\noutstanding performances keep the film from feeling over-stuffed or\nunder-explored. The cast, too, grows on an individual basis almost\nuniversally, with Luke wrapping himself in the wisdom of the Jedi, Han\nand Leia developing genuine chemistry and Darth Vader, in a surprise\ntwist that should never have been so effective, actually showing some\nsigns of humanity. Although it can be hammy from time to time, those\nmoments are balanced expertly by a wonderful series of mountains and\nvalleys, to the point that they stop being seen as negatives and\ninstead contribute to the picture's eccentricity. A legendary effort\nthat's just as monumental, entrancing and electric thirty years later,\nit's damn near perfect.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "haosstoposto",
                "reviewDate": "1 October 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "To quote the main character: \u0084It's messy.\"",
                "reviewTotalVote": "354",
                "reviewUseful": "208",
                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nLooper is a film that goes to extraordinary lengths to leave every base\ncovered in its quest to avoid plot holes and inconsistencies and in my\nmind it deals with the problems associated with time travel very well.\nOne thing I liked is that the older Joe is aware of everything the\nyounger Joe is about to do which gives him an edge if they were to do\nbattle. I also liked that the older Joe in true Bruce Willis style\nbypasses the whole idea of trying to work out how and why what is\nhappening is happening by saying he can't be bothered to work it all\nout. As well as the older Joe having the advantage of memory over the\nyounger Joe, the younger Joe in turn has his own advantages which\nbecome apparent. There were several times when I thought I'd worked out\nwhat was going to happen or what a particular character's arc was going\nto be but the film cleverly manipulates its audience, leading them down\nalleyways only to jump out at them from behind and spin them around.\nThere is a nice early twist which gave me a smile and plenty more to\nkeep you guessing right the way to the end. In the end it turns out\nthat time travel plays second fiddle to another phenomenon which I was\npleased by as there was no mention of this in the trailer which I've\nbeen trying to avoid for several weeks. The plot is multifaceted with\neach character having their own reasons for being where they are, when\nthey are and doing what they are doing. It is a dense plot which\nexplores several different ideas and concepts both personal and\nscientific."

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "markdroulston",
                "reviewDate": "27 September 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "Refreshingly original",
                "reviewTotalVote": "287",
                "reviewUseful": "174",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nThis story was written by someone who does not comprehend even the\nbasics of time travel problems and paradoxes. It is a mystery why this\nchaos received so high grades. The plot in short: mafia from the future\nsends their assassination targets into the present to be disposed of;\nin the present there are killers, so called loopers (organized by a\nsadist from the future) who await their targets and kill them. Before\nor later, the looper receives a mission to kill his future self. Some\nof them fail to do so. And then the chase begins. First of all, the\npremise is pretty stupid, to use such advanced technology for such\nmundane goal. In the movie they have explained, that in the future it\nis impossible to get rid of someone without being tracked. It is, as it\nseems, far easier to build a time machine then to avoid tracking\ntechnology from a collapsed society. Then we have a pretty horrifying\n(and illogical) scene of punishment for a failed looper. His present\nself is mutilated and his future self loses his limbs one by one. This\nis wrong, all his wounds have been inflicted in the past so they would\nappear all at once in the future. And it is unresolved if his present\nself has been killed or will they keep him alive for the next few\ndecades without his limbs, until he is sent into the present. Then we\nhave our \u0084hero\", Joe who escapes his captors in the future, escapes his\npresent looper-self and begins his search for a mysterious future mafia\nboss, the elusive \u0084Rainmaker\", who in the future has killed his wife.\nThen begins a \u0084Terminator-rip-off\". Terminator-Joe from the future does\nnot have exact information about Rainmaker, only his date of birth and\nhe manages to narrow his search to only three kids he will have to\nkill. He eliminates two targets and of course, his past self protects\nthe real Rainmaker, the fact that it HAS TO BE KNOWN to his future self\neven before his trip to the past, because it is past, no matter when\nthe audience has find out this. Then the Terminator-Joe eliminates his\nentire (ex-)gang and there is a showdown between him, his present-self\nand the Rainmaker-Kid. The situation is resolved when the present Joe\nkills himself and the Terminator-Joe disappears. Which would set in\nmotion time traveling paradox: Terminator Joe does not exist so he cant\nbe sent into the past and all his actions would be reversed. But no,\nall his actions in the movie remain. The Rainmaker-kid survives and he\nwill grow up not to be mafia boss but exemplary member of future\nsociety. The end. Oh, and this Rainmaker-kid has a Carrie-like\ntelekinetic abilities, which has nothing to do with a plot and is\ncomplete superficial. As for the pacing of the movie, it is horrible.\nWe begin with a bang (literary), then a movie comes to a halt and we\nhave an hour or so pure boredom (or character \u0084development\"). Then we\nhave a final shoot out. All in all a very bad experience, caused by a\nfanboy-hype. If you want to see Bruce Willis travel through time, watch\n\u008412 Monkeys\", a far superior movie in every sense.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "TheSquiss",
                "reviewDate": "25 September 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "This time travel crap; just fries your brain like an egg\u0085\"",
                "reviewTotalVote": "213",
                "reviewUseful": "115",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\n\"Looper\" qualifies as a sordid science fiction thriller about time\ntravel with an awful ending. Stir a little H.G. Wells in with some\nStephen King and add a pinch of \"The Sopranos,\" and you've got the\nbasics of \"Brick\" director Rian Johnson's contrived, unconvincing\nchronicle. Bruce Willis and Joseph Gordon-Levitt are cast as one in the\nsame character in this disappointing actioneer that pits them against\neach other with a no-win outcome. Furthermore, both protagonists emerge\nas more anti-heroic than heroic. If you dismiss the fact these talented\nthespians bear scant resemblance to each other, you must still consider\nthe scarcity of information about a distant future as well as a warped\npremise. These shortcomings constitute the chief flaws in this\nimaginative but predictable sci-fi saga that unfolds in an erratic\nmanner, lacks quotable dialogue, and features one character with no\nqualms about shooting innocent adolescents. By the time this\nuninspired, R-rated, 118-minute, spectacle has worn out its welcome;\nyou have no reason to care about anybody, including an obnoxious\ntelekinetic tyke who doesn't know when to keep his trap shut. Mind you,\nthe future has never appeared more dystopian. Some people are born with\na mutation that enables them to levitate objects, and these fellows\nfind that they can lure facile-minded babes into bed by making quarters\nfloat above the palms of their hands. The economy has hit bottom, and\nvagrancy has become epidemic. Citizens can execute vagrants on the spot\nif they feel so inclined. Any time Hollywood undertakes a time travel\ntale, the filmmakers conjure up some of the ugliest vehicles. While the\ncars and trucks look hopelessly tacky, the motorcycles resemble\nsomething Luke Skywalker might ride. Basically, you see a guy\nstraddling a cylinder with handle bars. Computer-generated special\neffects blur everything beneath his feet so he appears to be cruising\non a cushion of air."

                "reviewAuthor": "Wizard-8",
                "reviewDate": "7 September 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Lightly amusing comedy, I guess",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": -1,
                "reviews": "\nThe idea of doing a comic take on the serious drama \"Training Day\" may\nsound strange at first, but they say there are no bad ideas, just bad\nexecution of ideas. While \"Ride Along\" isn't a bad comedy, at its best\nit is just mildly amusing. I think a big reason why it isn't funnier\nthan it is is due to the screenplay being very predictable. Once you\nknow the premise of the movie, you can pretty much predict what is\ngoing to happen some time before it actually does. The screenplay\n(written by FOUR screenwriters!) should have been wilder in both its\nhumor and with the plot. But as I said, there are still some amusing\nmoments here and there. What really does keep the movie afloat are the\nperformances by the two leads, Ice Cube and Kevin Hart. They both give\nvery appealing performances and show that they are up to the challenge\nof whatever the screenplay and direction could throw at them. It's a\npity, though, that they weren't given much material that was more\nbiting in nature.\n"

                "reviewAuthor": "LeeRob7",
                "reviewDate": "17 July 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "Hart is the Heartbeat of this entertaining but flawed cop flick",
                "reviewTotalVote": "1",
                "reviewUseful": "1",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nAn enjoyable ride in which Kevin Hart keeps you smiling and chuckling\nthroughout with his off-beat comedy and charisma. The same cannot be\nsaid of his counterpart however as Ice Cube is woeful in his leading\nrole, often cheesy and wooden displaying very little acting ability. We\nall know by now to expect poor, wooden acting from Cube but other major\nlet-downs also came in the form of John Leguizamo and Laurence\nFishburn. Set in Atlanta focusing on the strained relationship between\nhardened street cop James (Cube) and his proposed\nbrother-in-law/wannabe cop Ben (Hart), the former takes the latter on a\n24 hour ride along around the city to test his prowess as a law\nenforcement officer and his suitability to marry his beloved sister.\nThe story is tried and tested failing to break any new barriers or set\nthe world alight with the on-screen chemistry between the two main male\nroles often seeming tedious and slow to develop. Hart however keeps at\nit, plugging away with it in his own unique way which goes some way to\nsalvaging the film. What begins tedious ends pretty well as the film\ngets better as you get into it. Hart is the saving grace making this\nmovie entertaining and worth the watch but there is also a good\nsupporting effort from Tika Sumpter playing Hart's/Cube's sister.\nWithout Hart this movie would be a huge flop as it is far from perfect\nyet entertaining and somewhat funny eventually earning its 6/10.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "ironhorse_iv",
                "reviewDate": "6 February 2014",
                "reviewTitle": "Come along on this wild ride. It's going to be a fun trip",
                "reviewTotalVote": "3",
                "reviewUseful": "2",
                "reviewUserRating": "6",
                "reviews": "\nThis buddy cop movie directed by Tim Story, was surprising very funny!\nThe film is about Ben Barber (Kevin Hart) a fast-talking, security\nguard whom has dreams of joining the Atlanta Police Department and\nmarrying his girlfriend, Angela (Tika Sumpter). Tika Sumpter is one\nattractive woman, I have to say. For him to marry her and get a good\nwork in with the Police Department, he has to join his potential\nbrother-in-law James Payton (Ice Cube), an APD cop/detective, on a\n24-hour patrol of Atlanta in order to prove himself worthy of marrying\nAngela. What Ben doesn't know, is that, James is on the hunt for the\nmost ferocious kingpin in the city name Omar. Omar is so terrifying and\nimposing that no one has ever seen his face. I wouldn't spoil it, but\nyou can pretty much, guess who it is, by the opening credits. It's not\nthat hard. It did indeed kinda ruin a lot of the film, for me. I have\nto say, 2014, looks like it's going to be comedian Kevin Hart's year.\nKevin Hart's performance itself is arguably worth the price of\nadmission. I never did like a lot of Kevin Hart's previous films, so I\nwas pretty happy with the results here. He has this charm to his\ncharacter in the film that you can't help not hate. While, Ben Barber\ndoes has his clumsy shtick, it was never as offended as a Jar Jar Binks\npest type of a black stock character. While, he is normally failing in\nattempting to prove himself capable, Ben does invoke some knowledge\nuseful in the case through his knowledge of weapons which he learn in\nvideo games. He was indeed very helpful in the movie. His facial\nexpressions are just funny to watch whenever he is fact with real\ndanger. I didn't find Kevin Hart one bit as annoying as Chris Tucker in\nother buddy cop films. The way, he acts throughout the film from being\na charisma klutz to a tough guy role is hilarious to watch. Reminds me\nof a bit of Eddie Murphy mix with Martin Lawrence. Great comical\ntiming. Ice Cube is pretty much old school Ice Cube in this movie\nplaying a tough, loose cannon cop. I wish there was more character\ndevelopment for him. He was indeed cold and cool. Still, I can't see\nhim as an action star or a real cop. This movie is about Ice Cube\nshowing Kevin some Hart, so you know, predictable that the buddy cop\nstory was going to have a good ending. The opening to the movie was\nvery cheesy with over the top action buddy cop clich\u00e9s like the angry\nsuperior officer and rogue action, no back up cop. In the middle and\nthe end of the film, the humor got more realistic, and the events that\nhappen wasn't off the wall, dumb. While this basic plot line has indeed\nbeen done to death, it mocks previous buddy cops movies by using\nprevious popular movies lines such as 2001's Training Day to 1982's 48\nHrs. The movie does too much talking with few action scenes, but it\ndoes work, most of the time. The Jokes are so prolonged, it takes\nforever to get to the punch line. I was pretty surprise, the film was\npretty tame with the language, surprising since both Ice Cube and Kevin\nHart curse a lot. The 'N' word is rarely used here, and I'm pretty glad\nit wasn't use much in the movie. Plus, most of the jokes here are\ncommon jokes that you might see in any buddy cop movie. There is little\nracism black jokes. There isn't a lot of sexual jokes. Both are rare\nnot to see in African American comedies these days. I have to give the\nmovie props for thinking outside the box. On the other hand, the script\nlends itself to other flaws like odd filler scenes and backstabbing\ntwist, you can tell was coming. The odd double cross was much a\nlet-down, that I wish it didn't happen. Sadly, I have to blame\nmarketing as I have already seen most of the funniest bits in the\ntrailer and coming in. It wasn't as funny as the first time. I wouldn't\nsay this is the funniest film ever, but I have to say, it's the\nfunniest buddy cop movie in a long while. Don't expect anything new,\nRide Along stand out amongst the many buddy cop films made. It could've\nbeen a lot better. Still, it was a pretty good movie.\n"
            },

When they told me\nI learned something about you.\" Jackson (Eastwood) is a Civil War vet\nwho is trying to put his past behind him. When he comes back to find\nhis wife missing he sets out to get her back. This is a pretty good\nwestern with a few neat and original ideas but just never really lives\nup to its potential. There is so much that could have been done with\nthis movie but it seemed to hold back to the point of becoming\nirritating. Eastwood is good in this but the movie seemed to rely on\nthe fact that this is a western starring Clint Eastwood's son rather\nthen trying to succeed on its own merit. All that said, it's not\nterrible and one of the better westerns to come out lately, but based\non the last dozen or so in the genre that's not really saying a lot.\nOverall, a movie that had so much potential but left too much on the\ntable to be as interesting as it could have been. I give it a B-.\n"

            {
                "reviewAuthor": "T largo",
                "reviewDate": "16 December 2015",
                "reviewTitle": "Meticulously crafted psychological thriller Western",
                "reviewTotalVote": "44",
                "reviewUseful": "14",
                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nI saw this movie at the San Diego International Film Festival where it\nwon best picture and I was completely thrown for a loop. A good loop.\nWithout spoiling it for audiences Diablo is nothing like what you\nexpect from a Western and is everything that you ever wanted from one.\nAt the Q and A the director talked about consciously avoiding western\nclich\u00e9s and trying to be authentic whenever he could. The result is\nvisually stunning. Director of Photography Dean Cundey (Apollo 13,\nJurassic Park, Back to the Future) lensed the film. and the\ncinematography is epic. Their use of unique looking aerials to capture\nthe American landscape really helps tell the story and captures the\nworld of the mentally tortured PTSD Jackson (Eastwood's character)\nincredibly well. The movie starts out rather quickly with a big action\nscene and moves from there. Danny Glover makes an appearance here and\ndoesn't disappoint (although I still would have loved to see more of\nhim). But what lacks in Danny's screen time is made up by the always\nimpressive Walton Goggins as the evil highway man Ezra. He reaches deep\nand pulls off a chilling performance reminiscent of some of the most\nevil protagonists from the genre. In contrast to him a young but\ntalented Scott Eastwood rounds out the cast and delivers a capably deft\nperformance chillingly similar to you know who... Diablo delivers a\nsuccessful punch but beware it will be unlike any western you've seen\nbefore. Depending on your taste it could go either way. I myself\nenjoyed it and recommend it.\n"

                "reviewUseful": "35",
                "reviewUserRating": "8",
                "reviews": "\nGladiator! A thrilling tale of a Roman general who must battle against\nall thinkable odds to avenge the death of his family and restore\njustice to the empire. The plot is simple, legendary general Maximus\nDecimus Meridius, after many victorious campaigns and battles wants to\nreturn to his peaceful home in Spain, However the kind, fair and dying\nEmperor Marcus Aurelius wishes to bestow his title on him over his\ncruel son, Commodus. Commodus is understandably annoyed and kills his\nfather calming the title of Emperor. Maximus is sentenced to death\nalong with the rest of his family back at his home in Spain. Maximus\nescapes but is unable to save his wife and son. His loss of will to\nlive makes him an east target for slavers and he is soon sold as a\ngladiator. He fights his way into the coliseum in Rome were he wins\nover the crowd and uses his celebrity status to defy the Emperor, to\nwhom he swears his vengeance for the death of his family, after many\nbattles and political backstabbing he gets his chance to fight the\nEmperor in the Arena."

Film pictures all\nthe gladiators as united against some unnamed enemy over on the other side\nof the arena, thus daintily skirting the more Spartacus-like reality that\nthe gladiators fought and killed each other -- and therefore, presumably,\nwere hard put to have indulged themselves in the kind of emotional ties we\nsee here. When the leading lady (Connie Nielsen, in fact just about the only\nwoman) arranges to meet Crowe privately, she explains for the audience's\nsake that patrician women purchased sexual favors this way all the time.\nSeems to me everybody onscreen would know that already! It's like in The\nMikado where Yum Yum turns halfway toward the audience and says to Nanky Poo\n\"But darling, you forget: in Japan...\" except that in the latter case WS\nGilbert meant it as a joke.                 "reviews": "\n\nIt's starts out like any good epic should with a masterfully filmed and\nexecuted exciting battle sequence that sets up the audience for one of\nthose\nrare Hollywoodian confections that are both entertaining and artsy.\nUnfortunately, it all goes downhill from there. It isn't the performers\nfaults since every single one of them give amazing, emotional, even, at\ntimes, riveting performances (the kinds you should find in better movies)\nand who give the whole picture more class than it deserves. It isn't Hanz\nZimmer's nor Lisa Gerrard's fault since they have composed a score that's\nalmost (and I do mean almost) as unforgettable as the Godfather's. And it\ncertainly isn't Ridely Scott's fault since he yet again succeeds in\nimmersing the audience in the world he has created.\nNo, the ones who are to blame are the people who wrote the saccharine,\nclich\u00e9d, soap-opery script and who, in the process, have wasted all of\nthis\nincredible talent. They should be fed to the lions.\nIt's an entertaining B-movie that could have been a classic. Just like\nTitanic in a way."

                "reviews": "\n\nGladiator is well-made and sports all the frills of a big budget\nproduction\n-- big sets and lotsa extras in good costumery. It is not much more than a combination of Braveheart and Last of\nthe\nMohicans, go to Rome -- to name a couple of more recent films. In effect,\nit\nis hero gets done wrong and his loved ones are killed, so he bides his\ntime\nand gets his revenge.\nI think all of the hurrah behind this film is from Hollywood having little\nelse to offer this year at the Oscars (how else could Chocolat get\nnominated\n--$$$). Since Crouching Tiger is not part of the good ole boy Hollywood\nnetwork, Hollywood is working hard to prevent a foreign film from\nupstaging\nthem. In a different year, this film would not get half the recognition it\nis getting. \n"
            }
