            {
                "reviewAuthor": "Raveesh_Kulshrestha",
                "reviewDate": "3 November 2012",
                "reviewTitle": "A Skyfalling Bond! Watch out !!! Someone help him!...CRASH !!!",
                "reviewTotalVote": "180",
                "reviewUseful": "96",
                "reviewUserRating": "4",
                "reviews": "\nI do love James Bond movies. As soon as the movie was released in\nSpain, I wanted to watch it. So, yesterday, after a light dinner with a\nfriend, I went to the cinema. At first, I was extremely comfortable\nwith the movie. A list of secret agents has fallen into the wrong\nhands, and Bond has to recover the list whatever the cost. M has her\nhead on the line, so, she becomes ruthless and drives her agents into a\ncoldblooded rampage of killing and destruction in order to get back the\nstolen list, including a very uncompassionate approach to her own\nagents if she believes they stand on the way to the mission's success.\nAll starts with some scenes packed of good action in Turkey, where two\nMI6 agents pursue the bad guy, one of these agents being Bond. Finally,\nafter a good chasing and some fights on top of a train, Bond is shot\naccidentally by the other agent (a pretty black woman) on M\ninstructions, and Bond is considered missing in action, supposedly\ndead. Of Course, Bond is not dead, returns to duty after some colourful\nand self-destructive holydays in South America, where he drinks tequila\nshots with a scorpion on his hand(very nice scene), and is unleashed\nagainst the bad guys again, going to Shanghai to capture the mysterious\nbad guy who previously eluded capture in Turkey. We have some very good\nscenes of a shooting in a Chinese skyscraper, the appearance of a very\nbeautiful Asian woman, a Macau prostitute, and some interesting moments\nin a strikingly beautiful and decadent Chinese casino with an arena\nfull of Komodo Dragons and bad guys, which is great\u00a1\u00a1. Then, Bond sets\nsail with the beautiful Asian woman in a magnificent sailing yacht, and\nreaches an abandoned island where the bad guy (Javier Bardem) lives.\nThe good part of the movie ends here. From now on, all loses\ncredibility, does not stand scrutiny, and all is utterly ridiculous. A\nsensation of boredom invaded me and the rest of the audience. We do not\nhear any more about the list of agents, or any other tangible or\nmeaningful plot. A bad guy with mommy issues for M, who feels betrayed\nby her just appears out of the blue, and all he wants is personal\nrevenge. A bad guy with mommy issues is just unfit for a James Bond\nmovie. We wanted to see a bad guy full of plans to control or destroy\nthe world, with some intelligent design that Bond will try to thwart\ndesperately in the last minute. However, we are just given a poor chap\nwho calls M \"Mom\" (I nearly jumped from my seat and puked when I heard\nthis\u00a1\u00a1\u00a1\u00a1), suffers from Oedipus complex and feels betrayed, engaging in\na sort of vengeful killing spree. From this moment the movie rapidly\ndecays into unbearable nonsense, and feels almost like an insult. The\nend is just so bad\u00a1\u00a1\u00a1\u00a1 Basically Bond takes mommy (see M) to his\nancestral home in Scotland in order to kill the bad guy with old\nhunting rifles. The Bad guy arrives with a bunch of thugs and a\nhelicopter, torches the house, and then Bond kills the bad guy with a\nknife without fighting, M dies, and the movie ends. In order to\ncompensate the very poor script and ending, a new M and a new Money\nPenny are given to us, setting the atmosphere for the next movie.\nCasino Royale was very good. Quantum of Solace was not so good. Skyfall\nis very bad. The decreasing quality of this franchise is evident. It\ndoes not work anymore and a new formula is desperately needed.                 "reviews": "\n\nAlthough I am not AS lovestruck with this film as many other reviewers are,\nI did find it an entertaining albeit conscience-churning experience.  From\nDusk Till Dawn really is two films in one.  The first part tells the story\nof the Gecko boys(Not Geico) played by George Clooney and Quentin Tarentino.\n They are escapees from the law and have killed over a dozen people brutally\nalready by the time the film opens.  For me, this tale of how they kill a\ngas station guy and finally abduct a preacher and his two children for their\nRV is the most chilling part of the film.  Clooney plays a guy with little\nmoral conscience well.  Tarentino does a good job too and you can see his\nwit throughout the script.  I found both men very despicable, so I guess the\nacting was good.  The film falls into parody/farce, however, once the the\nwhole gang(the two Geckos and the preacher and his daughter and son)reach a\nstrip club/bar out in the middle of nowhere in Mexico.  What happens here,\nto the uninformed viewer, will be totally unexpected.  Does it work?  To a\ndegree, however, the film really loses momentum and credibility it might\nhave had.  The acting in general is all acceptable.  Harvey Keitel once\nagain shows us why he is such a good actor.  Juliette Lewis is also very\ngood in her role as his daughter.             {
                "reviewAuthor": "pineconequestionmark",
                "reviewDate": "6 February 2006",
                "reviewTitle": "Good movie... until the vampires came along",
                "reviewTotalVote": "16",
                "reviewUseful": "10",
                "reviewUserRating": -1,
                "reviews": "\nIn 1960, Alfred Hitchcock did something unthinkable in the film\n\"Psycho\". Halfway into the movie he killed off the main character (and\nthe film's biggest star), thereby shocking the audience through sheer\nunpredictability while simultaneously changing the expected course of\nthe narrative. A similar trick is employed in \"From Dusk Till Dawn\"\n(although the two films are nothing alike). For the first half the film\nis a kinetic crime thriller, characterised by writer Quentin\nTarantino's trademark witty, hard-boiled dialogue and a clutch of well\ndelineated characters. At the halfway point, the film suddenly switches\nto become an ultra-gory, ultra-violent vampire movie, almost a\nhyperactive homage to \"Night Of The Living Dead\"! It is a jarring\nswitch; the effect is like watching half of two separate movies. There\nis an element of frustration that the serious crime thriller half never\ngets properly resolved, and similar frustration that the horror half is\nnot introduced and built-up logically. But both halves are undeniably\nwell-made and the actors seem to be having a great deal of fun with\ntheir outrageous roles."
            },

                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\n\n\"From Dusk Till Dawn\" is a great crossover between A- and B-movies, that\nonly a genius like Quentin Tarantino could have made possible: there are\ngreat character actors (Harvey Keitel, Juliette Lewis) next to Hollywood\nsuperstars like George Clooney, Salma Hayek or Tarantino himself. Not to\nforget the excavation of almost forgotten cult-,trash- and C-movie actors\nlike Cheech Marin, Fred Williamson, Tom Savini, John Saxon or Michael Parks.\nOf course, \"From Dusk Till Dawn\" is also the only serious horror film of the\n90s, which gave this sickening genre some new impulses. While all those\nteenager flicks like \"The Faculty\" (also directed by Robert Rodriguez) were\nonly rip-offs from their elder examples, FDTD has enough originality to be a\nreal classic! This movie is full of slime and gore, absurd ideas (holy water\nfilled in condoms), although the showdown reminded me a little bit on Peter\nJackson\u00b4s \"Braindead\". Instead you get a great performance from Salma Hayek,\nwho is one of the most erotic women alive! Her dance is one of the most\nunforgettable moments ever featured in a horror film! Many people also find\nit idiotic to combine a gangster story with a splatter flick: well, you\nshouldn\u00b4t take this movie too serious, because \"From Dusk Till Dawn\" is\nnothing else but a B-movie with A-list actors. It exists from his crazy\nideas and the pure fun entertainment! (9/10)\n"

                "reviewUserRating": "9",
                "reviews": "\nIf you haven't heard by now Cloverfield is a film about a giant monster\nattacking Manhattan all seen through the perspective of a\n20-something's hand-held camera. The film has been hyped for months via\nviral marketing, JJ Abrams fan boys, and media coverage/ monster\nspeculation. Did it live up to the hype? The answer is OH GOD YES\nCloverfield is by far the most intense monster film I have ever seen in\nmy lifetime, after the initial 15 minutes of character introduction and\nwhatnot the film does not go 5 minutes without a HOLY CRAP moment.\nConstantly driving you to the edge of your seat at every turn and it\nreally pulls no punches, I was surprised to learn it was rated PG13.\nNow the film is entirely filmed in shaky cam since you cant really\nsurvive a monster attack pushing a trolley around and it just works,\nyou may get motion sickness though so be warned. The camera itself\nbecomes a character of the film as it IS the viewer making everything\nhappening on-screen more and more realistic. Now the acting is amateur\nbut thats for the best considering that the film would have made no\nsense if they had used big name actors/actresses, the characters are\nnot that deep either and mostly serve as fodder, comic relief, moral\nguidance, panic, commentary, puzzlement, a little bit of annoyance, in\nother words they're people surviving a monster attack. The presentation\nis brilliant, the only music heard is in the party and at the ending\ncredits and the special effects are some of the most seamless stuff\nyou'll ever see in a film. The monster itself is actually not seen in\nits entirety only being viewed from different angles for the audience\nto piece it together as the survivors themselves are, you pretty much\nknow as much as they do about everything going on making you actually\nfeel like you're there. Critics compare the film to Blair Witch meets\nGodzilla but it is so much more than that, Cloverfield is the\ndefinitive American Monster Film, best if seen on the opening weekend\njust to hear the audience's reactions not to mention the presentation\nis far greater on the big screen, watch it again to see the things you\nmissed or just to enjoy the ride again, admittedly the shock value will\nwane with multiple viewings but for what it's worth Cloverfield is an\nexcellent piece of film and special effect engineering and is the first\ngreat monster film of the millennium. Its also downright scary at\nparts. 8/10\n"
            },

                "reviewAuthor": "gfarren",
                "reviewDate": "26 January 2008",
                "reviewTitle": "Not Thrilling, Not Intense, But a Head-Ache Giver.",
                "reviewTotalVote": "164",
                "reviewUseful": "104",
                "reviewUserRating": "2",
                "reviews": "\nSpoilers... Really now, what's to spoil? Story lines don't come any\nthinner than this. Synopsis: Huge monster appears out of nowhere,\ndestroys city, everybody dies, the end. There isn't any sense of\ncommitment to the main characters, who after the random, gratuitous\nintro spend their time running around screaming. There is no suspense,\nno explanation, no point. Predictably, the full view of the monster is\nsaved for last, when even the appalling camera work (yes, I KNOW it's\nintentional) can't disguise the mediocre CGI, nor the lack of\ninspiration among the monster-designers. Equally predictable, the nasty\nfoot-soldiers it drops look like big spiders \u0096 contact with which will\nmake you feel ill and eventually reduce you to an Alien-plagiarism. One\ndoes wonder why American filmmakers are so eager to destroy their big\ncities, especially after 9/11 has provided us with bone chilling\nimagery that will make any movie of this kind look silly in comparison\nfor decades to come. Not just silly, actually; the way 9/11-like images\nare opportunistically recycled in this cinematic non-event struck me as\nrather tasteless. A BBC reviewer quite rightly called it 'plain 9/11\nporn'. The makers have worked under the false assumption that 'live',\nshaky camera-work in dark surroundings will lift it all to a high level\nof hip artistry, but really, all it does is give you a headache. Any\ninexperienced klutz suffering from advanced Parkinson would get\nsteadier handycam images than the guy supposedly holding the thing\nduring these exasperating 75 minutes. It's all a very poor Blair Witch\nrip-off. Add to that the prevailing darkness and half the time you\nsimply haven't got a clue what you're looking at: as a viewer, I felt\ninsulted. This isn't 'intriguing' or 'artistic' or 'novel', it's just\nsheer, lax arrogance. Avoid at all costs.\n"

I\nguess the most plausible reason would be that being an official movie\nadaptation of a television series, the movie would have instant\n\"branding\" and make it easier to market than a movie with a more\noriginal plot line and characters. Now Sandler and Chris\nColumbus (Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone) team up to make\nPixels, a new action comedy where aliens send real life video games\nlike Pac-Man, Centipede, Donkey Kong, and many more. Now, President\nWill Cooper (played by Kevin James of Paul Blart: Mall Cop), assembles\na team of arcade champions to fight off the games the aliens are\nprojecting down. The team consists of Sam Brenner (played by Sandler),\nLudlow Lamonsoff (played by Josh Gad of Frozen), and Eddie Plant\n(played by Peter Dinklage of Elf) to stop the aliens before its game\nover. Pixels is a great film with an engaging story, great visuals,\nfunny humor, and classic nostalgia galore!\n"

Another\naspect of the film that's so refreshing is that instead of the focus\nbeing on the villain, Batman is the film's star. And rightly so. It's\namazing what can happen when a studio leaves a respected director, and\nthe creative team alone, and allow them to make the best movie\npossible. The only two negatives that I can think of is Katie Holmes\nand the fight sequences. Holmes does indeed look like a teenager\nplaying grown-up. Her performance isn't bad per SE, it's just that you\nreally don't buy her as an Assistant D.A. As for the fight sequences, I\nfelt the cameras angles were too tight on the action, edited too\nquickly, and lit too dark so that you really couldn't tell what was\ngoing on and determine who was hitting who. Maybe we can attribute this\nto the fact that Nolan is not an action director. Hopefully the next\nfilm will open up the fight sequences so we can actually see Batman use\nthe martial arts skills he developed during his exile. But apart from\nthose relatively minor quibbles, the film is excellent, and I'm\ndefinitely going back on opening day June 15th, and seeing it a second\ntime. I was at the edge of my seat from the thrills in some scenes\nand clapping & laughing from the humorous lines that director\nChristopher Nolan had written for the characters. I was really amazed\nby the acting performances from the new generation of actors, assuming\nthat they wouldn't have been able to compete with and compliment the\ntalented, veteran actors such as Michael Caine, Morgan Freeman, Gary\nOldman, and Liam Neeson. I mean you couldn't have asked for better\nactors!! Christian Bale was just perfect for the role: he had the\nintensity, physique, and charm you'd expect a Batman character to\nencompass. Every actor was casted perfectly for their roles. I even\ngive props to Katie Holmes for playing a district attorney considering\nher previous roles consisted of \"the young girl\" or \"girlfriend\". "

                "reviewTotalVote": "61",

                "reviewUserRating": "1",
                "reviews": "\nWhat we see in this movie is the \"dark & gritty\" (TM) Batman, which was\nintroduced by Frank Miller in 1986 in the comics mini-series Dark\nKnight Returns, which was an alternate future version of Batman. But\nMiller also gave the \"real\" comics Batman the dark & gritty treatment\nin the seminal Batman: Year One story, which is perhaps the greatest\nBatman story ever created (also because of the effective artwork of the\nexcellent David Mazzuchelli), and which chronicles, among other things,\nBruce Wayne's initial (pre-Batman) martial arts training in a remote\nmountain region. In the comics, a creative force as strong as Frank\nMiller was bound to yield massive imitation by less original comics\ncreators - and so the early 1990s saw the Batman character getting\nconsistently and increasingly dark & gritty, to the extent that the\nentire Batman universe was based on that darkness and grit."
